PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin. Minister, why has the government repeatedly refused to release its legal advice on whether the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 is consistent with Australia's international legal obligations and whether it overrides the Racial Discrimination Act? When was the government advice sought; who provided it; and when was it received? Will the government now release the advice and, if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bolkus for his question. Naturally, there have been discussions within the government on legal aspects of this bill, as there must be in developing a very complex piece of legislation. We have released our legal advice from the Solicitor‐General which confirmed that the legislation is constitutional, that it is of net benefit to Aboriginal people, that it does not contravene the races power and is a legitimate exercise of the races power within the constitution, and is a bill of benefit to Aboriginal people.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not going to speculate at this stage about what advice the government may or may not have received on a whole range of legal and policy issues involved in the development of this very significant, technical and complex legislation. It is the case that on many occasions the previous government declined to say whether it had legal advice on particular issues and what advice that was. That is the traditional position adopted by governments quite properly and one pursued by the previous government on numerous occasions.

It is important to state that the Native Title Amendment Bill was drafted with very close regard for Australia's international human rights obligations. We support the principles of non‐discrimination in both the Racial Discrimination Act and the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

We note that the Native Title Act 1993 already validates past acts that might have been invalid due to the Racial Discrimination Act, and it allows for the extinguishment of native title by compulsory acquisition. The Native Title Amendment Bill adopts a very similar approach.

The Native Title Amendment Bill will similarly allow for validation although on a much more restricted scale. It continues the existing compulsory acquisition arrangements in the current act. I have had the benefit of rereading all the debates and what went on in 1993 in relation to the Native Title Act. That Native Title Act was criticised repeatedly by Aborigines and others as being inconsistent with Australia's human rights obligations and with the Racial Discrimination Act.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I never called any of you racist.

ANSWER.PARA: What the former Labor government did, and what this parliament agreed to, in order to resolve those sorts of issues, was to ensure that the act contained a provision which established the relationship between the Racial Discrimination Act and the Native Title Act. I refer to section 7(1) which states:
Nothing in this Act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 .

You all accepted that as the proper relationship between the Racial Discrimination Act and the Native Title Act. Our bill maintains exactly that provision. Our bill continues the arrangements which you, the then Labor government, and this Senate regarded as an appropriate and acceptable statement of the relationship between the Racial Discrimination Act and the Native Title Act. You ought to agree that that is the appropriate provision with which to continue in the Native Title Amendment Bill which we are proposing to you.

This bill is not racially discriminatory. It preserves and protects the common law right to claim native title, and it does so on 79 per cent of the Australian mainland. It respects the integrity and the decisions of the High Court in Mabo and Wik in full.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I note in your answer reference to section 7(1) of the Native Title Act. Minister, isn't it true that in the High Court decision in Western Australia v. Commonwealth, on page 484, the six majority judges held:

QUESTION.PARA: Section 7(1) provides no basis for interpreting the Native Title Act as subject to the Racial Discrimination Act.

Minister, how can you, as you just did, claim that the Native Title Act as amended by your bill will be subject to the Racial Discrimination Act when the High Court has already established that subsection 7(1) does not have that effect? How can you justify the selective release of legal opinions from the Solicitor‐General in respect of constitutionality when you will not release the opinions with respect to breach of international obligations and the Racial Discrimination Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said was not what Senator Bolkus wishes to report. I said that the former Labor government established the appropriate legal relationship between the Racial Discrimination Act and the Native Title Act as being described in section 7(1), which states:

ANSWER.PARA: Nothing in this Act affects the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 .

We have continued with exactly that clause. We are continuing exactly the legal relationship established by the former Labor government with regard to those two pieces of legislation. Our bill is not racially discriminatory; we categorically reject that accusation. We are preserving the special common law right available only to people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent to claim common law native title in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. I refer the minister to the unprecedented success of this week's flotation of one‐third of Telstra and ask the minister—
—Flotation? I mean—really!

—This is very painful for the opposition, who opposed it, but I ask you to listen, please. You must be embarrassed, but I am going to ask the minister anyway. Minister, what is the government's position in relation to any further sale of Telstra after the next election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that it was indeed an unprecedented success in the annals of Australian economic history. It delivered enormous benefits to all those who invested in it. It certainly delivers benefits to consumers. It means that, for the first time, in excess of 600,000 people are new shareholders and therefore have a direct stake in the Australian economy. Nearly 1.9 million people and institutions subscribed to shares in Telstra. As a result, taxpayers will benefit to the tune of $14 billion‐plus. In addition, Australians will have the benefit of the $1 billion Natural Heritage Trust and those in regional and remote areas will benefit from the $250 million regional telecommunications infrastructure fund.

ANSWER.PARA: None of this could have occurred if we had not got this bill through, in the teeth of opposition from that crowd opposite who were not interested in the slightest, despite the fact they privatised everything in sight, in the merits of the argument; they were simply interested in doing what their masters told them—that is, to not, in any shape or form, weaken union power and allow any more privatisations through in opposition. Our position is perfectly clear. We made it plain before the last election that, if we were to seek a mandate for any further sale of Telstra, we would do that in the context of an election. That remains our commitment. We have made no decision whether or not to proceed to sell down any more of Telstra.

That is in stark contrast to the position of the opposition. It is critically important to understand this, because at the moment the Labor Party platform, which is to go forward to the national conference, merely talks about retaining Telstra in majority public ownership. As Senator Ray told the Senate on 29 October:
What the platform says is that we believe in majority ownership of Telstra, and that is exactly where we are at.

What he is at is having a lend of the likes of Senator Faulkner, who, presumably, if he still has any factional commitment to anything, would be in there arguing tooth and nail for no further sell down.

Senator Ray was prepared to give us a short lecture on the difference between platform and policy. I think we all understand what platforms are about. They are about stating where you stand in principle. We have no in principle objection to any further sell down. Does the Labor Party? The platform is the document in which to make that clear. If the Labor Party believe that simply selling down 51 per cent is okay by them, then you retain the wording of the platform as it currently is which says you simply believe in majority public ownership. I hope Senator George Campbell is taking great notice of this because that platform leaves it wide open to sell down another 16 per cent.

When we have Senator Ray telling the Senate that a future Labor government will not sell one share more in Telstra than has been sold off by this government, and Mr Beazley saying that they do not think this much of Telstra should have been sold and that there will certainly be no more sold, why wouldn't they be prepared to reflect that as the in principle position in their platform? All they need to say is that they do not believe in any further sell down and that they believe in the maximum possible public ownership.

If that is their position, let them say so. Otherwise, this dissembling makes Murray Farquhar look like a choirboy. The fact is that they are trying to have it both ways. They are trying to carry out the usual mass of deceits and distractions. They are simply not prepared to face up to the fact that this has been a huge success. The majority of the party do not like it, but of course the leaders are wanting to keep their options open. If that is the way it is, if that is the way you are going to have it, then we understand it. Your platform allows a further sell down and that is your formal position. If it doesn't, then change it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his excellent answer and am prompted to ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware of any alternative approaches to the future ownership of Telstra? Do any of those approaches commend themselves to the government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —Apart from that obvious proposition—that the Labor Party wants to keep its options open and in the platform make it plain that it is prepared to sell down another 16 per cent if necessary—the only other alternative approach is that espoused by Senator Schacht who is still in the business of arguing that Telstra ought to be broken up, presumably along the Keating model lines of separating core and non‐core businesses. That is what you said in your press release when you endorsed the criticism made by the NCC. You said that there should have been an inquiry carried out before any privatisation was embarked on in order to establish whether there were core parts of the business that ought to be retained. You wanted an examination of whether or not it should be broken up into pieces. That is the alternative. If you get a guernsey at the national conference—it is not looking too good at the moment, but if you are even able to be there as an observer—presumably that is what you will be arguing for. You will have Senator Faulkner arguing for maximum possible public ownership and you will have Senator Ray arguing for a majority. It is a dog's breakfast. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill. Minister, are you aware of claims made by the former Australian Ambassador to Honduras, Mr Richard Broinowski, that he learned in January that Robert Dunn was in the Honduras area? Is it a fact that Mr Broinowski sent a lengthy cable to Canberra detailing his conversations with Honduran authorities on possible extradition arrangements? Is it also a fact that, having received no response from Canberra to his original cable, Mr Broinowski telephoned to confirm that it had in fact been received and then sent it again, in his words, `just to be on the safe side'? Is it a fact that no response was ever provided to Mr Broinowski? Is it also a fact that his cable was passed on to Mr Downer's office?

—I heard the interview with Mr Broinowski this morning. I am advised that the Attorney-General's Department contacted DFAT in March and advised that they did not know the whereabouts of Mr Dunn but heard that he might be in Honduras. I am further advised that former Ambassador Broinowski, who was accredited to Honduras, was asked that day to seek information regarding extradition and deportation procedures applicable in Honduras, in response to a request from the Attorney-General's Department, and that he followed up on the issue during a visit to Honduras shortly afterwards. I understand that he reported to DFAT by cable on 17 March 1997 of the situation. A copy of that cable was passed to the Attorney-General's Department, which, of course, has primary responsibility for extradition matters, and was taken into account. I understand that Mr Broinowski's report did not, of itself, indicate that Mr Dunn was in Honduras.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the answer given by the minister, I ask: is it a fact that Mr John Westacott has claimed that the AFP's Washington office only had a travel budget of $12,000 and therefore lacked the resources to track down Robert Dunn? Is it a fact that it was the AFP who tipped off 60 Minutes as to Mr Dunn's whereabouts rather than pursue him themselves, because of their limited resources?
—That is a different matter entirely. On that matter I have no relevant information, and I will seek advice.

—Madam President, my question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, what action is the government taking to turn the Beazley $10 billion budget black hole into a surplus over the life of this parliament? What would be the impact on taxes, interest rates, budget deficit and government debt if this does not occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Gibson, for that important question. Senator Gibson, I think everybody knows of this government's determination to restore fiscal responsibility to the nation's finances. Indeed, this determination has been widely welcomed, I believe, throughout the community.

ANSWER.PARA: In brief, as you said, we are determined to take the $10.3 billion deficit we inherited from the Labor Party and transform it into a surplus within this term. This action by the government has helped cut debt; it has helped to lower interest rates; it has helped build a platform for strong and sustainable growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Job growth? Not likely!
—Senator Schacht calls out. He always calls out when others are on their feet—other than Senator Richard Alston, we have to note, Senator Schacht.
—Do not.
—Yes, you do, Schachty. We all know it over here, Senator.
—Senator Kemp!

—Thank you, Madam President. As you can see, the loudest calls opposing this action by the government have come from the Labor Party. They have relentlessly opposed the fiscal repair of the budget over the last two budgets. On top of that, of course, they oppose the $14 billion sale of Telstra. That is what they oppose, Madam President.

ANSWER.PARA: As we saw over the last five years of the Labor government, the Labor Party prescription was to rack up budget deficits in the order of $70 billion. The performance of the Labor Party in this really vital area of getting fiscal policy right in this country, of getting the fundamentals right, has been noted in the press and elsewhere. For example, last week an editorial in the Australian Financial Review said:
And, in Opposition, Labor has repeatedly scaremongered whenever the Government has sought to repair its—
meaning Labor's—
fiscal damage.
Furthermore, the ALP draft platform would provide:
. . . government force‐feeding to pump up the economy in ways that would fuel inflation and increase the risks of the old boom‐bust cycle.
And we all remember, of course, the recession we had to have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Boring!
—`Boring', says the Labor senator.
—You are boring.

—It is not boring, Senator, to have low inflation, low interest rates and a budget which is running into surplus. That is not boring, Senator—that is hard work, and that is one thing that the Labor Party could never do. To top it all off, Labor have opposed our Charter of Budget Honesty.

ANSWER.PARA: Madam President, this is not new Labor; this is tired, failed Labor with a twist of Whitlam's budget responsibility—or lack of responsibility—thrown in. It has nothing to do with Tony Blair; in fact, it is well wedged between Whitlam and Keating.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, Senator Parer. Minister, can you confirm that the Prime Minister, in his statement announcing his new campaign to combat the drugs menace, placed emphasis on stopping drugs before they come across our borders? Is the minister aware that, on 5 November 1997, the Port Kembla office of the Australian Customs Service asked the Wollongong shark patrol to provide a surveillance flight for one of its officers at no charge because they lacked the funds to pay for it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I did notice, some time ago, quite an outrageous statement, I might say, by the Premier of New South Wales in regard to drugs when he tried to absolve his own police force from any involvement with the drug strategy.

ANSWER.PARA: The national illicit drug strategy announced by the Prime Minister introduces some important measures which will better equip Customs to deal with the traffic of illicit drugs. The strategy fully recognises the importance of working smarter to overcome this illegal barrier, and that better intelligence is an important element. Customs will engage an additional seven intelligence analysts. The ready exchange of intelligence and sensitive operational information between Customs, the Australian Federal Police and the NCA will be boosted with the development of a secure, high volume communications network. New information handling technologies will enable the increasing volume of information to be handled more effectively.

The development of national reporting standards for law enforcement agencies will open the way for a common intelligence pool. Further assistance will be provided to develop a new cargo profiling system to analyse advance information on cargo, to provide Customs with greater scope to target suspect consignments without causing disruption to the flow of legitimate goods. The acquisition of new Customs examination facilities, fully equipped with modern handling and search equipment, will permit Customs to examine more containerised cargo.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I did not interrupt the minister to ask him if he could actually answer my question, so perhaps he might be able to take it on notice. The question was: firstly, does the Prime Minister's new drug strategy place an emphasis on stopping drugs before they come across our border; and, secondly, is the minister aware of this request of the Wollongong shark patrol?
—Yes, the new strategy does in fact address the matter of coming across the border.
—What about the shark control?

—Madam President, we have interjecting from the other side Senator Schacht, who was the minister for customs, who did nothing and who, I might say, during their period in government cut back 300 Customs officers. That is what Senator Schacht did when they were in government. He has the gall to come in here and be critical of this government, which is seriously ad dressing a very serious problem in this country, which is the drug strategy.

—Madam President, I take a point of order. I hope the minister has sat down because of my point of order and not because he has concluded his answer. The minister has not, in the last minute, even addressed what I raised, for a second time, in my supplementary question.
—Order! There are still 17 seconds available, if the minister wishes to avail himself of it.

—Thank you, Madam President. What the opposition clearly avoids is recognising the package that takes into account the surveillance arrangements in the Torres Strait, which is a very serious area. The government has directed $6.7 million to improving Australia's coastal surveillance and detection capacity in that area. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment. Minister, I am pleased that many companies have signed onto the so‐called greenhouse challenge in good faith. However, isn't it true that this program does not involve setting sector specific targets for reduction, against which individual contributors can actually be accounted? Isn't it true that there are no obligations on any company to go beyond `no regrets' measures, and isn't it true that there is no obligation on any company to actually meet their stated reduction targets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got it closer to correct than usual, if I might say so, with respect, Senator. This is a voluntary program with Australian business and other organisations. It has now been extended to include local and state government organisations, industry groups, and some federal departments, I am pleased to say, including the department that is responsible for this building.

ANSWER.PARA: The concept is that these organisations, within a `no regrets' envelope, will seek to do all that is reasonably possible to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions. They are under an obligation to, firstly, prepare an inventory of their emissions to analyse what potential reductions can be made, and then to demonstrate to the Commonwealth government through the Greenhouse Challenge Office that they are in fact going to the barrier of `no regrets', that they are doing all that is possible to reduce their greenhouse emissions consistent with not undermining their economic credibility—in other words, `no regrets' being that you are seeking to achieve a better environmental outcome that is consistent with not a worse economic outcome.

This cooperative scheme has been incredibly successful, I might say, Madam President. As you would know, it has been taken up by other governments around the world. President Clinton announced the other day that he was setting up a similar scheme for the United States. In this country, agreements have now been reached with a hundred different companies and organisations, which is very pleasing. Each of those companies and organisations have entered into an agreement with the Commonwealth government consistent with the outline that I have just put to you. The result is a very substantial reduction of business as usual in terms of greenhouse gases.

Furthermore, the contribution to the change of culture in relation to energy production is also very significant. What is particularly pleasing to us is the way that Australian companies are now almost competing with each other for the best environmental bottom lines. There are few better ways that I can think of to ultimately achieve a better greenhouse contribution as a nation as a whole than to have Australian corporates approaching the challenge in that light.

So, yes, Madam President, this is a voluntary scheme. It has now been going for a few years. It has been remarkably successful. We have a hundred companies and organisations committed. More are coming on line all the time. I simply take this opportunity to congratulate those companies and organisations that have participated with government in this way. I would also like to congratulate the Greenhouse Challenge Office and staff, who I think have done a remarkably good job. The contribution that Australian corporates are making through this scheme is something that is recognised and appreciated by all reasonable Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, if we do look around the world at countries that have had similar programs operating for some time, isn't it true that the most sophisticated of those self‐regulatory models is that of the Netherlands? Doesn't the Netherlands program involve setting sector specific targets based on an independent assessment of the potential for energy conservation and the adoption of multi‐year plans as the basis for long‐term signed agreements between the environment ministry and sectoral associations? So I ask: why don't we go the next step—we have a good basis—such as countries like the Netherlands have done, to really make a difference?

—To some extent we are doing that in the sense that these companies have to be able to satisfy the Greenhouse Challenge Office that they are achieving their full potential, and that does require a certain amount of benchmarking. I agree that the Netherlands have got quite a good program. Those who study these things seem to refer to either the Australian program or the Netherlands program as leading the world. So, to the extent that you praise the Netherlands, I would like to think that you were also praising Australian corporates, but I suspect that would be too much to expect of the Australian Democrats. Nevertheless, I am pleased that Senator Lees acknowledges the importance of these voluntary programs of this type and the benefit that can be contributed by corporates acting responsibly within the national interest and within their bottom line.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration, Senator Kemp. How does the government justify replacing the newly developed finance information resource management system, FIRM, which cost $12 million, with an off‐the‐shelf inferior software package? Is it true that the KPMG scoping study for the sale, which the government has refused to make public, did not establish a business case for its sale? Is it true that the overseas package bought to replace FIRM does not satisfy the departmental requirements for accrual accounting?
—Thank you for that question. It is an interesting question. I have not got a brief on it. I will take the question on notice and respond as soon as possible.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What is the cost of the new package and was this decision to replace FIRM made on advice from IBM Global Services?

—Madam President, I think that again shows the problem of having a written supplementary without listening to the answer. I mentioned to Senator Lundy that I did not have a brief on that from the Minister for Finance and Administration. Therefore, I will put those questions to him and will inform the Senate in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Has the minister noted comments by Labor Senator Quirke that Australia could benefit from a sensible expansion of uranium mining and the uranium industry? Does this position reflect government policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —After the last election, the coalition abandoned the farcical and absurd Labor Party three‐mine policy. What we said at the time was that we would not pick winners; it is a matter for the industry to go out and find its markets, but it must go through a proper environmental impact assessment process.

ANSWER.PARA: The ALP is suffering from multiple personalities. Senator Quirke's comment that `Australia could benefit from a sensible expansion of uranium mining and the uranium industry' is sensible and is in accord with government view. Best of luck, Senator Quirke. Senator Quirke's statement is backed up by senior Labor figures quoted in the same article by David Penberthy in last Wednesday's Adelaide Advertiser, which stated, `It is time to scrap the three mines policy.'
The article also refers to the lunatic Left's drive to either retain the three‐mine policy or institute a no mines policy.

BREAK.PARA: When we consider the ALP's recruitment of Ms Kernot, it would appear that the lunatic Labor Left have a new ally. In a notice of motion to the Senate in June 1995, then Senator Kernot moved:
That the Senate calls on the Government to ban the mining and export of all uranium from Australia.
What she was saying was that she wanted to shut down Olympic Dam and Ranger. That would be roughly hundreds of millions of dollars in export earnings gone.

TALK.START.PARA: —And jobs!
—Thousands of jobs gone. The Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, recently stated that Ms Kernot shares the Labor Party's values. What are these values? No mines—they are the values.

BREAK.PARA: In response to a question asked by then Senator Kernot in this chamber on 18 September 1995, just two years ago, then Senator Gareth Evans, in referring to Australia's involvement in uranium mining, stated:
If you do not understand these dimensions of this subject you should not be opening your mouth, Senator Kernot, in public because every time you do you make an idiot of yourself.

Then there is Carmen Lawrence—the lady with amnesia. In a press release of 24 May 1996 she stated, `Australians don't like uranium mining. It is up to us to stop it.' Apparently she could not recall that when she was Premier of Western Australia she excised the Kintyre uranium deposit from the Rudall River National Park on 18 August 1993.
Now we turn to the press release of the shadow minister for resources, Stephen Smith, on 8 October when he stated: Jabiluka is not one of the three named mines,
I might remind Mr Smith that Nabarlek shut down in 1989. So they had a mine that shut down in 1989 as one of the three mines named. He continued:
and as a consequence the uranium mine at Jabiluka approved by the Government today is not a project the Labor Party in Government could countenance.
This is the same man who has been talking about the need for policy renewal.

Veteran supporter of uranium mining Senator Bob Collins is strangely quiet at the moment, as opposed to his former days when he was quoted in the Age on 27 July 1994 as saying, `My position is we should either be in the uranium business or out of it.' In other words, he was highlighting the ridiculous Labor Party's good uranium, bad uranium stand. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister explain other factors that are relevant to government policy on uranium mining?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chapman for that question. I know Senator Collins would not like to turn his back on a project such as Jabiluka, in his own territory, which would cost something in the order of 300 jobs for his constituency, $70 million in capital expenditure and $200 million in royalties to the Aboriginal community. The confusion in the ALP becomes apparent when we consider the excellent report done by Senator Chapman, who chaired the committee on uranium mining, which ranks with reports of thoroughness and significance such as the Fox report.

ANSWER.PARA: The interesting thing is that this committee confirmed the validity of the Fox conclusions and recommendations, confirmed that existing uranium mines have not damaged the environment and was supported by five out of seven members of the committee. Guess whom they included? They included the two Labor Party members—Senator Bishop and Senator Reynolds.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Kemp, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, given that IBM Global Services has been awarded the contracts for both applications development and the IT infrastructure in the department which is making the strategic decisions and administering the IT outsourcing program, as well as participating as a tenderer for other potential IT contracts, does the minister believe there is a conflict of interest? Has the Independent Probity Auditor been asked to investigate this matter? If so, can the minister table the report? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see Senator Murphy taking an interest in the IT area. I felt there was a monopoly of concern emerging in this area, and it is good to see him taking an interest in it.

ANSWER.PARA: The government is very proud of the IT outsourcing program. It is a program, Senator Murphy, which has its origins in the previous government. It is a program which will deliver very substantial savings to government and greater efficiencies. I have been actually waiting in recent weeks for Senator Lundy to stand up and correct the errors she made in a recent speech in this parliament on savings. We will still wait for that, Senator Lundy. Senator Murphy asked about the probity audit. I will seek a response from the Minister for Finance and Administration and see whether he is prepared to table it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, what safeguards and security checks have been put in place to ensure that IBM Global Services does not obtain an unfair advantage in the tendering process through access to inside information? How can you demonstrate to the parliament and to other outsourcing vendors participating in the tendering process that there is a level playing field? Can you rule out further piggybacking of contracts to IBM Global Services?

—Again, I do not accept the assumptions that were made in that question. But, as I do in these cases, I will refer them to the Minister for Finance and Administration, who has the responsibility in this area. I will seek his response.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. With the introduction of the common youth allowance, is it not a fact that many young people will in fact lose their income support and become totally reliant upon their families? Is it a fact that the taxation department will not recognise this added impost on the family budget? Why will the taxation department not acknowledge, for the purposes of their income tax assessment, the additional burdens placed on those families by that decision of the government?

—I think, Senator, you have asked this question a number of times in relation to the common youth allowance and you raised the costs of children to these families. In the context of our policies, and to the extent we are able to, we have provided great assistance to families, as you are aware, which you welcomed. In relation to the particular matter you raised, we will not be going further than the policy that we have already announced.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister take back to the person whom he represents in this chamber the question of equity on this particular matter—that is, the equity of tax treatment of income of parents in respect of this particular matter? I would be most grateful.

—Senator, you have asked me on previous related matters to bring those questions to the attention of the Treasurer. I know your considerable interest in this matter and, of course, I will bring those to the attention of the Treasurer.

—My question is also to Senator Kemp, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. Minister, on what basis has the Department of Finance and Administration justified selling the central accounting systems? Was there an impartial business case established for the sale? Is it true that, pending this sale, the number of staff in the IT application section has been reduced from 50 to 10, making it necessary for the current development work on this system to be outsourced? Is it true that this outsourcing work has been awarded to the same company as was given the Department of Finance IT contract by way of a ministerial discretionary provision under the interim procurement guidelines to piggyback on a previously awarded contract? Does the minister believe that this constitutes a conflict of interest for this company, IBM Global Services?

—We continue to have related questions being raised on this matter, and we continue to have the attack on IBM Global Services, which we note. Senator, I will bring your questions to the attention of the responsible minister, the Minister for Finance and Administration.

—Madam President, I have a supplementary question. I appreciate that the minister says that he cannot answer that and that he will take it to the minister but, while he does that, would he also ask the Minister for Finance and Administration whether the process for the awarding of this contract has been scrutinised by the Independent Probity Auditor? If so, can he or you, Minister, table the report? If not, why not?
—That was a very similar question to the one that was asked by Senator Murphy. Senator, I will put your views to the Minister for Finance and Administration and see whether he is happy to respond.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Parer. Minister, are you aware of the announcement by Woolworths Ltd last year that they would accept imported pig meat products for sale in their supermarkets? Are you aware that this announcement has resulted in record pig meat imports since then? Minister, are you aware that, as a result of the government's announcement to allow the entry of Danish pig meat and cooked pig meat products from Canada, Chisholm Manufacturing, a processing division of Woolworths in Queensland, has since dropped the price paid to Australian producers for pigs by 10c per kilo? What is your government going to do about the massive loss of income to Australian pork producers from your government's decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley should know—but perhaps he does not—that the whole basis for determining the importation of foodstuffs, or in fact anything, into Australia is scientific purposes, a scientific background. One of the things I have tried to explain over the years to Senator Woodley, without success, is that this country—in particular, the primary industry sector—has a vested interest in getting rid of tariff and non- tariff barriers in other countries because we export more than 80 per cent of our primary products. Senator Woodley may want to go down the lunatic track—and I say it is a lunatic track—of putting non-tariff barriers on imports into this country and then having retribution from other countries where we want to put our products, but we do not want to be a party to that.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say that the recent decision, based on scientific purposes, to allow the importation of pig meat into this country received the total support of the National Farmers Federation. Senator Woodley, I know that you do not have a particular interest in rural issues. You pick up peripheral issues on the side and to hell with the general industry. Let me say that, by going down this track, you are pursuing a course which is to the detriment of the primary industries in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I cannot thank the minister for his answer, but I might just say that my question came from the Pork Council, a member of the National Farmers Federation. Minister, I will pass your answer on to them but I will try another question. Has Woolworths Ltd honoured the public agreement made last year that it would cease purchasing imported products as of January 1997 and implement a labelling system to inform consumers of the origin of the pig meat products sold in its supermarkets? Even more important, Minister, where is your labelling legislation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Amazing; I do not know who wrote that question for you, but you would know damn well, Senator Woodley, that the chances of answering that sort of broad question in one minute—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections in the chamber.

—I do not know the position with Woolworths. I will refer it to the minister and I will come back to you. But that is not to do with the importation or otherwise of foodstuffs into Australia. I thought I had made it—
—Labelling? You've got to be joking!
—Senator Collins, the question that was asked was with regard to an agreement between Woolworths and the pork producers.
—Labelling! Have you made the connection yet?
—Order! Senator Collins, you can take this matter up at the appropriate time.

—I made the position very clear that this action was welcomed by the National Farmers Federation, and the government has taken the right course—and I quote from the National Farmers Federation—by offering assistance to help the industry meet the challenge for the future. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Minister, can you confirm that you told the Senate on 21 October that the decision to abolish the Department of Administrative Services was for reasons of efficiency and effectiveness? Will you now also confirm evidence given at a Senate estimates committee that in fact no documents or formal advice of any kind was provided to the Prime Minister from PM&C recommending the abolition of DAS prior to 1 October? Is it also a fact that, according to evidence given before Senate estimates, no savings are now anticipated from the amalgamation of DAS and DoF? Finally, given the Prime Minister's petulant outburst in front of senior DAS officials at the time of the travel rorts affair, will you now admit that the real reason for abolishing the Department of Administrative Services was revenge, pure and simple?

—That was an interesting bit of political theatre but I do not think it had a genuine question involved in it. Yes, I reconfirm what I said before—the reason was efficiency and effectiveness of government administration. It is probably right that documentation was not prepared by PM&C but—
—Why not?

—Because PM&C do not make these decisions—governments do. I am a little surprised that you say there are no savings involved, because the other day you came in here and said hundreds of people will lose their jobs.

—My question is to the Special Minister of State. Is the minister aware of the Hopevale agreement in Cape York which was negotiated under the Native Title Act? Does the government have a view on the Hopevale agreement and, in view of its successful negotiation, why are amendments necessary to the Native Title Act to secure fairness and certainty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator MacGibbon—a senator from the great state of Queensland—for his question. The Commonwealth does welcome the Queensland government's approval on 11 November of a mediated agreement recognising native title at Hopevale in Far North Queensland. This agreement brought together the state and local governments, native title parties—some 13 clans were involved—the commercial fishing industry, Telstra, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, the Far North Queensland Electricity Corporation, the Cape Flattery Silica Mines and the Cape York Land Council. The Queensland coalition government really should be congratulated on its work in reaching this agreement and its recognition of native title on the Hopevale deed of grant in trust land.

ANSWER.PARA: This agreement reflects the commitment of governments—both state and federal—indigenous parties and other interests to work constructively to resolve these native title claims. The application for native title will now be referred to the Federal Court for a consent order confirming this agreement. Once approved, it would be the first determination of native title in Queensland since the Mabo decision and only the second native title matter determined through the National Native Title Tribunal's mediation process.

You may know that Hopevale is a former Lutheran mission approximately 200 kilometres north of Cairns, and it is home to traditional Aboriginal owners and historical people whose traditional lands are elsewhere. It is a credit to the native title claimants and an indication of their goodwill that the rights of these historical people to traverse, hunt and fish in the land of the claimants have been guaranteed—one of the real issues that had to be resolved in getting this agreement sorted out. The Hopevale Aboriginal Council will retain local government functions and all relevant state and Commonwealth laws will continue to apply.

Successful resolution of this claim by agreement does not mean that the need to make the Native Title Act more workable has gone away. The two native title claims in this area were lodged back in 1994 and we have only now reached agreement on the claim to recognise the native title. In this case there was a very big head start. The Bjelke‐Petersen government itself had awarded inalienable freehold title to this land back in 1986. I think we should acknowledge what the former Queensland coalition government did in 1986 in recognising that freehold title.

The delay in coming to agreement is no reflection on any of the parties involved in forming this agreement, but it is very clear evidence of the problems involved in working through the current Native Title Act. It is just such a difficult piece of legislation to work through. I must say that the Labor Party and the National Indigenous Working Group do recognise and accept that there is a very significant need to fix up the current act's inadequate voluntary agreements provisions.

The problem is that the current provisions do not guarantee legal certainty for agreements about native title. That is a fundamental deficiency in the act. So our bill is essential so that fair and legally certain negotiated agreements can be a real alternative to long, drawn out and adversarial legal cases. We would of course prefer resolution of native title issues by voluntary agreements to be the norm and not the exception. It is clear that strong, negotiated agreements are absolutely fundamental if you are going to have practical coexistence on the ground.

Our encouragement for this approach is not just through rhetoric but through the bill's very detailed and sensible framework for certain and fair voluntary agreements. Once these agreement provisions are in place, as I hope they will be when this Senate rises, there will be genuine incentive to follow the approach that was successful at Hopevale.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, I refer you to your interview with the West Australian last week. Is it true that you told the West Australian that you thought that the Wik bill was `fair and just', that your relationship with Aboriginal people had not suffered in the escalating race debate and that land was not the basis for Aboriginal independence or reconciliation? How do you reconcile these views with those of ATSIC Chairman, Gatjil Djerrkura, reported in the same paper, that the Prime Minister's position on Wik was not in the broader interests of the general public, that he was deeply disappointed in your failure to comment on native title, and that land was the basis of Aboriginal identity, Aboriginal survival and Aboriginal existence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I was getting a slight attack of the QDS, question deprivation syndrome. I have been here all afternoon and after six weeks I finally got a question from Senator Bob Collins. I thank Senator Collins for the question because I want to clear up some misconceptions in this regard. Yes, I stand by those statements. I was interviewed by the West Australian . It is a pity that a bit more of that does not get into the wider spectrum of newspapers rather than the attacks that occur constantly, particularly in some of the metropolitan press. I am not looking at anybody in particular, but I think something should be done about this in the metropolitan press so the other side of the coin can be detailed.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Collins, you would be aware that I travel constantly. I have given you a list of where I have been. There are certain Aboriginal activists who state a certain position—and they are quite entitled to do so—but it is not the position of the government. I am a member of the government and I support the government's position. The position in rela tion to the 10‐point plan is a fair and equitable resolution of this situation that was foisted on us by the passage of the Native Title Act by your government. I was here in the Senate on 23 December 1993 and I well remember all the activists in the gallery stood, clapping and cheering—

TALK.START.PARA: —And we read your speech too.

—I am happy to reiterate that speech. In my speech at the time I said that this is a recipe for disaster. There were amendments being done in the corridors, as we could see advisers rushing in and rushing out of the adviser boxes. It was an absolute shambles. It was apparent even to me. I came into the chamber and I said at the time, `I know little about this. I have listened to the debate and it is obvious to me that this bill is going to be an absolute shambles.' That is what we inherited when we came into government. We were faced with trying to resolve the problems that had occurred as a result of that legislation that was passed by this chamber.

ANSWER.PARA: As you would recall too, Madam President, as I am sure everybody in the chambers would, the applause, the almost deification of Senator Evans, as he was then, for the great work that he had done—carried it entirely on his own. That result was produced and we are picking up the pieces now. We went to the last election saying that we would produce a resolution of this and that is what we are doing. It is a fair and equitable resolution of the problems that are affecting this nation.

Of course there are comments and I respect those statements. I have spoken to the chairman of ATSIC about it. Again, the dear old ABC sent a crew up there, edited what they thought was suitable for their purposes and then put it on television. I am surprised at Senator Bob Collins taking everything at face value. I always remember Malcolm Muggeridge said, `How can you disbelieve the evidence of your own eyes?' in relation to editing of television programs.

I would refer Senator Collins instead to the ATSIC army program that was broadcast on the ABC. It was a very good report on the 7.30 Report in relation to Bulla, in Senator Collins's own territory. A very good result has been obtained from the army going in to provide that resource. I would assure Senator Collins that he should not believe everything he sees on television, because of selective editing. On the other hand, he should recognise that the government is doing what is best for the nation as a whole. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for confirming at the beginning of your answer, Minister, that the West Australian report was accurate and particularly the comments that you made about land in terms of denigrating the importance that it had to Aboriginal people. I asked you to reconcile that with what Gatjil Djerrkura said. I now ask you to reconcile that accurate report with the views that you expressed in a speech that you delivered to the United Nations Working Group on Indigenous Peoples in Geneva on 30 July this year when you said:

QUESTION.PARA: My Government recognises that land lies at the heart of indigenous existence, indigenous people need their land to fulfil spiritual and cultural needs, for traditional use, for living areas and for economic purposes . . .

Could you also reconcile the report with what you said later in the same speech that the Northern Territory Land Rights Act acknowledged that `affinity with the land is fundamental to Aborigines' sense of identity'? Do you have one view for export and another for domestic consumption, Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I resent the implication of that remark. But I sincerely thank Senator Collins for the supplementary question, because the answer to his question is that land is a major part, as I said in that speech to the United Nations. It is; there is no question about it, Senator Collins. You are aware of that and I am aware of it. I think everybody in the community is aware of it. But it is not the totality; it is part of the process. It is an important and fundamental part of the process, but it is not the totality. I think even Senator Collins might try to understand that it is but part of the process.

ANSWER.PARA: Housing, education and employment are important parts of it as well. That is what we are addressing: the fundamentals that were not addressed by the previous government. Thirteen years they had, and we are now faced with dismal statistics. We are doing something about it, and I think it should be to our credit. I do not resile from any of the remarks. They are all compatible and consistent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Justice, Senator Vanstone. Minister, the alleged paedophile Mr Robert `Dolly' Dunn was recently deported from Honduras to the United States where he is now facing extradition hearings. There have been reports that the Australian government knew of Dunn's presence in Honduras 10 months prior to his arrest and deportation. Mr Beazley this morning alleged that AFP budget cuts were responsible for the delay in locating Mr Dunn. Will the minister set the record straight on the facts surrounding the international search for Mr Dunn?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Heffernan for the question, because it does give me the opportunity to set the record straight, to endorse the remarks made in the other place by both the Attorney and the Prime Minister and in this place by Senator Hill but to add some additional information. Mr Broinowski has suggested that Commonwealth authorities knew of the whereabouts of `Dolly' Dunn in Honduras for some 10 months prior to taking action.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts are simply these. The then ambassador was advised early in March this year that Dunn's whereabouts were `at present unknown' at that time but that the Attorney‐General's Department had heard that he might be in the Honduras. He was asked to give a general overview of extradition arrangements from the Honduras and went on to do that.

Mr Broinowski claims that his cable was not acted on. It is important to understand that Mr Broinowski does not have the entire picture. As I understand it, he is not privy to what the AFP did subsequent to February and March. That is not surprising, because an ambassador is not a part of the law enforcement authorities that Australia uses. He was asked to provide some information from the Honduras and did so. Diplomats are not used generally to hunt for fugitives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe they should be.
—An additional point is that the AFP discharged its responsibilities in this matter quite properly through the appropriate channels.
—We thought he was supposed to be a No. 1 fugitive.
—Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—The AFP made the appropriate inquiries through Interpol. Interpol is the proper and acceptable channel for these matters. Australian police do not have the right to fly around the world and investigate or conduct matters in other countries, just as police from other countries do not have the right to fly in here and do as they choose here. Interpol is the appropriate network to work through.

ANSWER.PARA: As soon as the presence of Mr Dunn was confirmed in the Honduras and his location was identified, an AFP liaison officer was dispatched to the Honduras, and the work that had already been commenced was finalised with respect to Mr Dunn's extradition.
Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bolkus, cease interjecting!

—The additional point that I wanted to make is that the suggestion has been put that this investigation has in some way been impeded by cuts to the AFP. You would expect opportunists such as those on the other side to make that point. You would expect them, even on a matter as serious as this, to use every cheap political point they could.

ANSWER.PARA: But there are two points to make here. Firstly, the number of AFP liaison officers has not changed from under the previous government to this government. Additionally, during question time today—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of interjection is too great, and some of it is sledging and not interjection that is relevant to the question in any event.

—The suggestion was made that AFP liaison people were not operating earlier in the Honduras, despite the fact that, if they went there, they would not be operative police; they would be liaising with the Honduras police—
—Ask a supplementary, Bill.
—Senator Schacht! You have been persistently interjecting.

—But it is true that the budgetary allocation for travel for the Washington AFP liaison officer is in this financial year $12,000. What the opposition might like to have told everybody is that in the previous two years, including under their government, the notional allocation was $11,000.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, 17 November, I was asked questions by Senator Neal in relation to therapeutic drugs and by Senator Denman in relation to contracts to pay nursing home bonds. I seek leave to incorporate the answers in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The answers read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Therapeutic Drugs

SENATOR NEAL—My question is directed to Senator Herron representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. What steps has the government taken to inform pharmacists, general practitioners and patients how the introduction of the therapeutic group premiums policy will be handled? What plans have been made for the transition to the new system?
Answer:

The Government has planned, in consultation with consumer, medical, pharmacy and industry representatives, an information program to advise consumers, their carers and health professionals about therapeutic group premiums.

The information program will begin with the release of medicine pricing information and details of the exemption criteria in the next couple of weeks and continue beyond the 1 February 1998 implementation date for the initiative.

SENATOR NEAL—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. . . Can you assure Australians, particularly elderly Australians, that the policy change to pharmaceuticals will not become another disaster like your nursing homes policy?
Answer:

The elderly are the main users and beneficiaries of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS). The Government overall, covers 80 per cent of the full cost of PBS medicines. The elderly are also the people who will benefit most if the Scheme is more cost effective and able to cover important new medicines as they emerge.

The government is saying that where there are a number of choices, we will fund a set price for the alternatives. It is a choice for the doctor and patient to decide if they want to choose a more expensive version. Like brand premiums introduced by the opposition when in government, therapeutic premiums are an avoidable price signal. Where a doctor and patient do decide that a drug above the base should be used, the average premium is likely to be under $2. At the same time, the Government will protect those people who must stay on a particular medication for clinical reasons through the authority prescription arrangements.
Nursing Homes
SENATOR DENMAN asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:
Is the Government now in a position to say how many people signed contracts to pay nursing home bonds?
SENATOR HERRON—The Minister for Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
According to information provided by the Accommodation Bond Trust Scheme Manager, 112 nursing home residents have agreed and paid a bond, while a further 22 have agreed but not yet paid.
SENATOR DENMAN asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family Services on 17 November 1997:

Can you confirm that Aged Care Assessment Teams at Sydney's Prince of Wales Hospital are finding it increasingly difficult to place concessional residents—that is, people who do not have the money to pay entry fees of any kind—in nursing homes? Can the government ensure the Australian community that all nursing homes are following the requirement to provide 27% of beds for financially disadvantaged older Australians?
SENATOR HERRON—The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

The Randwick Botany Aged Care Assessment Team in NSW provides assessment services to the region that encompasses the Prince of Wales Hospital. The ACAT is located in the nearby suburb of Zetland and is not located within the hospital.
The Department has received no information that this ACAT is experiencing difficulty obtaining access for concessional residents.

The Department will be closely monitoring achievement of each facility's concessional ratio. Aged care providers are required by law to meet the minimum ratio for their region and face tough penalties if they fail to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 November, Senator Quirke asked me a question in question time relating to higher education and the students' hotline. I undertook to get an answer for him, and I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—
EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION, TRAINING AND YOUTH AFFAIRS SENATE LEGISLATION COMMITTEE 1997-98 BUDGET SUPPLEMENTARY HEARING QUESTIONS ON NOTICE
Programme: 2—Higher Education

TAB.TAB: 2.1—Higher Education System

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to yesterday's question.
Senator Quirke asked on 17 November, draft Hansard page 8752
Question:

. My question is addressed to The Minister representing the Minister for Employment Education Training and Youth Affairs. Can you confirm that the `Dob in a don ` hotline proposal is now regarded by the government as another failed initiative by the former education minister?
Can you confirm reports that the hotline proposal which Senator Vanstone maintained would provide a picture of students' experience, has been canned?

PARA.EMPHASIS: Answer:

SPEECH.PARA: In response to Senator Quirke's question I can now provide the following answer.
