SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to questions without notice asked by Senators Lundy, Murphy and O'Brien today, relating to government proposals to `outsource' information technology.

We have a situation in the Department of Finance and Administration where a number of ministerial decisions have led to the same corporation and their partners controlling both the IT infrastructure and the applications development aspects of the same department which is implementing the whole of government IT outsourcing program. The significance of this lies in the fact that it is the same group of companies that has access to infor mation relating to the strategic development of that whole process.

How IBM Global Services got this particular contract in the first place is another area of concern that has been well canvassed in this place, given that they did not even have to participate in a competitive tendering process. They were awarded the contract by the minister utilising a discretionary provision under the interim guidelines after an unsolicited approach, in the first instance, from IBM Global Services to the Department of Finance and Administration. Interestingly, the original contract that was piggybacked upon by IBM Global Services was awarded prior to this government's IT outsourcing program being implemented through the original PE68 IT panel. At the time, there was angst as to the loss of that contract from the original vendor, Ferntree, amidst public speculation that IBM came in below cost.

In retrospect, it is not difficult to speculate upon the value of that investment. IBM Global Services have since picked up $70 million worth of contract work in IT outsourcing without having to prepare one additional tender. What an investment! While the rest of the industry is now complaining quite vigorously about the magnitude and complexity of some 15 clusters that are now proposed under the government's IT outsourcing program, IBM has cruised through. Now we find that a partner, Computer Power, is also involved in the applications development work of that particular department.

This is a critical issue in terms of due process and public accountability. In contrast, if there were to be in-house bids, the government would have made sure that there were strict competitive neutrality principles applying, but it seems that this was just too hard for the government to institute. I believe, at the behest of the larger corporations participating in this process, that the government excluded the opportunity for in-house bids in the IT outsourcing program. What we have now is no process to check the competitive neutrality of what is now occurring within the Department of Finance and Administration.

BREAK.PARA: The minister was quick to crow about the Independent Probity Auditor that he announced to put in place some semblance of checks and balances on the IT outsourcing program, but we are yet to see any evidence that this Independent Probity Auditor has been able to apply any viewpoints or any critique upon the process. If that has occurred, that information has not been able made available to the parliament. Why is it that probity is not getting an airing in this area of IT outsourcing?

Today we have seen, through questions to the minister, some examples of specific issues that are worthy of scrutiny, that are worthy of some response from this government. It is not surprising that a perception is building that there is, at best, an uneven playing field and, at worst, a serious breach of due process and a blatant conflict of interest.

We have asked for some answers on specific matters to clarify these critical questions of probity but, as yet, they have not been forthcoming. No contract has yet been awarded under the government's IT outsourcing program—they have only been given away to IBM-GSA—and neither should there be. It is a flawed process, and the recent Senate inquiry into this issue exposed the flaws in this government's IT outsourcing program.

The program should be stopped at this point and a rethinking of the whole strategy should occur. The government should commit themselves to not doing any further piggybacking and bypassing of the competitive tendering process. The government should also get themselves a minister who can at least keep himself briefed on what is a critical issue of both public accountability for government administration and industry development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The questioning by a number of opposition senators this afternoon really followed very closely a number of issues that were canvassed in a recent inquiry by the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee. That committee was chaired by Senator Murphy—a person who asked a number of questions. While we are on air I think it is useful to note that, in reading much of the metropolitan daily press, one would have hardly been aware of the fact that there was a very significant minority report to that references committee report which, in most papers, never rated a mention. In those papers that did, there was scarcely a paragraph or there was just a line or two.

SPEECH.PARA: What was important in that minority report was that the government members comprehensively refuted each of the issues that were raised in the majority report. I think there was only one article in the press that actually acknowledged this fact. So I ask: where is the democracy in this country if the media are not prepared to provide balanced reporting on such a significant and important issue? If the Canberra press gallery continues to provide such a one-sided ideological approach to an important issue of outsourcing, then I ask: where is democracy? Where is the public going to be able to fully understand this issue? I think it is important that this issue was raised this afternoon to give government members the opportunity to speak to the wider audience, through the broadcast of these particular issues, and to be able to put a correct position to the people of Australia.

One would scarcely have realised this afternoon in all the questioning to Senator Kemp that Senator Kemp is not the minister for finance and that he is not the minister for outsourcing. In fact, that is handled in the other House by the very responsible Minister for Finance and Administration, Mr Fahey—the minister who was, incidentally, responsible for the very important and successful sale of Telstra. I think all Australians would be applauding the capable manner in which this very successful minister handled the sale of Telstra.

The point that must be understood is that Minister Kemp merely represents the Minister for Finance and Administration. Every time the present opposition were unsure of the detail—and these questions went to detail—and sought a comprehensive reply, effectively Senator Kemp, as a very competent and effective minister, took those questions on notice.

I think it is important to note that the information technology arena is an environment which is moving very rapidly. It is moving so rapidly that the minority report agrees with the present and previous governments that it would have been more efficient and more effective for the Commonwealth to have these IT services delivered by the private sector. The Labor Party now that they are in opposition are taking an entirely different approach to outsourcing and the responsibilities. They are taking a different approach to privacy issues from the one they took when they were in government. They paid scant regard to privacy issues in the contracts that they outsourced when they were in government.

Our government, the Liberal‐National coalition, has taken on board very strict privacy issues, set down standards of behaviour and conduct, and put heavy reliance on issues such as the Crimes Act, the Privacy Commissioner and so on. Our government is very confident that the consolidation and outsourcing of IT infrastructure, if proven by a market test, will help address and greatly improve the often poorly performing, coordinated and costly systems that have existed in the past. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very interested in Senator Watson's comment with regard to Senator Kemp being a very competent minister. Senator Kemp cannot come in here and represent the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey), which he is supposed to do.
—He doesn't have to; he only has to take note.
—That is what he is supposed to do, Senator Watson. He is supposed to be able to come in here and answer questions. That is what he is supposed to do, but he cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the whole outsourcing issue, what a shemozzle the government has turned this into; what a cock‐up. The government could not have gotten itself into a worse position if it had tried. This is what is really interesting: it proceeded down the path of the philosophy of competitiveness, openness and allowing the private sector to openly compete for tenders and government contracts in a fair and equitable way. But what has it done?

BREAK.PARA: Let me quote a few statements from the minister in respect of that—that is, the real minister, not the minister who comes in here and pretends to represent the minister. On 25 April this year, the Minister for Finance and Administration, Mr Fahey, announced the government's decision to outsource its information technology infrastructure. Statements made in that announcement and since have clearly shown that this government continues, true to form, to say one thing and do another.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's an open and competitive process.

—I will quote for Senator Watson's benefit in particular some of the things the minister said. On the issue of privacy, in referring to the government's decision to outsource its IT infrastructure, Minister Fahey said in a press statement on 25 April:

BREAK.PARA: . . . this initiative will address two other priority matters. First, to ensure the privacy of personal and other sensitive information through stringent contractual conditions—

TALK.START.PARA: —Correct. Exactly what I said.
—We will get to that in a minute, Senator Watson. On the transparent competitive tendering matter, the minister said:

BREAK.PARA: The move to more open, competitive processes for delivery of IT infrastructure services is in keeping with the Government's election commitment to streamline the administration . . .
On competitive neutrality, the minister said:
The Government is determined that for outsourced projects, the private sector will compete with the public sector on an equal footing.
That is what competitive neutrality is all about.

Those are very interesting statements from the minister. But what have we seen? I have to say it is all here in the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines . This is the guide that agency and departmental heads are supposed to use when they let contracts. What does it say with regard to open and effective competition? Let us just have a little read. In the preamble it says:
Open and effective competition is the central operating principle of Commonwealth procurement . . .

I do not know how IBM Global Services got $30 million worth of government business when a tender was not even called for. It was not even gazetted. With respect to that, section 6 of the government's own Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines under the heading `Contracts arranged' says:

Finance Regulation 43B requires that agencies notify in the (Purchasing and Disposals) Gazette details of any contract arranged for supplies to be procured or used in Australia where the total estimated liability is $2,000 or more.

Why did they not advertise the $30 million department of finance arrangements instead of piggybacking them and handing them over to IBM Global Services? More importantly, a subsidiary company of that company has secured a contract for the servicing of the IT infrastructure in the Department of Finance and Administration, as it now is.

How does that leave the security? How does that not open up the way for those companies to have access to inside information? Why is that not the case? What is the government going to do about that? I would suggest it is going to do nothing other than continue to make a cock‐up of this whole process, as you have done to date, Senator Watson. You ought to have a very clear think about it.

The minister that you say cannot come in here and represent the minister for finance ought to have a very clear think about what the government is doing in terms of IT outsourcing because, to date, all it has done is create another nursing home fracas, and it is going to be a total disaster for the IT industry in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self‐determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate the Australian Government's hesitation in signing the Ottawa Treaty to ban the production, sale, stockpiling, transfer and use of landmines.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support the Ottawa process
2. immediately sign the Ottawa Treaty to ban landmines.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows our concern that Australia should fully participate in a comprehensive global ban on anti‐personnel landmines.
Your Petitioners ask that the Parliament should act to have Australia:
sign the treaty in Ottawa to ban the use, production, stockpiling and transfer of anti‐personnel landmines and to seek to persuade other nations which have not signed to sign;
increase its current spending on the elimination of landmines laid in foreign countries.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Allison, Sen Lyn; Bourne, Sen Vicki
PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Allison(from 31 citizens)and Senator Bourne(from 140 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that "The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC".
2. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicly owned organisation.
3. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows strong opposition to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, which aims to amend the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and the Occupational, Health and Safety Act.
This Bill is opposed because:
1. Outlawing claims arising from `reasonable management action' is a direct assault on the long held principle of no fault workers compensation.
2. The Bill's definition of `significant contribution of work' is the toughest of any compensation legislation in Australia, and will see many workers' otherwise valid claims rejected.
3. Requiring Comcare to investigate the private life of every worker who makes a claim is a gross attack on civil liberties and will discourage people in genuine need from applying.
4. The Bill's provisions will in no way assist in the reduction or prevention of illness or injury in the workplace.
5. The wording of the Bill allows for wide interpretation, which makes it bad law.
6. There are no adequate financial reasons to tighten the Comcare compensation scheme to the detriment of all workers.
Your Petitioners therefore request that the Senate oppose the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 in its entirety.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned pensioners and citizens of Australia hereby call upon the Australian Government to cancel the current charges for entry into a nursing home by frail aged peoples of Australia. We point out that over many years the Private Nursing Home Industry has distributed large profits to shareholders, neglecting the need to upgrade buildings and facilities. We further call upon the Government to publish the profits of the Private Nursing Home Industry, before tax, over the past five years.

Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to direct the Government to provide a system that ensures that frail aged Australians be free from the stress and strains of the huge environmental changes of lifestyle in entering a nursing home and the uncertainty of a better quality of life in their twilight years. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Airport: Sydney Basin
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
(a) a proposal has been made by the Department of Transport to build a major no‐curfew international airport in Sydney's western suburbs;
(b) airports and attendant infrastructure are a major source of air and noise pollution;
(c) Western Sydney already suffers from the worst air pollution in Australia;
(d) an additional airport in the Sydney airshed will only serve to greatly increase such pollution; and
(e) an airport in Sydney's west will harm the lifestyle and wellbeing of citizens living and working within the Sydney airshed.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate not pass any bill which would lead to the construction of any new airport within the Sydney airshed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Genetic Manipulation, be established to inquire into and report on:

PARA.TAB: (a) the ethical issues arising from genetic manipulation and the application of this technology, also known as genetic engineering, in Australia, with special reference to humans;
(b) the likely economic and social impact on Australia of patents the subject matter of, or the claims of the patents, being directed to:

TAB.TAB: (i) deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) and ribonucleic acid (RNA) derived from animals, plants, bacteria, viruses or other things,

(ii) DNA and RNA derived from human genes including their use for the purpose of cloning human tissue(s), detecting and treating human illnesses and diseases and the treating of humans howsoever described,

(iii) DNA and RNA derived from non‐human genes including their use for the purpose of cloning tissue(s), detecting and treating illnesses and diseases and the treating of animals, plants, bacteria, viruses or other things howsoever described, and
(iv) proteins derived from DNA and RNA for use in the detection or treatment of illness or disease and the treating of animals, plants, bacteria, viruses or other things howsoever described;

PARA.TAB: (c) the public interest requirements of existing regulations in the granting of patents for inventions involving genetic manipulation;
(d) international developments in the regulation of genetic manipulation and genetically‐manipulated products;
(e) the regulation and use of genetically‐modified food and food components in Australian agriculture, manufacture, sale and consumption; and
(f) the regulation of arrangements for the research, testing and release of genetically‐modified materials in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) That the committee present its final report on or before 30 June 1998.

(3) That the committee consist of 9 senators, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, and 3 nominated by minor groups or independents.
(4) That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that not all members have been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5) That the committee elect as chair one of the members nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

(6) That the chair of the committee may, from time to time, appoint another member of the committee to be the deputy chair of the committee, and that the member so appointed act as chair of the committee at any time when there is no chair or the chair is not present, at a meeting of the committee.
(7) That, in the event of an equality of voting, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.
(8) That a quorum of the committee be 4 members.

(9) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(10) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of 4 or more of its members and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(11) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(12) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it and that a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes, with alarm, the National Association of Community Based Children's Services survey which shows that:

PARA.TAB: (i) 73 per cent of families exiting care cited fee increases as the reason for taking their children out of child care,
(ii) 67 per cent of families leaving centres are using informal care,
(iii) more than 25 per cent of centres in each State and Territory have reduced staffing levels, and
(iv) 50 small child care centres will close nationally by the end of 1997;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) condemns the Government's cuts of $820 million to child care over two budgets, leading to:

PARA.TAB: (i) fee increases of up to $20,
(ii) lower quality child care,
(iii) the closure of services,
(iv) job losses, and
(v) changes that are forcing some people to stop working, take their children out of child care, or rely on backyard care; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c) expresses concern about limits on emergency child care, which will limit the availability and reduce the quality of child care.
I seek leave to make a statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate very much for giving me this opportunity. This is a motion that has been on the book for some time. It is particularly pertinent at the moment with the launch today of a survey of child‐care services conducted by the New South Wales government. You may recall that, some weeks ago now, NACBCS did a survey in which it was indicated that there was a twofold concern on the part of parents in relation to child care. Firstly, there was the fact that there has been an erosion in the quality of child care, and, secondly, there has been an increase in the fees that parents have had to pay, largely because of the $820 million worth of cuts that have been imposed on child care in the last two years.

SPEECH.PARA: This survey by the New South Wales government, titled `Families at work', has been done of community‐based child‐care centres. It indicates that the trend has not abated but is continuing and getting worse. In fact, this survey shows that in New South Wales the average increase in fees is $25 per week presently, and that the increase has varied from $10 up to, in some cases, $40 per week.

The consequences for parents and their children are dire. It means that those children do not have the quality of care that they are entitled to, and, secondly, in many cases, the families are losing their opportunities to make a choice about their lifestyles. They are having to reduce the hours their children are in care or, alternatively, they are having to leave work or work fewer hours in order to afford the fees.
These changes in child care are making it harder for Australian families, and I think it is very important that the Senate takes note of that fact.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: More than a third of Australian adults—some 4.7 million people—now have investments in the share market. Efficient capital markets are central to the Government's objective of achieving higher economic growth and facilitating private sector investment, employment generation and wealth creation. Economic growth depends on the investment of the savings of Australians in productive and innovative ways. Efficient, well supervised securities markets are a vital component of our capital markets and are one of the most important vehicles for economic growth. They provide investment opportunities, enable companies to raise capital, act as an efficient price-discovery mechanism and help to channel resources and savings to their most productive uses. Strategies to promote the standing of our securities markets must be adopted in order to achieve the Government's foremost objectives of promoting growth, attracting investment to Australia and creating employment.

The Australian Stock Exchange (ASX), as Australia's leading securities market, plays a central role in the efficient operation of the Australian economy. It provides a market place for the trading of the securities of Australia's leading companies. In reflecting the collective information and judgement of investors, the Exchange channels investors' capital into its most productive uses. By bringing together parties wishing to buy and sell securities, the Exchange facilitates price discovery and reduces transaction costs and settlement risks.

The savings of millions of Australians are invested directly or indirectly through the Exchange. The privatisation of one-third of Telstra, together with the recent demutualisations of National Mutual Holdings and Colonial Ltd, will add to the overall market capitalisation of the Exchange.

In addition, the ASX, in its capacity as a market regulator, is the front line regulator of the day to day operations of the market. The ASX is, therefore, an important national asset and a cornerstone of our capital markets.

The ASX is currently organised and governed in a manner that is traditional for stock exchanges. It is a `co-operative' or mutual. Since their origins in coffee-shop meetings of stockbrokers in London and Amsterdam four centuries ago, most stock exchanges around the world have come to be structured as mutual organisations of stock brokers. The Exchange is owned and controlled by its members and run on behalf of its members under its own constitution and operating rules. Its members are the brokers who use the Exchange to deal in the securities of businesses and governments. They are either corporations or firms that are licensed stockbroking organisations, or individuals who are senior employees or directors of stockbroking organisations.

Only recently has the continuing appropriateness of this structure been challenged. Substantial changes to the commercial and international environments in which stock exchanges operate have obliged exchanges to radically rethink their corporate governance structures. In 1993 the Stockholm Stock Exchange chose to become a limited liability company whose shares are freely traded. Recently other European exchanges have altered their governance structures in one form or another.

Stock exchanges operate in a dynamic, competitive and rapidly changing environment that is far removed from the circumstances of yesterday. The world financial system has witnessed dramatic changes and exponential growth over recent decades. New technologies have allowed an increasing range of financial services to be supplied across international borders. Recent events in the world's stock markets highlight the increasing international interdependence of those markets. Exchanges must continually appraise and, if necessary, adapt their governance structures to meet new demands and competitive pressures.

The ASX initiated a review of its governance structure in 1995. That review concluded that the ASX should demutualise, and go one step further than any other stock exchange by listing on its own market and having its shares quoted.

In October 1996, after considering a business case prepared for them, members of the ASX voted to `demutualise' the Exchange, i.e. to convert the Exchange from a company limited by guarantee to a company limited by shares. That company would be owned and controlled by its shareholders and conducted as a conventional business for the purpose of yielding a return to its owners.

The ASX is, essentially, a private body. It is not funded by Government in the role that it carries out. The Government accepts that the internal governance of the Exchange is, in the first instance, a matter for the Exchange and its owners. The Government has agreed in this bill to facilitate the conversion of the Exchange to a public company. However, the proposal does raise an important issue for Government: namely, how is it to ensure that the public interest in the proper running of the Exchange is protected following the proposed changes to the ASX's governance arrangements?

The ASX undertakes three roles within the securities industry. It is a market regulator (self regulatory organisation or SRO); a commercial entity conducting a public securities market as a business; and a trade association seeking to protect and promote the interests of its members.
The regulatory responsibilities of the ASX

The ASX's Listing Rules perform an important role in the regulation of listed companies. In making and administering these rules, the ASX occupies a formal, statutorily recognised position in the system of co-regulation of companies and securities with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). Important services provided by the ASX include the maintenance of market integrity, fair trading systems, guarantees of trade completion, clearing, settlement and transfer systems and information about stock that is traded. The maintenance of market integrity encompasses a number of important facets including ensuring investors are properly and fully informed about matters affecting listed companies so that their shares can be fairly priced, having trading and settlement systems that are fair and efficient, ensuring that stockbrokers deal fairly and honestly with their clients, and detecting any attempt to mislead the market. Markets characterised by the presence of these elements attract broad investor participation. It is essential that the ASX continues to ensure the honesty and integrity of the securities market for which it is responsible.

The conversion of the Exchange to a company limited by shares represents a significant change to the way in which stock exchanges have traditionally been conducted. The issue, from a policy perspective, is whether the commercial pressures of a `for profit' entity will undermine the commitment of resources and capabilities of the Exchange to effectively fulfil its regulatory and public interest responsibilities to an appropriate standard. To ensure appropriate levels of investor protection, the Corporations Law will be amended to clarify the responsibilities of the ASX as an SRO, and ensure there is appropriate accountability of the ASX to the ASC and the Government in carrying out its SRO responsibilities.

The Law will impose obligations on the Exchange to do everything necessary to ensure that the market it conducts is an orderly and fair market and self regulatory functions are carried out on an ongoing basis.

It will, in particular, require the Exchange to have adequate arrangements for overseeing stockbrokers, for the settlement of transactions, and for investigating complaints by investors about business transacted on the market.

To ensure appropriate compliance with these obligations, the bill will empower the Minister to direct the Exchange to attend to certain matters that the Minister believes will promote compliance with the ongoing obligations. In addition, the bill will provide for an annual report by the Exchange of its performance of its SRO responsibilities.
Supervision of a listed ASX

The ASX proposes that its shares be listed on its own exchange. As the ASX is responsible for the administration and enforcement of the Listing Rules against all listed companies, there would be a conflict of interest in the ASX monitoring its compliance with, and enforcing, its Listing Rules against itself. To remove the potential for any conflict of interest, the bill provides for the ASC to undertake the supervision of the ASX's compliance with the Listing Rules. The ASX will meet these supervisory costs.
Restrictions on the ownership of shares in the ASX

Given the critical role it plays in the national economy, it would not be in the public interest for any one party to gain control of the ASX. The bill thus imposes a statutory limitation of 5 per cent on individual shareholdings in the ASX. A limitation of this order will encourage diverse ownership of the ASX. The 5 per cent limitation will apply to both Australians and foreigners.
The regulation of stockbrokers

Under the current law, stockbrokers must be members of stock exchanges and stock exchanges must ensure that their members are of good character, and conduct themselves accordingly when trading on an exchange. Following demutualisation, the right to trade on the ASX will be available to appropriately qualified and financially sound organisations, whether or not they are members of the ASX. Access to the market will be based on a contract between the ASX and brokers. Those contractual arrangements will not require any ownership interest in the ASX, as at present. While the bill recognises the ASX's altered relationship with brokers, at the same time it ensures that the ASX continues to be responsible for the conduct and integrity of market participants trading on the ASX and in related activities.
Access to the National Guarantee Fund

On its conversion to a public company, further approvals of payments from the National Guarantee Fund (NGF) for the ASX's own development would not be available. Such approvals, in circumstances where the benefits of the capital investments funded by those moneys would inappropriately accrue to shareholders of the ASX, will no longer be appropriate.

There is no need to make specific provision for these changed circumstances in this bill. The Corporations Law presently confers a broad discretion on the Minister in approving payments out of the National Guarantee Fund for the development of the securities industry.

Within the scope of this discretion, the Government proposes that guidelines be developed detailing the circumstances in which payments from the Fund may be approved in light of the ASX's changed circumstances. It is anticipated that payments will continue to be approved for such purposes as investor education and campaign or research projects that will enhance the development of Australia's securities markets, but not for capital development of the Exchange.
Conclusion

In summary, the bill provides a mechanism for the conversion of the Exchange to a public company. In so doing it gives effect to the decision of members as to the governance arrangements they consider appropriate for the ASX into the next century. Legislation is necessary to effect this change as the Corporations Law does not presently permit a company limited by guarantee to change its status to that of a company limited by shares through administrative procedures, nor facilitate the breaking of the nexus between ownership of a stock exchange and access to the market operated by that exchange.

More importantly, however, legislation is necessary to clarify the responsibilities of a demutualised ASX as a self regulatory organisation (or SRO), and ensure appropriate accountability of the ASX to the ASC and the Government in meeting those responsibilities. Where appropriate, the clarification of these responsibilities will have application to securities exchanges generally, and not solely to the ASX.

The measures proposed by this bill will assist the ASX to compete with regional exchanges and enhance the international competitiveness of Australia's financial sector in the Asia‐Pacific region. They will help to deliver significant new employment, income and wealth to the Australian community.

The bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on Government. While additional costs will be incurred by the ASC in supervising the listing of the ASX, the ASX has agreed to reimburse the ASC for these costs.

In accordance with the Corporations Agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, the Ministerial Council for Corporations has been consulted and has approved the introduction of the bill into Parliament.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first sitting day in 1998, in accordance with standing order 111.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a statement by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) entitled Better aid for a better future , together with the government's response to the Simons committee's review of Australia's overseas aid program, and the seventh annual report to parliament on Australia's development cooperation program. I seek leave to incorporate this statement in Hansard and to take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

I am pleased to table the Government's Response to the Simons Committee's Review of Australia's Overseas Aid Program. In doing this I am outlining future directions for Australia's overseas aid and fulfilling my requirement to make an Annual Report to Parliament on the Aid Program.

Mass poverty is the single most important economic and social issue on our planet today. Some 1.3 billion people, nearly a quarter of the world's population, continue to live in extreme poverty, trying to survive on less than $1 a day. Over half of these poor are in the Asia Pacific. Even in countries which have been developing rapidly, the vast majority of people are incomparably worse off than ourselves. The average income of people living in Indonesia is a mere 6 per cent of that in Australia, people in China earn only 3 per cent of what we do. The enduring challenge for most of these countries is to provide their people with such basics as food, clean water and education for their children. Meeting this challenge has proven to be no easy task.

If there were any doubts about the fragility of the development process and the need for Australia to provide effective assistance, these would have been dispelled over the past two months. Recent events such as the severe drought in Papua New Guinea, forest fires in Indonesia and the South East Asian currency realignments bring home the diverse and urgent problems faced by our nearest neighbours.

On my most recent visit to Papua New Guinea, earlier this month, I saw at first hand the devastating effects of the worst drought in perhaps one hundred years. Expert assessments—funded by Australia's aid program—show that as many as half a million people, in a population of only four million, are affected.

With my colleagues, the Minister for Defence, Mr McLachlan, and my Parliamentary Secretary, Mrs Kathy Sullivan, I flew by RAAF Caribou to Pumani in Milne Bay Province. We wanted to see for ourselves the work funded by our aid program. Stowed in the aircraft were 150 sacks of rice. When we set down, the plight of the people of Papua New Guinea was clear.

These people had not seen rain in many months. There was no fruit on the trees. Vines were brown and withered. The soil had turned to dust. Water supplies were a long distance from homes, and were polluted. Children had the distended bellies we know is a sign of malnutrition.

Australia has reacted rapidly and generously to the prospect of this human suffering on our doorstep. Ten Australian Defence Force aircraft are now ferrying essential foods into the most inaccessible areas of Papua New Guinea, to feed the worst affected people. Several Australian NGOs are also assisting with drought relief.

Both the Prime Minister and I have reassured the Government and the people of Papua New Guinea that Australians will stand by them in their hour of need. If the rains fail, and the next growing season is lost, that need will be immense.

The Australian aid program has played a vital role in nearly every major humanitarian emergency in the world over the last thirty years. But by far the greatest focus of our aid efforts has been on the basic building blocks for sustainable development. Since the establishment of the Colombo Plan in the early 1950s, our aid program has touched the lives of millions of people in developing countries, many of whom are our immediate neighbours. This is a record of which Australia can be proud. It is a record I am committed to continuing.

For some time I have been concerned that the aid program has been in danger of losing focus on its core developmental role. For this reason, an independent review of Australia's aid program was foreshadowed in our pre‐election platform, "A Confident Australia"—and in June last year I instituted such a review. The Review Committee headed by Paul Simons, and including Gaye Hart and Cliff Walsh, produced an excellent report. This report, and the public comments on its recommendations, have played a key role in determining the future directions of Australia's aid program.
OBJECTIVE OF THE AID PROGRAM

The Simons Committee confirmed my concern that the aid program had become burdened down by a range of competing interests. A clear development objective for the aid program is needed. The aid program can not and should not be a vehicle for other purposes, such as short‐term commercial goals.

The Government has determined that the objective of the Australian overseas aid program will be, "to advance Australia's national interest by assisting developing countries to reduce poverty and achieve sustainable development." This objective is consistent with the course set in the Government's White Paper on Foreign and Trade Policy.

I know that some people in the community think that there is a choice between dealing with problems at home or providing assistance overseas. This is a misunderstanding and it is self‐defeating. The promotion of sustainable development overseas and the pursuit of Australia's long‐term national interest are inextricably linked.

Those who say Australia should not have an overseas aid program are nothing more than political opportunists whose world view extends no further than their front gate. Let us remember, it was the member for Oxley who called for Australia to disband its aid program and then almost immediately after called for increased support for the people of North Korea. She cannot have it both ways. The fact is the provision of well‐targeted aid gives Australia another strong means of playing a leading role in our developing region.

Economic growth and rising incomes in developing countries foster stability and expand trade and investment opportunities for Australia. The aid program generates considerable goodwill in the region and provides an important foundation for broader bilateral relations.

The aid program is an important instrument for addressing the non‐military threats to Australian security. The effects of poverty extend beyond national boundaries. Pandemics, illegal migration, refugee flows, global environment problems, narcotics and transnational crime are often directly related to poverty.

Our aid program, by promoting human rights and addressing the needs of the world's most disadvantaged, is a clear statement of Australian values. I have great faith in the generosity of Australians and our commitment to giving others, much worse off than ourselves, a fair go. We are a country founded on equality and opportunity; we are strengthened by our cultural diversity. These principles extend beyond our shores and will be clearly reflected in our aid program.
PRINCIPLES OF OUR AID PROGRAM
In addition to the objective, six key principles will underpin Australia's aid program.

First, our aid will be focused on partnerships. Our program will be determined and implemented in partnership with developing countries. This will guarantee that it remains focused on meeting their priority needs.

Second, we will be responsive to urgent needs and development trends. Our aid program will provide rapid relief to victims of natural disasters and emergencies and take account of changing pressures in developing countries.

Third, our aid will provide practical assistance. It will be realistic in assessing what can and cannot be achieved and will concentrate on practical efforts that can alleviate poverty and promote sustainable development.

Fourth, there will be greater targeting. Australia's aid program cannot afford to be all things to all people—greater definition and targeting is essential. Clear priorities have been identified, and our efforts will be assessed against these priorities.
Fifth, our aid program will remain identifiably Australian—it is a reflection of Australian values and is a projection of these values abroad.
Finally, the program will be outward looking. It will be open to new ideas and approaches. It will seek to draw on the best ideas in Australia and overseas.
PRIORITIES FOR AUSTRALIA'S AID

Each one of these principles is designed to bring about a more relevant, higher quality aid program. Using the principles and new objective as a guide, I have developed a set of core priorities for Australia's aid program.
Partnerships With Developing Countries

Our partnerships with developing countries form the backbone of Australia's aid program. Detailed country strategies will be prepared for all major programs. These strategies will detail how our aid will alleviate poverty and address sustainable development in each country. Efforts will focus on promoting economic growth, investing in human capital and protecting the most vulnerable groups in society.
Sectoral Priorities

Our aid will concentrate on five key sectors—health, education, infrastructure, rural development and governance—which have been identified as crucial for sustainable development. They are also sectors in which Australia is well placed to assist.
Australia's aid program has been operating effectively in four of the five sectors for many years and we will continue to ensure that our assistance is well‐targeted and effective.

Governance will be a new focus for the aid program. Effective governance means competent management of a country's resources in a manner that is open, transparent, accountable, equitable and responsive to people's needs.

We will have a particular focus on ensuring that sound fiscal monetary and trade policies are instituted to create an environment for private sector development. I have asked AusAID to develop a policy paper on promoting private sector development through our aid program. We will also undertake practical activities to promote civil and political rights in developing countries. Economies will not achieve their potential unless government is transparent, legal systems are fair, and information flows freely.
CROSS‐CUTTING ISSUES

Australia's aid program will place a strong emphasis on ensuring that men and women have equal access to resources and opportunities. Women's needs and perspectives will be considered in the planning and delivery of all Australian aid activities. The aid program will also ensure that the possible impact on the environment is considered in the design and implementation of all projects. We will also play a role in addressing global environment issues such as climate change and biodiversity, which have strong links to the alleviation of poverty.
Geographic Focus

Australia's aid program will continue to concentrate on the Asia Pacific region, Papua New Guinea, the Pacific and East Asia will all be high priorities for Australian assistance. Australia will also continue to concentrate selectively on development needs in South Asia, Africa and the Middle East. In order for the program to maximise its impact, Australian aid dollars will have a focus on the poorest regions in the countries of the Asia Pacific, for example, in eastern Indonesia and southern Philippines.
Australia will also respond flexibly to humanitarian and emergency relief situations—wherever they arise.
INTERNATIONAL AND COMMUNITY PARTNERS

While programs delivered direction from Australia to partner countries will remain the focus of Australia's aid program, we will also play a key role in fostering links with Australian community organisations and be involved in multilateral efforts to tackle poverty.

Non‐government organisations and multilateral institutions play a vital role in development. They complement Australia's bilateral aid efforts by extending the reach and efficiency of the program. They will continue to receive significant support. However, consistent with a more targeted aid program, the Government is taking a more strategic approach to their funding.

Future support for multilateral agencies will take account of the extent to which each agency's mandate contributes to the meeting of Australia's aid objective, and the efficiency and effectiveness of the agency. NGOs will be expected to demonstrate tangible community support for their development activities. The Government now requires NGOs seeking funding from AusAID to have a recognised development expenditure of at least $30,000 annually. This is part of a rigorous accreditation process to ensure Government funds are channelled through NGOs that have substantial community support and are of sufficient size and professionalism to be able to deliver aid programs overseas. The appropriateness of the $30,000 threshold will be kept under review, in consultation with the NGO community.
Grants And Loans

The Australian aid program currently provides bilateral assistance only in the form of grants, regardless of the country, sector and project involved. Grants are not the only way to deliver aid. I believe that, if introduced, the right sort of soft loans would be a useful instrument for aid delivery. Such loans should not be an imitation of Labor's discredited DIFF scheme, which the Simons Committee considered flawed as both aid and industry assistance. I notice that even the Labor Party, which made such a fuss at the time of its abolition, has now decided that a DIFF‐style scheme should not be part of the aid program.

Loans should be driven by recipient needs, rather than Australian industry wishes. They should be integrated with our bilateral aid efforts, not run as a separate scheme. They should require competitive tendering, not be driven by individual company proposals. The loan projects should also be designed, monitored and evaluated to ensure development quality.

Any decision to introduce a loan scheme would, however, have significant funding implications. While recognising their advantages, soft loans should not squeeze out other high‐priority aid activities. Consequently, introducing soft loans into the program will depend on future aid budget outcomes.
Refocusing Aid Management

A permanent advisory committee will be established shortly to advise me on aid and development issues. Such a committee will enable me to hear directly from the broader community about Australia's aid efforts.
AusAID is undertaking a major review of its operations and structures. Significant reforms will be introduced shortly, which focus on improving aid quality.
Australian Identity
Australia's aid program must be identifiably Australian. The simplest and most effective method of guaranteeing this is to use Australians in the delivery of the aid program.

Approximately one‐third of Australia's aid program is currently tied to Australian goods and services. Nevertheless, around three‐quarters of the total aid program is in fact spent on Australian goods and services. While we will make some minor adjustments in the current tying arrangements to increase the quality of the aid program, it is essential that it remain identifiably Australian.
CONCLUSION

The volume of aid spending will always be a difficult issue. Australia provides significant amounts of overseas aid, consistently spending more than the international donor average. Future levels of aid funding, like all aspects of government expenditure, will be subject to budget considerations. We will continue to support the UN's 0.7 per cent ODA/GNP target and endeavour to maintain our aid at the highest level, consistent with the needs of partner countries and our own economic circumstances and capacity to assist.

And while there will always be debates over the size of the aid program, it is important that we make the most of the aid dollar. With over $1.4 billion invested annually in Australia's aid efforts, the Australian community and our developing country partners have the right to demand excellence in our aid program. I believe that Australians can be proud of our development efforts. The new principles and priorities outlined today will result in a better‐targeted and focused aid program and a better, more productive world around us.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the importation of cooked chicken meat into Australia. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1
The Committee recommends that the Government amend the Quarantine Act and place final responsibility for quarantine decisions in the hands of the Minister and/or Government.

SPEECH.PARA: . As previously announced in its response to the Nairn Report (Australian Quarantine: A shared Responsibility) , the Government has decided that quarantine decision‐making will remain independent, the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy retaining responsibility for decision‐making as the Director of Quarantine. The Minister will continue to be responsible for ensuring that due process is followed, through a more disciplined approach and strengthened appeal processes, and that quarantine policy is administered in a manner consistent with government policy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2

The Committee recommends that AQIS commission tests of the thermal inactivation of Newcastle disease virus and infectious bursal disease virus in chicken meat products. This study should be conducted in conditions that are as close as possible to commercial processing conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: . The Senate Committee acknowledged the significant weight of independent scientific advice which supports the cooking times and temperatures proposed by AQIS. Nevertheless, to allay the continuing concerns of industry, the Government decided that the Department should arrange one final round of testing.

. AQIS commissioned trials under laboratory conditions to determine whether the thermal processing proposed in the import protocol is effective in inactivating Newcastle disease virus and infectious bursal disease virus if present in chicken meat. These trials were designed by Dr Dennis Alexander, a scientist of international renown whose work has served as an industry reference and has been used by AQIS as the basis for developing the import conditions. To maximise the value of the results obtained, the trials required strictly controlled conditions and therefore could not be carried out under commercial conditions as suggested by the Senate Committee. It is also impracticable to carry out trials in a commercial environment with highly infectious strains of virus. However, the trials were designed so that their results will be relevant to commercial conditions where there may be variations in oven temperatures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3

The Committee further recommends that AQIS collaborate with industry in the design of this experiment so that there can be no further disputation about the validity of the science underlying the protocols.

SPEECH.PARA: . The trials were designed by Dr Alexander who is an independent expert, in whom industry has expressed confidence. Scientists from the Bureau of Resource Sciences and from industry have contributed to the experimental design. The results have been made available to industry.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4
The Committee recommends that AQIS commission field trials in a commercial cooking environment to determine appropriate methods of verifying thermograph calibration and performance.

SPEECH.PARA: . AQIS consulted CSIRO and industry on the means of evaluating the effectiveness of commercial cooking. AQIS will require that equipment be maintained in accordance with good manufacturing practice and individual companies will be expected to provide for maintenance and calibration of equipment as part of their in‐plant Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Points (HACCP) programs.
. AQIS will require all records of calibration to be maintained and subject to audit by the foreign inspection authority.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5

The Committee recommends that AQIS conduct inspections of processing plants in all countries seeking to import cooked chicken meat into Australia. The Committee further recommends that industry representatives accompany AQIS officers on these visits.

SPEECH.PARA: . AQIS conducted inspections of Thai processing plants to assess their eligibility to export to Australia. An industry representative participated in these inspections. In relation to plants in the USA and Denmark, owing to its long history of dealing with the authorities and systems employed by these countries, AQIS will in principle accept the recommendations of veterinary authorities of these countries as to the plants which meet Australia's quarantine requirements (just as we expect similar treatment in respect of our recommendations to them). However, AQIS will also implement an ongoing program of auditing foreign inspection systems including, but not limited to, review of a sample of foreign plants exporting to Australia. Testing of imported cooked chicken meat under the Imported Foods Inspection Program will provide an additional assurance as to the proper processing of chicken under sanitary conditions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6

The Committee therefore recommends that AQIS require area certification from avian disease. The Committee believes that AQIS should follow established international practice with regard to disease certification requirements.

SPEECH.PARA: . The area certification requirement referred to by the Committee in terms of international practice applies to chicken meat generally and therefore also covers uncooked product, whereas the AQIS proposal relates to imports of cooked chicken meat only. It is considered that the stringent cooking process proposed, in combination with other measures such as ante and post mortem veterinary inspection, the presence of a quality assurance system, security processing of product destined for Australia and food inspection arrangements, effectively minimise quarantine risks associated with the possible presence of avian viruses in chicken meat imports.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7

The Committee recommends that the most appropriate assistance measure available for government's consideration would be introduction of appropriate safeguard action to allow the imposition of a tariff or quota restriction on importation on a temporary and reducing basis. An industry assistance package, of limited duration (similar to the citrus industry package) would be a possible adjunct to any such measure.

SPEECH.PARA: . I established an economic working group involving industry representatives in June 1996 to examine the potential impact of imports of cooked chicken meat. It concluded that imports could comprise 2 to 5% of domestic consumption. I subsequently invited the industry to provide any further relevant information, and the industry put further submissions to the Government. There have also been extensive consultations with the industry. The industry's submissions have been given careful consideration by the Government, consistent with Australia's international obligations.

. Given that the AQIS import protocol for cooked chicken meat has been revised and as a result it is not likely to lead to imports of commercially significant quantities, structural adjustment assistance will not be provided to the chicken meat industry at this stage. The structural adjustment needs of the industry will be kept under review in parallel with the work of the scientific working party reviewing the results of the additional tests.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 8
The Committee accordingly recommends that the Government provide the Parliament and the community with a clear explanation of the assessment process at the earliest possible time.

SPEECH.PARA: . The Government's response to the Nairn Report, released on 18 August, provides a detailed explanation of the assessment process now to be followed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendations contained in Appendix 3—Chapter 8
Recommendation 9
The Committee recommends that AQIS develop strategies to better explain and disseminate information on its risk analysis and management approach to quarantine and inspection.

SPEECH.PARA: . The Government's response to the Nairn report also provides information of the Government's plans in this regard.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 10

The Committee recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, recognising that scientific and technical expertise must increasingly underpin the operations of AQIS particularly in quarantine, undertake a review of AQIS's resources and capacities and, if necessary, increase staffing and resources.
Recommendation 11

The Committee is concerned that the scientific research on the basis of which AQIS must make an assessment of risk should be comprehensive and relevant to Australian conditions. The Committee recommends that assessments of risk should not be made until such research has been done.
Recommendation 12
The Committee recommends that AQIS should have wide‐ranging consultations with relevant industry groups before publishing a draft IRA.

SPEECH.PARA: Recommendations 10, 11 and 12 refer to the strengthening of AQIS's scientific base including provision for funding of basic research relevant to quarantine. They also call for a more structured consultation process.

The government announced in the Budget a four‐year package totalling $76 million to substantially enhance the national quarantine effort. The package will help sustain Australia's strong competitive position in international markets by improving our capacity to ensure the nation's highly favourable plant, animal and fish health status is maintained.
The package will provide for the import risk analysis (IRA) process to be upgraded to improve consultation and make it more transparent.
The Nairn Committee was very strongly of the view that the IRA process should remain scientifically based. This is endorsed by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies on operations of codes of practice in the television industry—part 1. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The document read as follows—
Introduction

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies's (the Select Committee) Report on Operations of Codes of Practice in the Television Industry Part 1 ('the Report'), was tabled on 26 October 1995. The Government's response was delayed due to the calling of a Federal election in early 1996. After the election the Department of Communications and the Arts sought comments on the Report from the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA), the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS), the ABC, the SBS, the Federation of Australian Narrowcasting and Subscription Services (FANSS) and the Confederation of Australian Subscription Television (CAST).

Finalisation of the Government's response was deferred when, on 6 May 1996, the Prime Minister announced the establishment of a Committee of Ministers on the Portrayal of Violence on electronic media (the Ministerial Committee) with terms of reference that substantially overlapped those of the Select Committee. It was decided that the Government's response to the Report would take into account the Government's decisions on the recommendations of the Ministerial Committee. The Ministerial Committee reported to Cabinet and on 9 July 1996, Cabinet accepted its recommendations.

One recommendation was to refer the matters arising from the public submissions to the Select Committee for further consideration. The Select Committee tabled its Report on the Portrayal of Violence in the Electronic Media on 13 February 1997. The Government is considering the Select Committee's recommendations and will respond separately to that report.
The Government has taken into consideration the comments made by
Mr Bob Mansfield in his report The Challenge of a Better ABC which was presented to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts on 24 January 1997.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1:

(a) That the ABC and the SBS incorporate in their codes of practice the classification guidelines contained in the Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice so that there is a uniform approach for free‐to‐air television; and

SPEECH.PARA: Determination and modification of the national broadcasters' codes of practice are the responsibility of the Boards of the ABC and SBS, consistent with their statutory editorial independence. The ABC and SBS do not believe that this recommendation is necessary or desirable considering the differing charter responsibilities of the national broadcasters and the commercial focus of the licensed broadcasters.

The Government acknowledges the Committee's concerns that the lack of uniformity in classification guidelines in the free to air broadcasting sector may increase the scope for idiosyncratic decision making. At the same time the Government is conscious of the value of ensuring a diversity of programming choices, provided by the differing approaches of the national and commercial networks. The issue therefore is whether uniformity across free to air television outweighs all other consider ations, particularly given the different purposes of national and commercial broadcasting.

The ABC and SBS codes apply the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC) guidelines in the classification of programs and the national broadcasters use the same classification symbols and consumer advice as the commercial broadcasters. The main difference between the FACTS code and those of the ABC and SBS is that the classification criteria are not detailed in the codes in the same manner. However the ABC and SBS codes in combination with their Editorial Policies make explicit the approach they take to classification and the treatment of violence, sex, nudity and language. To the extent that these may differ from FACTS' approach is not necessarily a deficiency but reflects the expression of their charter and policies developed over a number of years of practice.
Each sector's approach reflects their charters and programming imperatives which may result in differences even between commercial networks using the FACTS code.

In this regard the Government has noted the comments made by Mr Bob Mansfield in his report on the ABC. Mr Mansfield reported that as a national broadcaster, the ABC is expected to reflect community standards in terms of content and presentation of material. The issue of standards was raised in a relatively small number of submissions to his review, with 228 (2%) expressing the view that ABC programming in some areas did not meet common standards of morality and decency. Suggestions were made that the ABC and commercial broadcasters should be subject to identical program standards.

Mr Mansfield expressed the view that he did not regard this as necessary or practical. He argued that given the self‐regulatory approach to program standards adopted in respect of the commercial sector, it would be inconsistent to require the ABC to meet externally imposed standards. If external standards were imposed on the ABC, it would represent an infringement of the ABC's editorial and programming independence. Also, the program standards developed by the ABC's Code of Practice and Editorial Policies are, with slight differences of emphasis and wording, similar in intent to the Codes developed by FACTS.

Mr Mansfield was not convinced that the perceived problem with program standards relates to the ABC's formal standards rather than the interpretation of those standards. In this respect he believes that the ABC has a responsibility to consult widely to determine the standards its audiences expect and to ensure that such standards are met; and that fundamentally the issue of program standards is one for management. In discharging this responsibility, he believes that the ABC must listen to its audience and be prepared to respond professionally and politely to legitimate concerns.
The Government is committed to continuing to monitor public concerns about classification issues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (b) That FACTS amend its code of practice to include provisions dealing with the portrayal of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, women and men, and cultural diversity; for example, similar in substance to the ABC. (Paragraph 37)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government neither accepts nor rejects this recommendation as it is a matter for FACTS to address in the context of the industry self regulation scheme established by the Act.

The Government notes that in its discussion paper, for the review of the Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice, FACTS suggested that the Advisory Notes continue to be separate from the Code and remain unchanged. The revised draft Code has been prepared on this basis. The Government considers that FACTS in reviewing the Code has taken into consideration the views of the public on this matter.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the interests of consistency of treatment of industry groups in the television industry, the codes of practice of the national broadcasters should be registered under section 123 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. (Paragraph 41)

The Government notes the Committee's intention in making this recommendation was to ensure that s128 of the Act applied to codes of practice promulgated by the national broadcasters. Section 128 enables codes of practice registered under the Act to be amended on the initiative of either House of Parliament provided the other House agrees.

It is the duty of the Boards of the national broadcasters, under the relevant Acts, to protect their independence and integrity. The ABA already has a role under the Act in dealing with the national broadcasters on code matters, although the national broadcasters' codes are not registered under s123 of the Act.

Although not subject to the provisions of the Act, the ABC and SBS are subject to quite stringent codes of practice. Where the ABA upholds a complaint, the broadcaster must take whatever action the ABA deems appropriate within a specified timeframe. Failure to do so means the ABA can provide a report to the Minister on the code breach which he must table in Parliament.
The ABC and SBS also receive a much higher level of public scrutiny and Parliamentary accountability than the commercial and community broadcasters.

The implementation of this recommendation would require legislative amendment to the Act and consequential amendments to the ABC and SBS Acts. The Government considers such action would constrain the independence of the ABC and the SBS.
The Government further considers that, in line with Mansfield's recommendations as outlined under recommendation 1, current arrangements are adequate.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3:

That the Senate re‐establish the Select Committee on Community Standards in the 38th Parliament so that it can, inter alia, continue to monitor the effectiveness of the administration of the Broadcasting Services Act. (Paragraph 47)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes that the Senate Committee was re-established (Senate Hansard Monday 20 May 1996).
Recommendation 4:

(a) That the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 be amended to provide for financial penalties to be imposed by the ABA for a breach of a code of practice, including provision for on‐the‐spot fines based on the model of administrative penalties used in other legislation (eg taxation law) with licence suspension as the consequence of non‐payment; and

The Government is aware that there is a concern that there be appropriate sanctions available to deal with breaches of codes of practice. The Act directs the ABA to exercise its power in a manner commensurate with the seriousness of a breach. The Act already provides a range of sanctions.

The Government has received legal advice to the effect that the recommendation raises constitutional issues because it would involve a purported conferral of judicial power on the ABA. However, it may be possible to set up a constitutionally valid system of administrative penalties to enable the ABA to issue infringement notices to broadcasters who breached a code of practice. These notices would not be enforceable in themselves but a breach of a code of practice could be made an offence against the Act.
