A similar recommendation has been made by the Select Committee in its February 1997 Report on the Portrayal of Violence in the Electronic Media. Consequently, the Government is giving this matter further consideration and will reply to the recommendations in its response to the latter Report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (b) That the ABA require compliance with codes of practice to be made a licence condition after 10 successful complaints. (Paragraph 58)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes industry comments that there may be some difficulty in determining the weight to be applied to breaches and its doubts about whether a quantitative approach is fair and equitable.

One of the ABA's stated functions under the Act is to monitor compliance with codes and investigate complaints. The Act gives the ABA discretion to impose licence conditions requiring compliance with a code of practice and recognises that the ABA is in the best position to judge when to apply the penalties under the Act ie the imposition of a licence condition. The Government considers that current arrangements are satisfactory.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5:
(a) That MA material not be permitted to be broadcast before 10.30 pm; and

SPEECH.PARA: The Government acknowledges the Committee's concerns about the suitability of particular types of material which may be shown in the early evening hours. This was an important issue during the deliberations of the Ministerial Committee. Having considered the views of the ABA and broadcasters during that process, the Government decided that broadcasters should modify films for broadcast in accordance with OFLC Guidelines and restrict the broadcast of MA programs carrying a consumer advice V symbol to between the hours of 9.30pm and 5.00am. The ABC and the SBS have decided to amend their codes of practice so that no MA material will be shown set at a level equivalent to the top of the former `AO' classification before 9.30pm.

The Government notes that the commercial television industry has proposed amendments to the FACTS code. A revised `MA' classification—restricted to 9.00pm to 5.00am—would comprise the `M' criteria for violence, and specific criteria for sex and nudity, language, drug use, adult themes and suicide which are set at a level equivalent to the top of the former `AO' classification. A new `AV' classification—restricted to 9.30pm to 5.00am—would comprise the `MA' criteria for sex and nudity, language, drug use, adult themes and suicide and specific criteria for violence set at a level equivalent to the top of the former `AO' classification. On‐screen consumer advice about the classification elements of the program is compulsory for all `MA' and `AV' and some `M' programs.
The revised FACTS code has been submitted to the ABA for consideration.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (b) That a documentary program containing material which would otherwise be rated as M or MA should be required to be broadcast in the appropriate timeslot. (Paragraph 74)

SPEECH.PARA: Consistent with its election commitment to ensure broadcasters comply with codes of practice, the Government supports the notion that programs should be broadcast in their appropriate timeslots. The current broadcasting codes require material to be broadcast at the time appropriate to its classifi cation. The Government considers the current arrangements are satisfactory.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6:
(a) That all broadcasters specify in their codes of practice a minimum quota of on‐air promotions of the existence of their codes of practice and the operations of the complaints mechanism; and

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes the part played by broadcasters in regularly informing their audiences about the operation of codes of practice and related complaints processes is an important part of the self‐regulatory system. It was pleased to note the initiative taken by FACTS to conduct a campaign of on‐air advertising to improve the public's understanding of the classification system at the time the Ministerial Committee was conducting its inquiry.
The Government supports the notion that broadcasters should ensure their codes of practice make appropriate provision for this form of public education.
(b) That all broadcasters introduce automated menu driven telephone complaints systems and log and retain complaints for three years. (Paragraph 84)

The Government recognises that an effective complaints system is an integral part of the self‐regulatory process. The Government has adopted the recommendation of the Ministerial Committee that broadcasters should review complaints mechanisms so as to ensure that they are effective and responsive to community concerns. The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has written to broadcasters on this issue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7:

That the ABC and SBS amend their codes of practice to impose a requirement that a substantive written response be made within 10 working days where a viewer complains in writing within 30 days of a program's broadcast. (Paragraph 95)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government acknowledges that there is a public expectation that replies to complaints will be comprehensive and timely. As mentioned previously, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts has written to broadcasters about reviewing their complaints mechanisms so as to ensure that they are effective and responsive to community concerns.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 8:
That all codes of practice impose a maximum time limit of three years before they are subject to review. (Paragraph 101)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes that each sector has made provision for a review to occur within three years and that in practice the reviews have occurred more often than this in the case of the national broadcasters. The Government considers that this is a matter for the broadcasters to determine.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9:
(a) That the Federation of Commercial Television Stations include 50% viewer representation on its Code Administration Council;

SPEECH.PARA: The Government appreciates that the Committee is concerned to ensure that the Code Administration Council reflects the views of the broader community. However, the composition of the Council is a matter for FACTS to decide.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (b) That the Confederation of Australian Subscription Television and the Federation of Australian Narrowcasting and Subscription Services include 50% viewer representation on their codes of Practice Sub‐committees; and

SPEECH.PARA: Consistent with its response to Recommendation 9(a), the Government considers this is a matter for the Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association
(ASTRA—formerly CAST and FANSS).

PARA.EMPHASIS: (c) That the ABC and SBS report the results of complaints regularly to their respective statutory advisory bodies and invite their comments on the adequacy of the codes of practice. (Paragraph 108)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considers that the existing practices of the ABC and SBS accord with the intention of this recommendation having regard to the roles played by the ABC Board and the National Advisory Council, and the SBS Community Advisory Committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 10:
That the MA guidelines in the Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice be replaced by the former AO guidelines. (Paragraph 118)

SPEECH.PARA: The Act requires the classification guidelines used by commercial broadcasters to be based on the OFLC guidelines. The Government understands that the Committee's concern is based on their view that the existing criteria do not conform with the spirit of the former AO guidelines. The Government notes that there is a legislative requirement that programs classified M or MA for television not to exceed the previous AO criteria.

The Government notes that in the most recent draft of its revised code (December 1996) FACTS states that the language now proposed for the `M', `MA', and `AV' classification criteria is `to underline our intention that these classifications should, together, equate precisely to the former `AO' classification'. The revised FACTS code has been submitted to the ABA for consideration.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 11:
That FACTS circulate to its members detailed advice as to the meaning of the term "identifiable public interest reasons" in the news and current affairs provisions of its code. (Paragraph 125)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the recommendation and understands that FACTS proposes to raise the awareness of staff of the commercial broadcasters about the meaning of the words "identifiable public interest reasons".

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 12:

That all codes of practice be amended to ensure that, in relation to news and current affairs reporting, special care should be taken to ensure that programs which children are likely to watch unsupervised will not cause alarm or distress. (Paragraph 134)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes that FACTS has proposed amendments to its Code to ensure greater care and sensitivity in news and current affairs portrayal of upsetting footage, and matters relating to the identification of individuals, accident victims and the reporting of suicide.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 13:
That all codes of practice should ensure the rights of individuals to privacy in the news gathering process, except where it may be justified in the public interest. (Paragraph 137)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the Committee's recommendation. The Government is aware that this issue is addressed in the Media Entertainment and Arts Alliance (MEAA) Code of Ethics but acknowledges that the issue remains one of continuing public concern.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 14:
(a) That consumer advice symbols be required to be displayed on‐screen throughout the broadcast of programs to which consumer advice applies;

SPEECH.PARA: The Government appreciates the importance of on‐screen advice to viewers but believes it is a matter for broadcasters to determine the manner in which that advice is provided. FACTS recently launched a campaign to assist viewers to understand the meaning of the symbols which should further assist viewers to make informed decisions about programming.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (b) That all codes of practice be amended to require broadcasters to notify all consumer advice to the publishers of program guides; and

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the recommendation but considers that this is a matter for broadcasters to consider.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (c) That a consistent framework of consumer advice be established with an agreed set of letters and/or symbols. (Paragraph 150)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the recommendation and understands that the broadcasters meet regularly to achieve a consistency of approach with regard to consumer advice symbols across television broadcasting.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 15:
That the Australian Broadcasting Authority publish in its annual report results of its sampling of the broadcast of advertising material by commercial stations. (Paragraph 158)

SPEECH.PARA: The Government notes the recommendation and understands the ABA will implement it.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 16:
That FANSS amend its draft code of practice to prohibit the showing of X‐rated material by its members. (Paragraph 175)

SPEECH.PARA: Following public consultation, codes of practice for open and subscription narrowcasting services have been finalised by ASTRA (formerly FANSS), in consultation with the ABA.

These codes will need to reflect the Government's decision, which the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts and the Attorney‐General announced on 8 April 1997, to prohibit X‐rated programs and any replacement category for non‐violent sexually explicit material, on open and subscription narrowcasting services. The Government has also decided to prohibit R-rated programs on open narrowcasting services.
Legislation will be introduced to give effect to the Government's decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
Debate (on motion by Senator Carr) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the government's response to the report of the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities entitled Draft Second Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1996 . I seek leave to have the response incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The document read as follows—
Introduction

BREAK.PARA: 1. In June 1996 the Government referred the draft Second Corporate Law Simplification Bill to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. The Committee received 26 written submissions on the draft Bill and held hearings on 13 September and 2 October 1996 in Canberra and Sydney respectively. The Committee's report was tabled in the Senate on 18 November 1996. In its report the Committee expresses its approval of the general content of the Bill. The Committee made 11 specific recommendations. It also made several suggestions on matters of detail which the Government has reviewed and, where appropriate, amended the Bill.

2. The Government wishes to thank the members of the Committee for considering the submissions and preparing their report. The Government also acknowledges the valuable contribution made by those who made submissions to the Committee.

3. The Government proposes to accept or note a number of the Committee's recommendations, in particular, those which would facilitate the orderly calling and conduct of company meetings or which invite the government to consider or review certain matters. However, a number of recommendations would impose additional costs on companies. The Government considers that these recommendations would best be addressed through the ASX's Listing Rules or best practice in corporate governance.

4. Since the Committee's report was tabled the Treasurer has announced the adoption of the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program. This program will involve a fundamental review of key areas of the Corporations Law affecting business and market activity. It is designed to bring a greater economic focus to corporate law reform, consistent with the Government's objective of facilitating investment, employment and wealth creation while providing investor protection. As part of this program the project of rewriting the Corporations Law will continue. The Second Simplification Bill will be advanced as part of the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program and has been renamed the Company Law Review Bill 1997.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Background to the Bill

BREAK.PARA: 5. The Company Law Review Bill will rewrite most of the core company law provisions of the Corporations Law. It will improve and simplify these provisions to make the Law more accessible and encourage efficient business practice by increasing choice and flexibility in the management of companies. For example, the Bill will provide a model framework of default rules for the management of a company's internal affairs (replaceable rules). These rules will be conveniently located within each subject area of the Law and will be able to be replaced or varied to suit the needs of particular companies. The Bill will also enable companies to make greater use of communication technology to hold meetings and exchange documents. The plain English approach taken in drafting the Bill will make the Law more readable and accessible. The Bill will also take up the Committee's suggestion that the person chairing a meeting be referred to as the chairman.

6. The seven subject areas covered by the Bill are registering companies, meetings, share capital, financial reporting, annual returns, deregistration of defunct companies and company names. The main reforms to be made in each of these areas are set out below.

7. The Bill will make it easier to register a company. It will be possible to register a standard company suitable for operating a typical small business by lodging a single form with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC), instead of the several that are currently required. Changing from one type of company to another (eg from a proprietary company to a public company) will be facilitated to enable company structures to best suit their commercial or other objectives. Doing business with a company will also become easier, especially for those who provide finance to companies, because the Bill will reduce the need for third parties to make inquiries about the company's internal affairs.

8. Proprietary companies will be able to pass a wider range of resolutions without incurring the expense of holding a formal meeting. Companies will be able to hold meetings more conveniently and involve a wider range of people. The proxy voting rules will be updated to give members greater certainty and flexibility in exercising their votes. Investors, particularly institutional and overseas investors, will have more time to prepare for general meetings. The Law will expressly recognise that, for public companies, the annual general meeting is an opportunity for shareholders to raise matters of concern with directors and the auditor.

9. Streamlined provisions will be introduced to deal with the issue of shares (including bonus shares), changing the rights attached to shares, partly-paid shares, dividends and the redemption of redeemable preference shares. The share buy‐back provisions will be amended to require that a buy-back not materially prejudice a company's ability to pay its creditors.

10. The Bill will give companies greater flexibility in the management of their share capital. First, it will be easier for companies to return capital to shareholders. This will be particularly useful for companies that have underperforming assets or that wish to dispose of capital assets not required for their core business activities.

11. Second, the Bill will replace the outdated concept of par value for shares, so that shares will no longer have a par value. Accounting and financial arrangements by companies will be easier to understand and companies whose shares are traded at a price less than their par value will therefore be able to raise fresh capital without prior approval from the court and their shareholders.

12. The Bill will reinforce the existing prohibition against a company acquiring or controlling its own shares. The rules prohibiting a company from financially assisting a person to acquire its shares will be relaxed so that a company will no longer require shareholder approval for a range of ordinary commercial transactions.

13. The Bill will improve the framework for financial reporting to members. It will establish within the Corporations Law the general conceptual framework for financial reporting, leaving matters of detail to be addressed in the accounting standards. Companies will have the option of sending concise annual reports to members, saving printing and distribution costs, although full reports will be available on request.
14. Annual returns to the ASC will be much shorter. The Law will expressly recognise that annual returns and other documents can be lodged electronically, with the agreement of the ASC.

15. It will be cheaper and easier to deregister a company that has no liabilities. It will be possible to make a claim against the insurer of a deregistered company without having to incur expenses associated with re-registering the company.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Response to PJC recommendations

BREAK.PARA: 16. The remainder of the Government's response to the report addresses in turn each of the Committee's recommendations.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1
The Committee recommends that:
(a) the Bill should more extensively recognise electronic forms of communication between companies and their members, and regulatory authorities; and
(b) the Law should make clear that, where it is proposed to hold a meeting using the assistance of technology, the participants at the meeting should be aware of:
(i) the intended use of that technology;
(ii) the effect on the meeting of any failure of that technology; and
(iii) for directors' meetings, the effect on the meeting of any withdrawal of consent to its continued use.

BREAK.PARA: 17. The Government supports the use of technology for communication between companies and their members and regulatory authorities. Com munication technologies accelerate the flow of information in the market, leading to more timely decision‐making. The Government notes that this is consistent with recommendations made by the Financial System Inquiry that the Law should facilitate electronic commerce.

18. Under the current Law companies can only use technology for their meetings if it is permitted by their constitution. The Bill will facilitate the use of technology without requiring a specific provision in the constitution.

19. The draft Bill considered by the Committee would allow companies to send notices and proxy documents by fax and to lodge documents electronically with the ASC and its agents. In light of the Committee's recommendations, the Bill will now enable companies to make greater use of communications technology. In particular, companies will be able to:
. send notices of meetings to an electronic address nominated by a member; and
. receive proxy documents from members electronically if the company has specified an electronic address in the notice of meeting.

20. The Government proposes that the use of communications technology in other areas of the Law, such as the provisions dealing with takeovers and fundraising, should be addressed when these areas are dealt with by the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program.

21. The Government agrees with the Committee that some specific provisions are necessary so that members are properly informed about the intended use of a technology. The Bill will therefore provide that if a members' meeting is proposed to be held at two or more places using technology the notice of meeting must indicate this and also the type of technology proposed to be used. This will enable members to decide whether to attend the meeting in person or via the technology.

22. More generally, the Government believes that provisions dealing with meetings should be consistent across all types of meetings. The use of technology in the conduct of a meeting is merely an extension of the normal meeting procedures and should be treated as far as possible as other meetings. For example, a breakdown in video‐conference technology has similar effect as the failure of microphones at a normal meeting. If a meeting does not give members a reasonable opportunity to participate, the existing law enables a court to declare the meeting invalid if a substantial injustice has resulted. The Government considers that this is also the appropriate outcome for members' meetings held at two or more places using technology.

23. In relation to directors' meetings, the Government accepts that directors must give reasonable notice before withdrawing consent to the use of technology at a meeting. However, the Law should allow directors and the company more generally to devise their own solutions concerning the consequences of a failure of technology.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 2
The Committee recommends that the right of an individual director to call a meeting of members should be a mandatory rule for listed companies.

BREAK.PARA: 24. The Bill will allow individual directors of companies, operating under the replaceable rules to be inserted into the Law, to call members' meetings. A company will be able to adopt a constitution and displace the rule through its constitution. It is envisaged that widely‐held companies would displace the rule. The rule is primarily designed for closely‐held companies to allow a members' meeting to be called with a minimum of formality.

25. For listed companies, a single director may wish to call a meeting to pass a resolution (eg removing a director or amending the company's constitution) or to publicise a matter of concern. However, for listed companies, calling a members' meeting is a significant and potentially costly action.

26. The Government believes that listed companies should be able to decide for themselves whether individual directors are able to require the company to hold a members' meeting. The Bill provides other safeguards for minority shareholders, such as allowing 100 members or members with 5 per cent of the votes to be able to require the directors to convene a meeting. The right of a director to call a meeting unilaterally would therefore only be relevant in practice where a director is unable to obtain this level of support for a resolution. It is therefore not considered necessary or appropriate to accept this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3
The Committee recommends that:

(a) where members call a general meeting under proposed section 249E, only those directors who fail to take reasonable steps to convene the meeting when requested under proposed section 249D should be liable to reimburse the company for the expense incurred in calling that meeting; and

(b) the Bill should make clear that the power of members to requisition or convene a general meeting should not be exercised frivolously, and should be exercised only where the purpose of the meeting is a valid purpose for such a meeting.

BREAK.PARA: 27. The Law currently provides that, if the directors have failed to call a meeting requested by members, the directors who are in default are liable to reimburse the company out of their fees for the cost of calling and holding the meeting. The draft Bill originally held all directors liable for failing to call a meeting. While this was intended to provide an incentive for compliance by directors, the Government accepts that some exemption should be offered to directors who act diligently. The Bill will therefore exempt from liability directors who can show they took all reasonable steps to cause a general meeting requested by the members to be held.

28. Under the common law a meeting that has not been called for a proper purpose can be declared invalid. It was suggested to the Committee that members may requisition meetings for improper purposes, without being aware that the meeting would be invalid, and that this would cause the company unnecessary costs and inconvenience. To address this concern the Bill will include a provision stating the general common law position that general meetings must be called for a proper purpose. This will help to make members aware of the limited nature of their power to request a meeting. The rule will apply to all members' meetings as there is no reason to distinguish between meetings called by members and those called by directors.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4
The Committee recommends that, as a general rule, for listed companies, the minimum notice period for a members' meeting should be 28 days.

BREAK.PARA: 29. Under the current Law the minimum notice period for a members' meeting is 14 days, with 21 days notice being required for a special resolution. The Bill will increase the minimum notice period to 21 days and remove the distinction between notice periods for different types of resolutions. This will encourage members and their representatives to participate in meetings as they will have longer to prepare and consider the content of notices.

30. Institutional investors, particularly those outside Australia, have argued that a 28 day notice period is required to give them sufficient time to receive, consider and respond to a notice of meeting (eg to appoint a proxy). The existing notice periods are said to discourage participation by institutional investors in members' meetings. However, the facilitation of communication technology proposed by the Bill, particularly in relation to the electronic service of notices of meetings and proxy documents, will greatly reduce the real time required to send notices.

31. Companies tend to prefer a short notice period to minimise costs and delay. A significantly longer notice period would make it more difficult for listed companies to capitalise on windows of opportunity to enter into a range of significant transactions requiring shareholder approval under the Corporations Law or the ASX's Listing Rules. Requiring a 28 day notice period would either cause the company to miss the opportunity or put pressure on the ASX to allow the transaction to proceed without shareholder approval.

32. The 21 days notice period therefore strikes an appropriate balance. It will be the minimum required by the Law: it will be open to companies to establish longer notice periods in their constitution, or in practice to offer a longer notice period.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 5
The Committee recommends that:
(a) the Law should be amended to require the auditor of a listed company (or the auditor's representative) to be available to take questions at the AGM at which the auditor's report is tabled; and
(b) the Bill or its Explanatory Memorandum should specifically refer to the applicability of qualified privilege to answers to questions put to auditors by members at an AGM.

BREAK.PARA: 33. The Bill will increase the ability of shareholders to make inquires about the company, by recognising the right of members to ask questions of directors and auditors at an AGM. Whether a company's auditors attend its AGM is currently a matter for negotiation between the company and its auditors as part of the audit engagement.

34. The Government generally considers that matters such as this should be determined by the relevant parties, and not be required by the Corporations Law. Accordingly, before mandating attendance by auditors at AGMs, the Government would need to be satisfied that interference with companies' freedom of contract on this issue was warranted.

35. The question whether to compel auditors to attend an AGM has been considered by a Ministerial Council for Corporations Working Party on the requirements for the registration and regulation of auditors. The Working Party comprised representatives from the accounting profession, the States and Territories, the ASC and the Treasury and consulted widely with relevant interest groups. Given the specific inquiry being made by the Working Party, the Government proposes to defer its consideration of this issue until it the Ministerial Council for Corporations has considered the Working Party's report.

36. The Law currently confers qualified privilege on auditors for any statements they make in the course of their duties as an auditor. This is a general privilege that applies in a variety of situations, including answering questions at an AGM. The Government agrees with the Committee's recommendation and the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill will confirm that qualified privilege applies to answers given by an auditor to questions at an AGM.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 6
The Committee recommends that further consideration be given to the issue of voting at meetings, with particular reference to:
(a) developing a standardised proxy form which will enable all shareholders to express the full range of their voting intentions; and
(b) requiring the chairman to call for a poll:
(i) if so instructed by a required number of proxies held by him or her; or
(ii) if the vote on a show of hands does not reflect the votes of the proxies held by him or her.

BREAK.PARA: 37. The formalities for appointing a proxy are currently determined by the company's constitution and the common law. Tables A and B also provides a basic proxy form, and sets out the basic requirements for appointing a proxy. The Bill will introduce greater choice to this area of the Law by providing that a proxy will be valid if it contains certain minimum information. A company's articles can therefore prescribe the use of one of the standard proxy forms available in the market place, set out the company's own specific proxy form or remain silent and allow informal proxies containing the minimum information required by the Law.

38. Companies have an incentive to provide a proxy form which meets their members' needs. This will vary depending on the structure of the company's membership. Introducing a standardised proxy form into the Law could reduce the flexibility and choice currently offered by the Bill to companies wishing to design their own proxy forms. The Government therefore considers that the development of a standard proxy form is a matter that is best considered by the relevant peak organisations outside of the legislative framework.

39. As at present, the Bill will allow resolutions to be passed either on a show of hands or on a poll. The current position under the Corporations Law is that resolutions may be carried on a show of hands but a poll may be demanded by the chairman or 5 members (including a proxy) or members holding 10 per cent of the votes. The Bill will reduce this to 5 per cent for consistency with other provisions conferring rights on shareholders in relation to meetings. Voting on a show of hands allows the company to progress meetings in a timely and efficient manner while the ability to call a poll provides a safeguard for matters which are closely contested.

40. If every member who appointed the chairman as their proxy could be counted towards the 5 members who may demand a poll most resolutions would be decided on a poll. This could cause companies considerable expense and delay and interfere in the orderly conduct of meetings. The Government considers that allowing proxy voters to count towards the call for a poll would be likely in practice to render voting on a show of hands redundant, as most resolutions would be decided on a poll, putting companies to additional expense and inconvenience and changing the character of the meeting. Given that the Bill will allow proxies to be lodged electronically, the Committee's recommendation would have a similar effect to the introduction of electronic voting. However, the Committee, in its consideration of whether the Law should facilitate electronic voting, noted that to do this `might ultimately change the character of the AGM, and the Committee has not been persuaded that the character of an AGM should change.' (Report para 2.17)

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 7

The Committee recommends that the adequacy of the transitional period for, and the possible taxation consequences of, those provisions in the Bill which abolish the par value of shares and the share premium account, and make other consequential amendments, should be carefully considered by the Government. The Committee also would welcome an opportunity to further examine this issue when the Bill is ultimately introduced into Parliament.

BREAK.PARA: 41. The Government acknowledges the need to ensure an adequate transitional period to give the business and professional communities sufficient time to adjust to the introduction of no par value and the abolition of court confirmation for capital reductions.

42. The Government is making a separate announcement about the taxation measures it will be introducing as a consequence of the abolition of par value for shares and court confirmation for capital reductions.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 8
With regard to the annual directors' report, the Committee recommends that:
(a) proposed section 299 stand unamended, but be reviewed 3 years after its implementation; and
(b) proposed section 300 be amended to additionally require listed companies to disclose the following matters:

(i) the policies of the Board for determining the remuneration (including incentives) of the Board and senior executives, and the relationship of these policies to the performance of the company/group;
(ii) the quantum and components of the remuneration of each director of the company and each of its 5 highest paid executives, including the existence and length of any service contract for the CEO;
(iii) the age and all other listed company directorships of each director;

(iv) whether, during the reporting period, any proceedings were instituted against the company for any material breach by the company of the Corporations Law or trade practices law and (if so) a summary of the alleged breach and of the company's position in relation to it; and
(v) whether, during the reporting period, any such proceedings were concluded or settled and (if so) the terms on which they had been.

BREAK.PARA: 43. The Government notes that the age and other listed company directorships of a director are already publicly available, for example, through the ASC database. Also, companies are currently required to disclose information about legal proceedings in the notes to their accounts where the proceedings constitute a material contingent liability. The Government considers that as this information is already available it would not be appropriate to be more prescriptive.

44. The Government notes that the Bill will enhance the disclosure of options granted to directors and senior executives. The Bill will require companies to disclose in their directors' report details of options that are granted over unissued shares or unissued interests during or since the end of the financial year to any of the directors or any of the five most highly remunerated officers in the company.

45. The Government believes that accurate and informative reporting to company members about a company's activities and performance is essential to maintaining investor confidence. Investors need to be informed about the factors underlying their company's performance, particularly when considering their ongoing investment in a particular enterprise. The Corporations Law currently provides an extensive framework for reporting members which ensures that members are well informed about the state of the company's business.

46. The Committee has endorsed changes proposed to be made to the Law in the Bill in the area of directors' reports to members by the introduction of a requirement to include a management discussion and analysis of the matters members needs to be informed about if they are to understand the overall financial position and performance of the company. The Committee also recommended that additional components be added to the disclosure of directors' remuneration and to specific disclosures about the company. In a number of respects, these recommendations go beyond the current law and the Bill, as considered by the Committee.

47. While the Government believes that proper reporting to members is an important responsibility for companies it considers that the approach proposed by the Committee is not appropriate at the present time. In particular, it considers that the provision of a management discussion and analysis to members should be a matter for companies to decide.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 9

The Committee recommends that the Corporations Law should require that information disclosed by Australian listed companies in overseas jurisdictions should be promptly and prominently announced via the Australian Stock Exchange to Australian investors.

BREAK.PARA: 48. The Government does not propose to amend the Bill in light of this recommendation as the disclosure requirements for listed companies are appropriately dealt with in the ASX Listing Rules.

49. A general requirement for the routine lodgment with the ASX of all documents lodged overseas by Australian listed companies runs the risk of imposing an unnecessary paperwork burden and therefore increased transaction costs on these companies.

50. The ASX Listing Rules currently require listed companies to disclose to the ASX information that is material to the price or value of their securities. These continuous disclosure requirements, which are backed by statutory obligations, ensure that the market is fully informed about non‐confidential information that affects the value of quoted securities. However, the general content of the disclosure obligation is appropriately a matter for the ASX. The Listing Rules provide examples of material information required to be disclosed. One of the examples given is that a document containing market sensitive information that the entity lodges with an overseas stock exchange or other regulator is required to be made available to the public.

51. The ASX has indicated that there does not seem to be justification for requiring the disclosure of documents lodged in overseas jurisdictions if the information is not material to Australian investors, particularly as some jurisdictions require detailed filings. Furthermore, the ASX considers—and the Government agrees—that this matter is more appropriately dealt with in the Listing Rules.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 10

The Committee recommends that consideration be given to the desirability of including in the Bill a provision giving the members of a class of shareholders the right to request and convene a meeting of that class to consider matters able to be dealt with at such a meeting.

BREAK.PARA: 52. This recommendation seeks to provide additional legislative safeguards for the interests of members of a class of shareholders in relation to their class rights. However, in order for a company to successfully compete for capital it must offer shares on terms which are attractive to the market. Market forces should therefore be allowed to determine the terms on which shares are issued. The rights attached to preference shares are negotiated as part of the terms of issue of the shares and could include the right of a class of shareholders to request or convene a meeting.

53. In addition the Law will continue to provide extensive safeguards protecting the interest of minority shareholders. In particular the rights of preference shareholders can only be varied by complying with the class rights provisions. Under the new class rights provisions, unless the company's constitution provides otherwise, any variation of the rights of preference shareholders has to be approved by a special resolution of the company and special resolution of the class of preference shareholders.

54. The Government therefore considers that a general rule to call a meeting of preference shareholders would interfere with the company's ability to negotiate the terms on which preference shares are issued and is not necessary to protect the rights of holders of preference shares.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 11

The Committee recommends that the ASC reconsider the criteria to be included in its Draft Class Order covering audit relief for large proprietary companies to remove any unnecessary audit burden from franchise motor dealers or businesses in similar circumstances.

BREAK.PARA: 55. The Committee recommended in its August 1995 report on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill that the Law contain criteria to govern the exercise of the ASC's discretion to grant relief from the requirement to prepare audited accounts. This recommendation was adopted by the former Government and enacted in the First Corporate Law Simplification Act 1995. The Committee also recommended in the same report that the 3 tests for determining whether a proprietary company was large or small (and therefore exempt from the reporting requirements), the criteria for exercising the ASC's discretion to exempt large proprietary companies from the requirements, and the effectiveness and cost of the process, should be reviewed by it and the Government after the new audit obligation has been in operation for 2 years. The Government is committed to undertaking this review. In May 1996, the Senate also resolved that the ASC should prepare a report by June 1998 on the operation of the small/large test. The Government considers it would be desirable to ensure coordination of these reviews to avoid duplication between them.

56. The Government notes that Recommendation 11 was not within the Committee's terms of reference, and that the Committee intends discuss ing the issue with the ASC. This recommendation is appropriately a matter for the Committee to raise with the ASC.

57. The Government notes that the ASC's Class Order exempting some large proprietary companies from the audit obligation has been changed from an earlier draft to meet a number of concerns raised, including by those representing motor dealers.

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I make an observation that there have been three important statements by the government, if you include the current one about which I am speaking. I understand that there is pressure on time. One wonders when we are going to get a look at the other two documents that have been tabled today. There are a number of positives and also a number of negatives in relation to these matters that need to be expressed in this chamber at some stage. I doubt that we will get time before Christmas, but I thought that I should take the opportunity of simply flagging my interest in those particular matters.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Madam President, I present the progress report from KPMG, the Senate department's internal auditors, on their audit of senators' travelling allowances for 1995-96. The progress report relates to the 1995-96 period of the 1995‐97 audit. It describes the data sources and methodology used in the data matching and sets out preliminary findings to date.

INTERJECT.PARA: These findings are important for all senators: 5,624 individual travel allowance claims were cross‐matched against DAS and other travel records; 5,500, or 97.8 per cent, were reconciled leaving 124 remaining. As of today, 105 of those 124 claims have been reconciled. KPMG is continuing reconciliation processes for the remaining 19. As a result of the audit checking processes, overpayments of $7,375 have been repaid or are due to the department, underpayments of $450 have been paid or are due by the department. The overall outcome of the audit is to date, in my view, very positive for both senators and the Senate department's administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The committee is considering the Public Service Bill 1997 and related bills and opposition amendments Nos 18 and 2, moved by Senator Faulkner.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening I was arguing, and I think persuasively, in support of opposition amendments Nos 18 and 2. The committee might recall that, in relation to amendment 18, I had indicated that the clause in the bill currently offers no guidance to agency heads on what workplace diversity programs ought to contain and how their effectiveness should be monitored.

SPEECH.PARA: I perhaps ought not repeat the arguments that I presented in support of these amendments last night, but I could predict to the committee that the government is likely to argue that it has achieved an appropriate level of guidance through the draft Public Service Commissioner's direction on diversity in employment. As far as the opposition is concerned, our preference is to provide this minimum level of guidance in the primary legislation. The government's prescription in the draft direction is in our view deficient in that it makes no provision for consultation with unions and employee representatives in the development of diversity programs.

It was on Senator Harradine's suggestion last night that I deferred opposition amendment No. 2 in relation to the definition of designated groups. In accepting the arguments that Senator Harradine put forward, I think it is appropriate to group that definition of designated groups with amendment No. 18. That definition in opposition amendment No. 2 is taken from the current Public Service Act. I commend both these amendments to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner correctly alluded to the fact that the government does find these amendments too prescriptive. We do have in the Public Service Commissioner's directions an area—chapter 2: diversity in employment—which we believe covers the situation more than adequately, and what we have here is something which is just too prescriptive, too unwieldy, for the act.

SPEECH.PARA: In our diversity requirements in the commissioner's directions, we do look at those aspects which touch on disadvantaged sectors of the community. We believe that that provides the equity that is necessary. It is correct that opposition amendments Nos 2 and 18 both touch on this. The government's argument in relation to both amendments is the same, and the government will be opposing both of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke briefly on this yesterday, but I will just repeat that the Democrats support these amendments. We do not accept the minister's argument about the need to keep detail to a minimum. Whilst loading up all the detail into subordinate legislation, there is no argument of principle in such a position. It simply enables, as I think Senator Cooney pointed out to us yesterday, a shift away from genuine accountability towards more government control of the Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: We think employment equity is one of the most important goals for the APS to meet and we do not think it should be left up to the Public Service Commissioner. We believe it is important that the obligations of agency heads in this regard be set out clearly in the act, and setting out these obligations in the act will do just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I focused on this matter and I think indicated last night—it was either last night or during the further study of the matter, together with another very major issue that is coming up—that the provisions that are included in amendment 18 are also included in the directions of the commissioner, copies of which have been provided to us. Under those circumstances, I felt it was not necessary to clutter up the bill. I do not think the government has any intention of suggesting that these particular criteria should not be observed by the agency head in establishing and implementing a workplace diversity program, because the directions that will be emanating from the commissioner contain in effect what is being proposed by Senator Faulkner in 18. So I do not propose to support that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (1) Clause 16, page 11 (lines 1 to 9), omit the clause, substitute:
16 Protection for whistleblowers

TAB.TAB: A person performing functions in or for an Agency must not victimise, intimidate, harass or discriminate against an APS employee because the APS employee has:
(a) made a public interest disclosure; or
(b) reported an alleged wrongdoing; or
(c) reported breaches or alleged breaches of the Code of Conduct to:
(i) the Commissioner or a person authorised for the purposes of this section by the Commissioner; or
(ii) the Merit Protection Commissioner or a person authorised for the purposes of this section by the Merit Protection Commissioner; or
(iii) an Agency Head or a person authorised for the purposes of this section by an Agency Head.

BREAK.PARA: This amendment is consequent to the defeat yesterday of our amendment which put forward a whole part and is also consequent to the very evident sympathy expressed from both the coalition side and the Labor side on matters to do with whistleblower protection. I accept that the Senate has made a decision that, to get full treatment, the whistleblower matter should be subject to a separate bill to be delivered by the Attorney-General, but the government has clearly intended that some minimal protection be provided for whistleblowers and has provided for that in clause 16.

To that clause 16, the opposition successfully put an amendment which added that the Merit Protection Commissioner should also be accessed by any employee who felt that he or she needed appropriate protection. However, because of the evident support for the general principles of ensuring that the terms and conditions of Public Service employees should include protection for whistleblowers, I thought I would come back to the committee and make a further attempt to persuade senators to strengthen that provision in a manner which would be to the advantage of the employees of the Public Service and, I believe, to the advantage of the parliament and the people as a whole, since it would go some way towards encouraging greater accountability.

In the first part of clause 16, the government at the moment has the words `must not victimise or discriminate against'. We have added the words `must not victimise, intimidate, harass or discriminate'. We have stretched that out once again based on our readings of the various royal commissions, inquiries and laws that apply in these areas which use the extended phraseology I have spelt out here. The second thing we have done is add the words:

PARA.EMPHASIS: . . . the APS employee has . . . made a public interest disclosure—

BREAK.PARA: The great weakness of the protection for whistleblowers provided by the government is that it only relates to breaches or alleged breaches of the code of conduct. Frankly, that is too narrowly confined, and it is our view that APS employees should also be protected when they have made a public interest disclosure. Senators should note that that in itself is a confined protection, since that disclosure can only be made to:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (i) the Commissioner or a person authorised for the purposes of this section by the Commissioner; or
(ii) the Merit Protection Commissioner or a person authorised for the purposes of this section by the Merit Protection Commissioner; or
(iii) an Agency Head or a person authorised for the purposes of this section by an Agency Head.

BREAK.PARA: So it is not as if it is a widely publicised area.

The third addition we have made is item (b), which is where they have reported an alleged wrongdoing. Once again, this picks up on wording and an intention which is expressed in other legislation and other recommendations where you are dealing with the issue of protection for whistleblowers. In a small but significant sense we seek to enlarge clause 16. We think is to the benefit of APS employees. We think it is to the benefit of accountability. It still includes all the elements that the government had put in and that the opposition had put in with their amendment. Accordingly, I commend our amendment to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, Senator Murray did run a number of these arguments previously in the committee stage. I indicated at the time that the opposition's general view was, while we have no argument in relation to the principle of these particular proposals—certainly I can indicate to him that I do support them in principle—we felt a better vehicle for them was separate whistleblowers legislation. I say again to Senator Murray that I do not think it would be improper at all for him to press the minister on a likely government response on that issue. I do think this is something that, as I indicated previously, the joint committee looked at in some detail.

SPEECH.PARA: It was perhaps the most complex and difficult issue that we had to give consideration to because these are very important matters. There is a need for them to be addressed by government. There is a need for them to be subject to debate in this parliament. The issue goes to the appropriateness or otherwise of them being dealt with as amendments to the Public Service Bill . As I have indicated previously, it is the opposition's view that the best way to deal with these particular matters is through separate whistleblowers legislation. That is a view that we have been consistent on and, regardless of the arguments put by Senator Murray again today, it is a position that the opposition will maintain.

I want to say very clearly that it is not to suggest that in principle these suggestions, these proposals, do not have merit. That is not the substance of the reason the opposition will be opposing these particular amendments from the Australian Democrats. They are important reforms. They deserve the attention of this parliament, but the opposition still believes that the Public Service Bill 1997 is not the appropriate vehicle for them to be advanced. It is for those reasons and those reasons only that the opposition will be maintaining its position in opposition to this amendment that has been moved by Senator Murray on behalf of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I acknowledge Senator Murray's tenacity in this matter. The arguments the government puts forward in opposing this remain much the same as yesterday and accord largely with what Senator Faulkner has related to the committee. The two areas that are introduced dealing with public interest disclosure and alleged wrongdoing bring into the scheme acts which would not necessarily entail a breach of the code of conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the government's view that this protection afforded in clause 16 should relate to breaches of the code of conduct and that anything further should be part of another piece of legislation. Further to my answer to Senator Murray yesterday about the question of where this is at, I indicated it had gone to the Attorney-General. I am advised that Dr Kemp has formally written to the Attorney-General asking him to give this his consideration and has expressed his concern in relation to this matter.
Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (19) Clause 19, page 11 (line 23), omit "particular individuals", substitute "individual staffing decisions".
(20) Clause 21, page 12 (after line 14), at the end of the clause, add:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) A direction under subsection (1) is to be published in the Gazette within 14 days of its issue.
(70) Clause 74, page 38 (line 9), omit "particular individuals", substitute "individual staffing decisions".

Opposition amendment No. 19 to clause 19 proposes that the words `particular individuals' be deleted from this clause and the words `individual staffing decisions' be substituted. We say to the committee that decisions relating to particular individuals is a very narrow class of decisions. We would prefer that the prohibition on ministerial interference apply to a broader range of staffing decisions, hence our proposal to change the wording to `individual staffing decisions', which need not necessarily be about particular individuals. I might also point out to the committee that these words are used in the explanatory memorandum.

In opposition amendment No. 20 we are proposing that any direction under clause 21 ought to be published in the Gazette within 14 days of its issue. I say very clearly to the committee but as succinctly as I can that this is simply in the interests of transparency and accountability. I hope that the committee gives due weight to those most important considerations.

Amendment No. 70 in relation to clause 74 proposes a similar change to the one we are proposing to clause 19 in relation to locally engaged employees. So the words `particular individuals' would be substituted by `individual staffing decisions'. As I say, it mirrors the amendment that the opposition has proposed to clause 19. I commend those amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments, albeit that the wording proposed by the opposition is slightly different. The ground for this is found in section 64 of the constitution, where ministers of state are afforded the responsibility of administering departments of state. Indeed, in clause 57 in the bill we have `Responsibility for managing Department' as a heading. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Secretary of a Department, under the Agency Minister, is responsible for managing the Department.

We have to balance that against any interference by a minister, any improper or undue interference. So the government is saying that the wording it has in relation to clauses 19, 21 and 74 is appropriate because we are saying that the interference should not be in relation to particular individuals—that is, you cannot tell an agency head, `Look, you cannot promote that person because they are not desirable or they have the wrong religion or something of that sort.' So we are looking at a particular interference in our embargo or in our prohibition.

We say that the wording as proposed by the opposition goes to individual staffing decisions, and that could go to groups of people, such as unemployed youth or areas of the community where it might be appropriate for a minister to give a direction as to policy. So we would think that just by that slight incremental change in the wording we are transgressing from one side of the fence to the other—from prohibiting the minister's undue interference to somewhat restraining his proper administration of the department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is the case, Minister, perhaps you might explain to the committee why this wording is used in the explanatory memorandum. I draw your attention to paragraph 3.24 of the explanatory memorandum where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: An Agency Head will not be subject to direction by any Minister in relation to individual . . . staffing decisions . . .
I would be interested to hear what you have to say on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —So would I be interested. I am just wondering whether Senator Faulkner is reading from a different version of the explanatory memorandum.
—I hope not.
—I think we would get into real trouble if that were the case. We are on clause 19, as I understand it, and 3.25 says in mine:

SPEECH.PARA: An Agency Head will not be subject to direction by any Minister in relation to individual APS staffing decisions . . .
This limitation on a Minister's powers of direction will reinforce the APS Value of an apolitical public service . . .
And 3.26 says:
The limitation will not apply to the appointment of Heads of Mission . . .
I would be interested in a clarification by the minister in respect of that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I am about to plead guilty, Senator Harradine. I expect that there might have been a revised explanatory memorandum, because at least the paragraph numbering is different in the document that I am referring to. But I am relieved to say to you that the substance of the argument remains the same, because the words that you quoted from the explanatory memorandum appear to be the same in the document from which I am reading. There may well have been a revised explanatory memorandum circulated. If there is, no doubt I will quickly be able to get hold of it.

SPEECH.PARA: But as I indicated to you, Senator Harradine, the words are the same. Paragraph 3.24 of the ex. memo. that I read from says:
An Agency Head will not be subject to direction by any Minister in relation to individual APS staffing decisions . . .

I think that the question in substance remains the same, Minister. Whether it is 3.24 or 3.25, I think it is still—Senator Harradine, I am sure you would agree—worthy of a response from the minister. We will sort out who is more up to date—and I have a horrible feeling that you might be, Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can clarify the position. The wording used in the explanatory memorandum is `individual APS staffing decisions'. The crucial difference there is `APS'. What the memorandum talks about is `individual APS staffing decisions'. As I see it, the amendment put forward by the opposition really says `individual staffing decisions'. So there is quite a difference there. We do not necessarily say that the wording has to be exactly the same as that in the explanatory memorandum. We have sought to make it more defined in our clause 19 by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: An Agency Head is not subject to direction by any Minister . . . in relation to particular individuals.
So we are targeting it specifically. The phrase as used by the opposition is perhaps broader in its application, and it talks of individual staffing decisions as a whole.

So, for instance, there may be a policy decision that a certain department has to go out and try to employ as many unemployed youth, for instance. I put it very basically, but that is a blunt example. That could be termed as an `individual staffing decision'; thereby, the minister is prohibited from giving some sort of policy direction. We are trying to distinguish between policy, which is a general broad‐brush direction, and targeting a particular individual in the APS. That is why we have used that wording.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I can see now what you are getting at. When I first looked at the amendment, I thought that it would be somewhat limiting on the power of the minister. I suppose the example that has been given by the minister would be a good one. Another possible example would be the agency head in charge of disability services. So there may be an interest in the government to make sure that as many persons with disabilities should be employed in that particular area as possible. That is what the clause is all about. I would support the clause as stated. Maybe there is a misunderstanding in the chamber, but that is what it means.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 22, page 13 (after line 5), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (5) Subject to this Act and to relevant awards and certified agreements, an Agency Head must engage a person as an APS employee on a permanent basis unless subsections (6) or (7) apply.

(6) An Agency Head may engage a person as an APS employee on a fixed term of less than 6 months if, in the Agency Head's opinion, the need for temporary assistance will not adversely affect the maintenance of a career service or a stable workforce.

(7) An Agency Head may engage a person as an APS employee on a fixed term of more than 6 months if, in the Agency Head's opinion, the employee is required to perform duties in relation to a project or task that has a fixed duration and:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Agency Head determines that the duties require skills or ability that is not, or cannot be made, available within the Agency; or

(b) in the case of a vacancy caused by a permanent officer being placed tempo rarily in another position or being on long term leave, there is no suitable permanent employee to fill the temporary vacancy.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is aimed at preventing casualisation of the APS work force. I believe that this particular wording had been previously agreed as an award clause during the life of the former Labor government. I must say—because I am sure Senator Ellison will say it if I do not—it obviously has not been agreed on by the present government. I would be interested to hear from Senator Ellison if the government is willing to give an assurance that it will agree to this in the context of award negotiations. If that were the case, I think Senator Ellison would perhaps persuasively argue that this might not be an amendment that the opposition ought to pursue.

If there is any argument about the use of the term `permanent', let me just say this: this is a term that is in common usage in the private sector. It entails no ironclad guarantees of permanency. The opposition uses it in the sense of permanent employment being subject to all the normal provisions for termination. I think this is an important amendment. I will be interested to hear the minister's response on this particular matter. In the absence of the sort of commitment that I have indicated might be forthcoming from the minister, I think it is appropriate that this amendment proceed and be supported by the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats strongly support this amendment. We think it is a very important one. We think it should be seen in the context of the general thrust of this bill, which is to give agency heads unprecedented powers in relation to individual employees. It is in this bill that we see the Public Service really being turned into a quasi private corporation. I want to quote Dr Michael Keating of the Institute of Public Administration in Australia. During his evidence to the JCPA, he made this point:

SPEECH.PARA: We support adopting private sector practices where they make sense rather than just because they are private sector. We make that distinction.

I do not think the bill makes that distinction. This particular amendment goes part of the way towards tipping the balance back in favour of the APS being a Public Service rather than a private company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there have been ongoing negotiations with the union in relation to this matter. In relation to the general employment conditions award, it may be that I could give an undertaking that continuing employment will constitute the usual basis for staffing functions in the APS.

SPEECH.PARA: The government is of the view that there is too much restriction in this amendment. The government is looking at a more decentralised aspect in that agency heads would look at recruitment in different ways. For instance, the Attorney‐General's Department recruits its lawyers somewhat differently than Treasury recruits its economists. We are trying to maintain this difference.

There are ongoing discussions in relation to the General Employment Conditions Award. I can give an undertaking that included in it would be the words `continuing employment will constitute the usual basis for staffing functions in the APS'. It may be that the opposition has to look at that undertaking to see where it finds itself in relation to it. The government is opposed to this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I was waiting for Senator Faulkner's response to the minister's statement to the committee. As I heard the statement to the committee, it was fairly clear that the normal thing would be that the current basis for employment in the Public Service would be maintained. Minister, on that particular matter, I heard what you said. If that is what the government's intention is, is it not a fact that the provisions of this amendment would give effect to the government's intention?

SPEECH.PARA: I know the government does not want to clutter up the legislation with all and everything. But when it comes to the fear held by many people, not only people in the Public Service itself but also people with an academic and outside professional interest in the maintenance of a Public Service with continuity and so on, these are points that are of interest to them.

BREAK.PARA: If that is the intention of the government—and I accept entirely what you say; I have never had cause at all to doubt what you say in a factual way—then I feel the government should have no real problem with this amendment. I am interested to hear what Senator Faulkner might have to say in response to your assurance to the committee and what you might say in response to what my understanding of the government's view is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether Senator Harradine was expecting a response from the minister, but let me indicate in response to Senator Harradine that I do not consider that the undertaking that the minister gave was adequate in these circumstances. I understand that negotiations the government is conducting on an APS‐wide award are not proceeding satisfactorily.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the opposition is concerned—and I want to echo what Senator Harradine was saying—we believe that it is sufficiently important for this particular matter to be resolved in the context of this committee debate. I would want to hear some far more persuasive argument from the government than Senator Ellison has been able to provide to the committee to this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can advise the committee that, indeed, yesterday there was a meeting between the government and the union. I understand another meeting has been set for 2 December. My feedback was that the discussions were perhaps more fruitful than the opposition would understand them to be—but that is from the government's point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a question which the government believes is dealt with more in a workplace relations environment, in the General Employment Conditions Award, and is something which is not appropriately contained within the legislation itself. This insertion would make it more prescriptive and would deal with not only those who are currently employed by the Australian Public Service but also those who would be in the future.

BREAK.PARA: I believe that the undertaking I have given gives a protection to those who are hitherto employed and would continue to be so. Others who joined the Australian Public Service would come under the new provisions. The question again is whether you want to make the act more prescriptive or rely on other instruments or avenues such as the General Employment Conditions Award.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (24) Clause 23, page 13 (line 11), after "time to time", insert "but may not diminish any such provisions".

(25) Clause 24, page 13 (lines 24 to 26), omit ". For this purpose, award and certified agreement have the same meanings as in the Workplace Relations Act 1996 .", substitute ", but may not diminish any such provisions.".

(26) Clause 24, page 14 (lines 1 and 2), omit "because of special circumstances", substitute ", provided any such determination does not diminish any provision of an award or certified agreement as in force at a particular time or as in force from time to time".
(27) Clause 24, page 14 (after line 4), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (5) For the purposes of this section, award and certified agreement have the same meanings as in the Workplace Relations Act 1996 .

SPEECH.PARA: (28) Clause 25, page 14 (line 7), after "Agency", insert "consistent with any provision in an award or certified agreement,".
(69) Clause 72, page 36 (lines 3 and 4), omit subclause (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) Determinations under this section are to provide that the provisions of any relevant awards or certified agreements continue to apply to affected APS employees until new provisions are agreed to by those employees.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition believes it would not be appropriate to allow classification rules issued by agency heads to diminish conditions which have previously been negotiated as part of an award or a certified agreement. In relation to our amendments to clause 24, given the amendments that we are making to this clause, all of which refer to award and certi fied agreements, it certainly makes sense to move the phrase `For this purpose' et cetera to new paragraph 5.

In relation to amendment 69, clause 72 of the bill, machinery of government changes, we say that it would not be fair to allow APS employees to be stripped of award conditions simply because of machinery of government changes. These amendments make good sense and certainly improve the bill, and they are worthy of strong support from the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments reflect the view of the Democrats that neither the Public Service minister nor the agency head should be permitted to set the remuneration or terms and conditions of employees at a level below that of an existing award or certified agreement. In particular, we see no valid reason for giving an agency head that power. The government might claim that it will lead to a more flexible public service, but I think it simply opens up all sorts of scenarios which are counterproductive to the evolution of a modern public service.

SPEECH.PARA: Aside from setting up a situation where individual employees could be penalised by agency heads—and, I might say, without going through proper disciplinary processes—it could also lead to major discrepancies across the APS, with some agencies offering higher or lower salaries than others, irrespective of the nature, value or priority of the work being undertaken by the agency. In our view, such an approach is unlikely to lead to better quality service, and it is also likely to erode the morale in those agencies with less capacity to pay.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is similar to debates we have had previously during the committee stage. By its amendments the opposition is, in effect, revisiting the workplace relations legislation. What we have here is a situation where you might have two layers of action or consideration. The appropriate situation is to not have that. These amendments, if passed, could lead to some uncertainty.

BREAK.PARA: It is the view of the government that the arguments of the opposition and the Democrats highlight this aspect of revisiting the workplace relations legislation. This is very carefully couched language which refers back to the workplace relations legislation. We do not want to reinvent the wheel. We do not want to bring in anything that could be at variance with the provisions of that legislation. We believe that this could result if these amendments were passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reason that everyone knows my position, I will be supporting Senator Faulkner on 24, 25 and 69, but I am inclined not to support 23, and I suspect that 23 may have been proposed in the event—
—Senator Harradine, clause 23 is not before the chair at present, it is 24 to 28 and 69.
