—My apologies. I was referring to Senator Faulkner's amendments Nos 24, 25 and 69. We are dealing with those, are we?
—We are.
—I indicate that I will be supporting those. Can I speak to clause 22A? I thought that Senator Faulkner wanted to deal with 23—that is, his amendment No. 23.
—That was dealt with last night, I think.
—I am sorry. You are right, that was dealt with last night. Thank you. I support the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, do I take it that Senator Harradine is supporting opposition amendments Nos 24, 25 and 26?
—Will the others be taken separately?
—The others will be taken separately.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not entirely sure that Senator Harradine expressed a view on amendments 26 through to 28. I will listen carefully to how he might vote as you call them, Mr Temporary Chairman. That might clarify where we are at.
—I am happy to deal with Senator Faulkner's amendments numbered 26, 27 and 28, because they involve the same principle, as I see it.
—They are before the chair. I did seek leave to move 24 to 28, and 69, together, Senator Harradine. You may not have heard that.
—They involve the same principle; I am voting for them all.
—The question is that amendments 24 to 28, and 69, moved by Senator Faulkner, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (29) Clause 25, page 14 (after line 8), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) An employee may apply to the Agency Head to decline a proposed transfer within 7 days after the employee receives notice of the transfer. The transfer is not to take effect unless the Agency Head rejects the application.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to this amendment, there is a similar provision in section 52 of the current act, but without the seven‐day time frame. This particular time frame was agreed as an award clause during the life of the previous Labor government.

In this instance, we are seeking a similar guarantee from the government to ensure that APS employees have some degree of protection from unfair dislocation for their families through transfer. This is an amendment that speaks for itself. I commend it to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subject to what the minister says, I think it does speak for itself and I will be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that there are adequate avenues for a review to be sought in relation to the assignment of duties, and that any employee of the APS does have it open to him or her to have such a decision reviewed. That is provided for in the regulations which cover the agreements. Looking at item 10 under schedule 1, the heading is somewhat misleading because this is an exception to that. Item 10(d) says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the reassignment of an employee to duties that the employee could not be reasonably expected to perform.
It is the government's contention that that would affect the situation and provide a review, and that it is not necessary to be contained within the act.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (30) Clause 28, page 14 (after line 24), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) The regulations must not provide for more than 30 days' suspension without remuneration unless exceptional circumstances apply.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment proposes that regulations must not provide for more than 30 days' suspension without remuneration, unless there are exceptional circumstances in relation to suspension from duties of APS employees. The amendment that the opposition proposes is consistent with the current Public Service Act. The situation is that the government's draft regulations are not tight enough in as much as there is no stipulation of a time frame. It is appropriate to have an assurance from the government about the 30‐day time frame unless there are exceptional circumstances. Again, this amendment commends itself and I ask the committee to support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's position is to oppose this amendment. Although there is no time limit on the suspen sion mentioned in clause 28, there is a provision for review from time to time. That is contained in part 4 of the regulations. I understand regulation 35(3) relates to that and that there is this review available. Again, the government's approach is not to have it in the primary legislation but to have it in the regulations, a draft of which has been circulated. I do not think anyone takes issue with the fact that you do have a provision for suspension. It is not normally part of a common law contract of employment that you can get suspended without payment. This provision is only contemplated for serious situations where an employee of the APS is alleged to have committed a criminal offence or something of that order.

—Clause 33 of the proposed Public Service regulations which we received from the government does refer to sanctions, including deduction from salary by way of a fine of up to no more than two per cent of the employee's annual salary. That is to do with fines. With regard to the suspension of payments, I am not sure that I am clear. Maybe I did not hear the minister correctly, but what is contained in the regulations which would make this amendment unnecessary? The amendment places into the new legislation, as I understand it, what is contained under section 63 of the current act. I cannot see anything in the regulations which would satisfy the chamber that the proposed amendment is not necessary.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to regulation 35 which is under part 4 headed `Suspension'—I referred to 35(3) earlier on—the agency head must review the suspension at reasonable intervals. It also deals earlier on in that regulation with the question of suspension. So, in regulation 35, suspension is dealt with squarely. Although I would concede that it is in the current legislation, the government's view is still that, rather than cluttering up the primary legislation with this, it should be contained in the regulations. But I can give an undertaking to the committee that an amendment along the lines of Senator Faulkner's amendment could be contained in regulation 35(3) where it talks about review of the suspension of reasonable intervals, if you wanted to put a time in there.
—Is the minister saying on behalf of the government that what is contained in the act at the present moment—that is to say, the cap—will be included in the regulations?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am prepared to give that undertaking.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it would make more sense, as I understand it, to move only opposition amendment No. 31 and then deal with amendment No. 32 if necessary. I think that would make it a little easier for the committee to deal with this particular issue. This relates to clause 29, `Termination of employment'. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (31) Clause 29, page 15 (lines 2 to 5), omit subclause (1), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (1) An Agency Head may at any time following due process, by notice in writing, terminate the employment of an APS employee in the Agency if, in the opinion of the Agency Head, termination is justified on any of the following grounds:

TAB.TAB: (a) unsatisfactory work performance;
(b) physical or mental incapacity;
(c) loss of essential qualifications;
(d) a serious breach of the Code of Conduct;
(e) being excess to the requirements of the Agency.
Note: The Workplace Relations Act 1996 has rules and entitlements that apply to termination of employment.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal here from the opposition is moved in the interests of ensuring that we have clarity and fairness. In our view, the grounds for termination should be spelt out in the bill and notice of reasons should be given in writing. I ought to inform the committee that the grounds used here for termination are those identified for SES employees in the commissioner's draft direction on SES em ployees. I would only be proposing to proceed with opposition amendments Nos 30 and 32 in the event of the committee determining that opposition amendment No. 31 is not worthy of its support.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Was Senator Faulkner referring to non-SES employees or only SES employees in relation to this amendment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to you that the grounds used here for termination are those identified in the commissioner's draft direction for SES employees. I will perhaps go on and make the logical point that we think that is appropriate for APS employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The genesis for the government's position came from chapter 8 in the report by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. There was not actually a recommendation made, but there were a number of comments made in relation to this matter. Paragraph 8.47 states:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to non-SES employees , the Committee accepts that the protections afforded by the Workplace Relations Act against termination of employment provide an adequate safeguard against unfair termination decisions which are commensurate with the protections afforded to workers in the private sector.

In relation to this amendment, we again have the situation where it is perhaps all in sawdust that the inclusion of this amendment is taking over the provisions of section 170CK of the Workplace Relations Act, which deals with the grounds on which people's employment is not to be terminated. It provides a list of reasons for which employment must not be terminated.

It is appropriate that that apply. If you bring in these two considerations, you leave litigation effectively open in relation to two pieces of legislation; that is, the Workplace Relations Act and this Public Service Act that was passed. The government believes that there may be some overlay in relation to that. It therefore opposes the amendments put by the opposition. Some of the reasons for which employment cannot be terminated in the Workplace Relations Act include union membership or participation, non-membership of a union and temporary absence due to illness or injury. There are some quite straightforward and commonsense reasons which would protect any worker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it thought by the government that what is proposed in the amendment would so conflict on occasion with the provisions of the workplace relations legislation that it would be less beneficial than the provisions of the workplace relations legislation and thus create a situation where the employee may take action to see that the more beneficial regime is applied? First of all, is it not a fact that if one makes specific requirements upon agency heads, as is proposed under this amendment, that that then overrides the provisions of the workplace relations legislation? Under those circumstances, there would be no such cause for concern on the government's part as to the possibility of litigation. Secondly—perhaps the clarification should come from the mover of the amendment as well as the government—is it being suggested that these criteria for termination of employment that we are considering may in some way be less beneficial than the provisions in the Workplace Relations Act?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —When one compares the list of reasons with the ones contained in the opposition amendment, one could at first blush say that the opposition's amendment is not as comprehensive as the reasons outlined in the Workplace Relations Act. It is perhaps more accurate to say that they cover different areas. So if you pass this, you could exclude certain aspects of those reasons contained in 170CK in so far as they are inconsistent and then leave it questionable as to the remainder of the workplace relations provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition amendment deals with unsatisfactory work performance. The Workplace Relations Act provision deals with temporary absence due to illness or injury. There is then absence on maternity or parental leave. They are more specific than unsatisfactory work performance, but perhaps they would come under that umbrella. Look at the question of the loss of essential qualifications. Could you say that that relates to membership or otherwise of a union? Does that relate to qualifications? Perhaps it concerns that provision in the workplace relations legislation which deals with race, colour, sex or sexual preference except if an inherent requirement of a particular position is for that, which you have these days. Under the Racial Discrimination Act, you can have positive discrimination, as it is called, where, to remedy disadvantage to a particular part of the community, there is provision for only Aboriginal people to apply for a position.

What you are dealing with is different terminology, different phrasing and different areas of the Workplace Relations Act compared to the provisions contained in (a) to (e) of the opposition amendment. The government sees the problem here more as being a cause of confusion and uncertainty rather than limiting the rights of the worker. It could well make them more uncertain, but I do not think, in fairness, I could say that it would reduce them. I would have to sit down and have a more thorough examination of the comparison between the two. In the first instance, confusion and uncertainty are totally undesirable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine raises an important issue that the committee ought to give consideration to in its deliberations. As I understand it, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, to Senator Harradine, what the opposition proposes is consistent with the existing Public Service Act. Certainly, as I indicated previously, this is consistent with what the government itself is proposing for SES employees. Also, it ought to be said that it is entirely appropriate for APS employees to be apprised of the grounds. In relation to the specific question, Senator Harradine, that you asked of both the minister and me, I can only say to you that they are—to the extent my knowledge goes—not less beneficial than what is contained within the Workplace Relations Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have, of course, in front of me the Public Service Commissioner's draft directions 1997. On page 14 thereof, at 4.6, we see the minimum requirements regarding termination of employment, upon which the opposition's amendment is based. I can understand that. My obvious predisposition is to say that it would be better to deal with these matters in the legislation rather than leave them to the workplace relations legislation. That would be my inclination.

SPEECH.PARA: I still have not really got a response to the question that I asked, that if this amendment were agreed upon, would aggrieved public servants, whose legal advice may be that the provisions of the Workplace Relations Act, notwithstanding what has been said by Senator Faulkner, are, in the narrow respect, more beneficial to an employee, have a—what is the word, Senator Cooney? Senator Ellison would know the word I am searching for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cause of action.
—Thank you, Senator Ellison. Would that be a cause of action upon which the public servant could rely?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps you could confirm, Minister, that such a termination would be appealable under clause 33 of the bill. That might assist Senator Harradine; I am doing the best I can but perhaps the minister could confirm that that is the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly would not make any difference in relation to the appeal because one would lie under the Workplace Relations Act to the Industrial Relations Commission. That would lie in any event. The nub of the question is: are we limiting the avenues of action open to an employee of the APS? The more accurate answer is that we are perhaps confusing them.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think I can say we are limiting them, but we are confusing them and that is undesirable. When one seeks counsel because one does not know or is not sure of the avenues that are open, it is an unsatisfactory state of affairs to be told, `On the one hand you could this, on the other hand you could do that.' We say that it should all be under that one umbrella of workplace relations legislation and that under that 170CK there are very good protections for the aggrieved worker.

TALK.START.PARA: —On balance, I think that I will be supporting the amendment. The amendment includes the very important provisions that the employee must be given full information about other employment in the agency, the agency head—having regard to the assessment—could make the assessment available to the employee, the commissioner has to certify that he or she is satisfied that the termination is in the best interests of the APS and notice of the termination has to be published in the Gazette .

—I wanted to indicate our support for this amendment. We accept the need for some reform of the termination processes, but we have been concerned for some time about the bill and the fact that it does not set out a service wide process for dealing with decisions leading up to termination and does not spell out the circumstances in which employment can be terminated. We think that Australian Public Service employees are entitled to have some certainty in knowing the grounds on which their employment can be terminated. For that reason, we support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I read from the basis for the clause which we are debating which is 4(6) of the draft directions by the commissioner. Even though I read from those instead of the amendment that was moved by Senator Faulkner, on the basis that the government is saying that the Workplace Relations Act is the one that ought to apply—and you know my view about the workplace relations legislation as a whole—I am inclined to vote for the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (32) Clause 29, page 15 (lines 6 to 9), omit subclause (3).

I think this could have been dealt with cognately with amendment No. 31. I think subclauses (2) and (3) of clause 29 were the subject of amendments moved by the government in the House of Representatives. I draw the committee's attention to subclause (2), which states, `The notice must include a statement of the reasons for the termination.' Subclause (3) states, `Non‐compliance with subsection (2) does not affect the termination.' I would be interested to hear if an argument really could be mounted here to suggest that subclause (3) does not completely undermine the effectiveness of the whole government amendment that was proposed in the House. I think it does. It is for those reasons that the opposition proposes to delete subclause 29(3).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of Senator Faulkner. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . (lines 6 to 9), omit subclause (3).

Lines 6 to 9 would include subclause (2) which states, `The notice must include a statement of the reasons for the termination.' We would be disinclined to support this if it did include subclause (2), however we would support subclause (3). Perhaps that amendment should be `clause 29, page 15 (lines 8 and 9), omit subclause (3).'

TALK.START.PARA: —I had assumed that was the case. One of the documents of opposition amendments that I have actually says, `(line 6 to 9), omit subclause (2) and (3).' The newer document does not refer to subclause (2) and I had just assumed that what you mean is simply `omit subclause (3)'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Allison and Senator Harradine are right. The opposition is proposing to delete subclause (3). Senator Allison is right that it should read `lines 8 and 9', and Senator Harradine is correct that it should be subclause (3). I want to clarify that.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (33) Clause 30, page 15 (lines 14 and 15), omit ", or such higher or lower age as is prescribed by the regulations".

I think the committee would accept that minimum retiring age is an important public policy issue. It is not appropriate that it could be varied for such an extensive category of employees simply by regulation. There is a similar provision in the current act, section 76U, but the power to vary the minimum retiring age is limited to prescribed classes of employees. It is not a broad power that extends to all APS employees. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government believes that this amendment would seek to restrict the minimum retirement age to 55. The amendment is not supported for that reason and because it is thought that there should be some sort of flexibility when one has regard to the vast range of occupations which are undertaken by employees of the Australian Public Service.

SPEECH.PARA: One just has to look at the situation of air traffic controllers who, I think, were formerly in the APS. Their occupation was one which was highly stressful. In fact, there was a situation where a lot of those air traffic controllers experienced early retirement due to the stress of their job. So, to that extent, the government believes there should be some flexibility here, and that flexibility is governed by regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one thing that occurs to me, Minister. If you pass a regulation which says the minimum retiring age will be 50, before we get up in December, and parliament is not back here until March, does that regulation not then take effect? Would that not mean that the person could lawfully retire without parliament having a say in that situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that would be so. Until it was disallowed, that would be the position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that the point made by Senator Ellison is valid, and I think this is in section 122 of the current act. Senator Faulkner has pointed out that it relates to specified areas, and the example that was given by Senator Ellison is one. However, the amendment would restrict the ability of the government—presumably after considerable consultations with those who are affected; and that no doubt would be ensured—and may, indeed, limit the opportunity of the public servants concerned to access some other benefits that may flow from the fact that they have retired at age 50 instead of age 55.

SPEECH.PARA: The more we look at this the better, and I am talking about in general. I am opposed to the general proposition of the government that was floating around a few months ago—I do not know where it has got to—that there should be some incentive for persons in the work force to go to the age of 70 before they retire. That was being canvassed around the place.

It was a classic proposal. It probably came from Treasury because, if you analyse the proposition, as I did, it turns out that at least in the first five years Treasury would be getting heaps of money because something like 17 per cent, or thereabouts, of the employees concerned die before they reach the age of 70 and, therefore, would not be eligible for the age pension. So that is a saving, is it not? And they, of course, would be contributing to Treasury all of the time via the pay‐as‐you‐earn tax system. So it was a very neat idea, but now we are talking about the minimum retiring age. I am supporting the government on this one, and I think the proposal by Senator Faulkner limits what can now be done under the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could there not be an aspect of retrospectivity about this, though? A person may be going to retire at 55—it has been their intention to do that for 10 years or more; they even went into the service on that basis—but when they get to 55 suddenly another 10 years is added to the time they have to go before they enjoy the benefits of retirement. It seems to me that there is flexibility, but the flexibility may be retrospective and may be unfair. If it is not retrospective, it may then be disappointing of people's reasonable expectations. If you have an age set by parliament, that is one thing, but if you have an age that can be either increased or decreased depending upon the decision of a department, that is another thing.
—That is a point, but the fact of the matter is that under section 122 the government has the power now.
—Minister, could you outline what is prescribed in the regulations in relation to this?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no intention to prescribe any other age. At this stage, it is 55 but this leaves the way open for this to be looked at. During the transaction of human affairs and experience, it could come to pass that there is an occupation which suffers some sort of stress—I mentioned earlier air traffic controllers. That was not so much the case 30 or 20 years ago, but that occupation did become more stressful recently with increased traffic in the air and more technological demands made in the area. So some occupations could change due to technology and other aspects of our lives, and the government needs this flexibility to address that.
—So, Minister, according to your explanation of this, that applies only in extraordinary circumstances?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think what I have outlined is extraordinary. The advance of technology in a certain occupation, the change in the demand that is made in relation to an occupation or the workload in a certain occupation is not a matter I would put down as extraordinary, but one which perhaps increases in an incremental way over time. So it was not extraordinary that air traffic controllers were changing their duties from perhaps the 1970s into the 1980s because of increased air traffic. That was not extraordinary. It was something which built up over time. Something which is extraordinary is something which is perhaps unintended, unexpected or unforseen. So it would not apply just to extraordinary matters.

—I can understand the situation as far as reducing the retiring age goes, but it is the ability to increase it which I want to know about. I wonder what effect that would have on an insurance policy. If somebody said, `I am going to retire at 55 and I want to take out an insurance policy on that basis,' and then two or three years before he or she turns 55, the retiring age is increased to 60, what would happen then?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you would have to look at the policy and the terms of that policy. Certainly, the person concerned could not be held accountable for any change because the government would be wreaking it upon them, so to speak. So I think there would be no prejudice suffered to the individual. In any event, you would have to look at the provisions of the policy.

—Are regulations expected soon on this matter? If there is no other minimum retiring age prescribed, does it mean that for air traffic controllers we will have regulations in the next short while? What stage is this at? Perhaps it would be better—and we support the ALP's amendments so this is what we are saying—if the government comes back to us as and when it is necessary to make those changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, air traffic controllers are no longer part of the Australian Public Service. I used them as an example. This allows the flexibility without having to come back to the chamber. There would be scrutiny by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee in any event. It is not something which could be slipped under the door in any way. It would have public scrutiny through the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and is something which could not be done lightly.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (34) Clause 31, page 15 (after line 25), after subclause (2), insert:

PARA.TAB: (2A) If an Agency Head, the Commissioner or the Merit Protection Commissioner receives any non‐Commonwealth remuneration for performing duties pertaining to their offices, then the Agency Minister may give a notice in writing to the Agency Head, Commissioner or Merit Protection Commissioner in relation to the whole, or a specified part, of the remuneration.
(2B) The amount notified by the Agency Minister:

TAB.TAB: (a) is taken to have been received by the Agency Head, Commissioner or Merit Protection Commissioner, as the case may be, on behalf of the Commonwealth; and
(b) may be recovered by the Commonwealth from the Agency Head, Commissioner or Merit Protection Commissioner as a debt in a court of competent jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition proposes this amendment on the age-old principle of what is good for the goose is good for the gander. In other words, if it is good enough for certain provisions to apply to APS employees receiving any non-Commonwealth remuneration for performing duties as an APS employee, we see absolutely no reason why these should not apply to others—that is, an agency head, the Public Service Commissioner or the Merit Protection Commissioner. I would hope the committee would see good sense in this particular clause of the bill being appropriately extended in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats strongly support this amendment, too. We think it is a very fair amendment. If APS employees cannot earn additional remuneration without the amount being recoverable by the Commonwealth, then the same limitation should apply to agency heads, the Public Service Commissioner and the Merit Protection Commissioner. Once again, the APS is not a private corporation where the CEOs or the members of the board can do whatever they like with no accountability to anyone. We see no justification and no fairness in the most senior APS employees being exempt from these provisions.

—I just ask the minister for an interpretation of what would happen if this amendment were carried and we had similar circumstances to when the head of the Prime Minister's department accepted, I think, $50,000 a year to head the Public Transport Corporation of Victoria and another $35,000 a year to be a board member of the Snowy hydro company. If our amendment was hereby carried, would that preclude arrangements being made in which those departmental heads could continue to top up their salary of $220,000 a year plus approve for themselves various entitlements—not go through the Public Service Commissioner for that particular one, but approve them themselves? I am talking about accommodation allowances, et cetera. Would this amendment moved by Senator Faulkner preclude that behaviour in future?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the opposition's amendment, it would be up to the agency minister as to what happened. You would have the power to order forfeiture and there is a sanction that is attached in (b) where it says that it may be recovered by the Commonwealth from the agency head or commissioners as a debt in a court of competent jurisdiction. So there is the sanction that does flow with it. But it would firstly depend on the agency minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Could Senator Faulkner advise who would be responsible for making the decision under this amendment? If an agency head, the Commissioner or Merit Protection Commissioner receives any non-Commonwealth remuneration for performing duties pertaining to their offices—
—The answer to your question is the agency minister.

—Yes. I was reading that incorrectly. Neither clause 31 nor the amendment precludes an APS employee at level 6 or SES people from receiving remuneration. Obviously that would have to be presumably declared.
—It is being treated the same way as the APS.
—It is being treated the same way as the APS. I think that is equitable.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (35) Clause 33, page 16 (after line 19) after subclause (2), insert:

PARA.TAB: (2A) An application for review of an APS action (other than action which involves or has resulted in termination of employment) in respect of promotion to determine who is the most meritorious officer, redeployment, inefficiency or misconduct is to be determined by a Review Committee consisting of:

TAB.TAB: (a) an independent convenor nominated by the Merit Protection Commissioner;
(b) a nominee of the relevant Agency Head; and
(c) an employee representative nominated in accordance with the regulations or in accordance with the provisions of an award or a certified agreement.
Note: The Workplace Relations Act 1996 has rules and entitlements that apply to the termination of employment.

PARA.TAB: (2B) For the purposes of paragraph (2A)(c), the provisions of an award or certified agreement prevail over the provisions of the regulations to the extent of any inconsistency.
(2C) A determination by a Review Committee is binding on the Agency Head.

(2D) The Merit Protection Commissioner is to make recommendations to the relevant Agency Head in respect of an application for review of any APS action, other than an action included in subsection (2A), which has not been satisfactorily resolved at the Agency level.

SPEECH.PARA: (44) Clause 49, page 25 (lines 8 and 9), omit "and made available by the Public Service Commissioner".
(45) Clause 49, page 25 (after line 9), at the end of the clause, add:

TAB.TAB: (3) For the purposes of this Act:
(a) the Merit Protection Commissioner and the APS employees assisting the Merit Protection Commissioner together constitute a Statutory Agency; and
(b) the Merit Protection Commissioner is the Head of that Statutory Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: (72) Clause 78, page 39 (after line 27), after subclause (5), insert:

PARA.TAB: (5A) The Merit Protection Commissioner may, in writing, delegate to an APS employee any of the Merit Protection Commissioner's powers or functions under this Act (other than this section).

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 35 is a particularly important one to clause 33—review of actions. I think it is important for the committee to understand that the government is abolishing all of the current appeal processes by repealing the Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act. Of course it is true to say—and I recognised this earlier in this particular debate—that the government has agreed, under a lot of pressure, to retain an independent Merit Protection Commissioner, which is dealt with under a new part 6 of the act.

The draft regulations that have been provided again fail to provide the Commissioner with sufficient powers, sufficient independence, to do the job. Amendment 35 would retain the current system of tripartite appeals committees which, according to the vast bulk of evidence that was presented to the Joint Committee on Public Accounts, particularly by the MPRA, has worked well. I really did not hear any corroboration for the views that were put forward by Dr Shergold, the Public Service Commissioner, and the government's claims—it was always a bit difficult to establish who was the real advocate for the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no difference between the two.

—On this particular issue I have made the point before, Senator Ray—I do not know whether you are aware of it—that Dr Shergold was a very strong advocate for the government's position. It is very difficult to make that distinction. In terms of these claims that the APS has become grievance ridden, there was not any supporting evidence that Dr Shergold or the government could point to. It would not be the intention of the opposition to have the review committees have powers that go beyond those that they currently have. I think it is important to make that clear to the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition amendment 44 proposes to delete the words `and made available by the Public Service Commissioner' from subclause 49(2). We believe that quite simply those words would compromise the independence of the Merit Protection Commissioner. We believe that opposition amendment 45 would give the Merit Protection Commissioner the necessary employment powers to employ his or her own staff. We believe that is an important issue for this committee to give consideration to.
Finally, opposition amendment 72 is the standard delegation provision. It mirrors that for the Public Service Commissioner. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats strongly support these amendments. One of our greatest concerns with this bill is its removal of the APS employees' appeal rights to an independent or an external body. We find it very unsatisfactory, especially as this bill considerably increases the powers of departmental heads and agency secretaries over APS employees.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that the approach being proposed by the government is almost certain to lead to unfair, arbitrary and improper decisions. Instead of going down this path, the government should heed the comments made in June 1996 in the report to the Commonwealth government of the National Commission of Audit that `referees should not be players as well and vice versa'. The minister will be aware of the submission made by the Merit Protection Review Agency to the JCPA that:

BREAK.PARA: . . . for there to be genuine accountability, the importance of independent, external review of administrative decisions increases in an environment where there are fewer other controls over primary decision makers.
The MPRA also said:
External review ought to be separated from the management of the Public Service if it is to be truly independent and thus contribute to a credible climate of public accountability.

We probably would have preferred to see an independent Commonwealth employment ombudsman established. We also would have preferred to see a process which is much more of a distance from the APS management than the amendments that are being proposed here. However, we will accept these amendments as being a reasonable compromise and one which does give APS employees access to a relatively independent review process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to these matters, a number of issues are touched on. Firstly, I refer to the independence of the Merit Protection Commissioner. The government does not agree that an independent statutory authority is needed. The government believes it is quite possible to have independent review with staff coming from the Public Service Commission who are with the Merit Protection Commissioner and that there would be an independent review without any bias at all. That, I think, takes care of the opposition amendments 44, 45 and 72.

SPEECH.PARA: The government did take on board the recommendation of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in relation to the Merit Protection Commissioner, and believes that it has adequately accommodated these concerns.

With respect to amendment 35, it is the government's view that the tripartite appeal committee is undesirable and that the current proposal as set out in the regulations is appropriate. In the circumstances it cannot support or agree to the proposed amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem with 33, the review of actions, is this. The government proposes to set out the mechanisms of the review by regulations. No doubt, you would say that those regula tions are subject to disallowance in this parliament, but in this case there is no ability for parliament to set up an independent structure. All it can do is to deny the government the structure it sets up. So there is a danger that there will be no structure at all, because the parliament will find the structure that the government sets up to be unsatisfactory and the government would fail to propose a structure that is satisfactory. It seems to me in those circumstances that the only way you can overcome that problem is to do what the opposition proposes to do in these amendments. That is the first point.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that even though the government might set up what seems to be a satisfactory structure, it is a structure set up by the government—the government being a party to the action—and the appearance of that is not good. So there are three reasons, I suppose: the practical reason of getting a structure that is satisfactory and that can be got to readily without there being toing‐and‐froing between the parliament and the executive; the second reason is that it is proper that the structure should not only be fair but appear to be fair, and therefore should be set up by somebody quite independent; and the third reason is that just out of a sense of fairness it is proper that there be an independent structure that is in fact independent and appears to be independent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that last point, in the regulations which have been circulated there is the provision for the use of an independent review by the Merit Protection Commissioner. Regulation 29 says:

SPEECH.PARA: An independent reviewer is not subject to direction by a Minister, Agency Head or APS employee in carrying out his or her duties.
The government believes that that is a framework for independent review.

TALK.START.PARA: —But don't you see that that is a government's creation—government being a party to this action? In fact, the various heads of the department are meant to represent the Commonwealth. Isn't the fact of the matter that in a review situation where a public servant is attempting to review the government he or she has to go to a review body that is set up by that government? Whether the government says it has to be independent or not, it is a body set up by one of the parties.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, the government appoints judges and they sit in judgment quite often on government departments and ministers who are taken to court, and they judge them accordingly. The situation here is that you have an independent reviewer who is involved in this process and who, as it is stated in the regulations, is not subject to the direction of ministers or agency heads or any APS employee. At the end of the day, I think any structure that you do get is going to have its genesis in the government somewhere. What the government has here is a workable situation with maximum independence. I take your point about the government having set it up, but really the government sets it all up.

—There is a difference with judges, isn't there? With judges, the government appoints particular people to a structure that is set up by parliament and to a position from which they can be removed only on a vote of both houses and where they have tenure and reasonable wages and a pension paid. From what you are saying, I take it that under these regulations similar conditions will be provided for people who staff these tribunals. If that is so, can't those regulations then be changed by government? I think the example of judges is a classic illustration of why there ought to be a review panel set up by parliament, as is the situation with judges. Judges are not appointed by parliament, but they are appointed to a structure and appointed to conditions which are set by parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The appointment of judges is not subject to the same scrutiny as these regulations. These regulations are under much more scrutiny than the appointment of judges. Regulations, of course, can disallow. The appointment of judges is a different story.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation here, after all, is that we are looking at a unique organisation which is in the service of the community and the government. It is not a situation where you are dealing with the community at large. I think the provision for independence here is perhaps not of the same requirement you have when there is a judge sitting in a community judging all and sundry. After all, this is an internal mechanism for reviewing matters within the Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —To use that comparison is the same as saying that a private enterprise should be able to appoint its own tribunal to judge whether it was entitled to dismiss its employee or to take action against its employee. That is the comparison here. We do not allow that. As a parliament, we have set up structures where people can contest their wrongful dismissal, and that is before a body that is set up by parliament. This is the exception because, if we agree to this legislation, we will be agreeing to legislation which will set up a body to judge a dispute between an employer and an employee, and that body will be decided upon by the employer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should make this my final word in the cause of brevity. That is subject to a possible appeal to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. After all, that is something which acts as an umbrella overarching all the actions of the review. So it is always available to the aggrieved person.

—I have some questions for you, Senator Faulkner. They are points of clarification. One of the amendments which was circulated said that the review committee would consist of an independent convener nominated by the commissioner. The amendment I have in front of me says Merit Protection Commissioner, but I just wanted to clarify that we were speaking to the same amendment. At the same time, Senator Faulkner, perhaps you could indicate what sort of role you see the Merit Protection Commissioner having in the review process. I note in your amendment No. 46 you say that the Merit Protection Commissioner will facilitate and support the operation of the review committees. Could we just have some clarification on those two points?

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We think the Merit Protection Commissioner ought to have a general role of overview in this process. I do not know, Senator Allison, whether you have an earlier copy of amendments before you. I apologise if that is the case, but these were circulated to all interested senators quite some time ago. We are talking here, very clearly, about the Merit Protection Commissioner, not the Public Service Commissioner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —For clarification, we are dealing with Senator Faulkner's amendments on sheet No. 695. I have a couple of matters for Senator Faulkner. Let us not beat around the bush. The previous government abolished the appeal provisions for SES people. In this discussion, we have been talking about what is good for the goose is good for the gander. Senator Faulkner, you yourself mentioned that in support of one of the previous amendments in relation to termination of employment, yet it was the previous government that actually withdrew these appeal rights of SES people. If your proposal is what is good for the goose is good for the gander, then what argument do you have to sustain what you are proposing now—unless this does apply to the SES?

SPEECH.PARA: I am in two minds about this. As a matter of fact, I must say from the start that, because those rights are currently there, I am inclined to support them. As Senator Ellison has said, the government has the provisions in its proposed Public Service regulations, of which it has given all of us an advanced copy.

An outline of the review process is listed in a nice diagram on page 4. This looks to be not so much a complex but a developed review process. If this developed review process is going to work in practice, then it will need to be supported by resources. That comes to the question of the Merit Protection Commissioner. In the diagram you have got the agency head making a decision and then the affected employee applies in writing for a review—that the first-tier review. Then the agency head reviews the action, et cetera.

If the employee is dissatisfied, then that employee can go to the Merit Protection Commissioner, who then reviews the decision and makes recommendations to the agency head. Alternatively, the affected public servant may apply directly in certain circumstances to the Merit Protection Commissioner, who may then refer the matter to an independent reviewer who reviews the action. Recommendations are then made to the agency head. I will not go into that any further, but it is clear that this is intended to be a substantive attempt to provide justice to public servants. At present the structure is the review procedures under the current legislation.

I come back to the point of resources. What kinds of resources is it envisaged that the government will provide for these procedures to be properly effective? In other words, what is the government proposing to do about the Merit Protection Commissioner, the establishment of an office of the Merit Protection Commissioner and the staffing of the commissioner's office? What amount has been set aside or considered to be necessary for independent reviewers? Who are the interdependent reviewers? Where are they going to come from? They are the sorts of things that the committee really needs to know before the committee can adequately deal with the matters.

I have seen nice plans like these in the regulations from time to time, but sometimes they have been done by people with airy‐fairy ideas and who do not have their feet on the ground. I am not suggesting that this is the case; I am taking it at face value that the government does want to have a process which does give justice to employees aggrieved by the decisions of the agency head. Minister, what are the resources that the government proposes should be applied for this purpose?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine has quite rightly reminded the committee of what the previous government did in relation to the Merit Protection Commissioner when staff were absorbed into the Public Service. As a result of that we now have the task of setting up the office afresh, if you like, and independently. That will require funding. At this stage all I can say, Senator Harradine, is that the government intends to adequately fund the Merit Protection Commissioner and the office of that person.

SPEECH.PARA: As to whom that might be, I am not in a position to be able to advise you at this point. In relation to who might be used as independent reviewers, again that is a situation which remains to be determined. But one would expect that they would be people who are experienced, professional and versed in some way in dealing with disputes.

In relation to the setting up of this structure, you quite rightly have pointed out the structure at the front of the regulations. The government would not have set about putting an outline of the review process in its draft regulations if it were not serious that that should not occur and should not be of substance. It is the government's intention to adequately resource that office and the functions attached to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to assure the minister and the committee that one of my questions was not who the Merit Protection Commissioner was going to be. I was interested to know where the independent reviewer is to come from. It is a bit vague; that is the problem. Despite the point that the goose and gander argument can be used against what is being proposed by the opposition as, when in government, the opposition cancelled the rights of the SES in regard to these matters, I still feel that it has not been sufficiently explained how this process is going to be a real deterrent against the nepotism that theoretically may be applied in agencies by certain agency heads.

SPEECH.PARA: It also has to be understood—and we all understand it—that this is a career service. It is necessary to make sure that the service is based on true professionalism, skills and experience. You have to evaluate those matters when it comes to the question of selection or promotion to determine who is the most efficient officer in respect of redeployment, reappointment, reintegration, to say nothing of dismissal or sanctions that are applied to employees. I distributed an amendment—it is a float—

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like Telstra.
—It is a `Telstra'. Though I voted for the one‐third sale of Telstra, I must declare to the committee that I did not apply for any shares. I do not know that I would be allowed to.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage, my amendment on sheet 780 is a float, but it puts in writing what actually occurs with agencies at the moment. They have a tripartite arrangement. As I understand it, they certainly can have it; it is provided for. I had hoped that if we could get to a situation where certain other matters could be referred to under the current structure in the legislation, similar to what is being proposed by Senator Faulkner, we might have been able to get something along those lines.

They are very serious questions for appeal, but if this other procedure were adopted in the first instance, then it may well be that that would be sufficient to enable the provisions of clause 33 of the government's bill, the review of actions, to apply if the provisions floated in my amendment applied in respect of engagements or promotions of APS employees. It is in that area where the real problem that the government sees applies. It is in that area that the government, as far as I hear the government saying, holds up a whole series of actions that the agency head might wish to take in the time that it takes for appeals to be finalised and so on.

At this stage, I will be voting for the opposition amendments, but in the second round—and there is no doubt we will we have one—it might well be that the government might have a look at this and come forward with a proposal that its structure contained in the draft regulations could apply to the disciplinary and major promotion areas. However, in order to ensure that we are not wasting time at this stage, I will be supporting the opposition's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, to make it clear: are you proposing to move your extra amendment to clause 33 at this stage?
—No.

BREAK.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (46) Clause 50, page 25 (lines 10 to 13), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 50 Merit Protection Commissioner's functions

TAB.TAB: The Merit Protection Commissioner's functions are:
(a) to facilitate and support the proper and efficient operation of, Review Committees in accordance with subsection 33(2A);
(b) to make recommendations to Agency Heads in respect of applications for review of APS actions in accordance with subsection 33(2D);

(c) to consider and report to the Public Service Minister on any matter relating to APS employment (including such a matter referred to the Merit Protection Commissioner by the Public Service Minister);
(d) to enquire into reports made to the Merit Protection Commissioner (or to a person authorised by the Merit Protection Commissioner) as mentioned in section 16.
(e) any function prescribed by the regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, this is an important amendment. After significant pressure, the government has created the Office of the Merit Protection Commissioner but has not given the Merit Protection Commissioner the functions, the powers and the protections which are necessary for the commissioner to be fully independent and fully effective.

We are not satisfied with the provisions of the government's draft regulations on review of actions. Accordingly, we are proposing what we believe are the necessary and appropriate powers and functions for the commissioner, which are essentially those contained in the current Merit Protection (Australian Government Employees) Act. In any case, we believe it is more appropriate that the commissioner's primary and general responsibilities be set out in the bill itself, which allows the parliament to have an input and a voice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. It is quite appropriate that the regulations provide for the functions of the Merit Protection Commissioner. The issue of a Merit Protection Commissioner is one that we took up from the committee in its inquiry. The functions of the Merit Protection Commissioner will be prescribed by regulations. It is proposed that the functions include responsibility for a streamlined external review process; approval of independent reviews external to the agency in which the aggrieved employee is employed; monitoring the progress of reviews that have been sought; making recommendations to the agency head; and reporting to the Public Service Commission on matters not satisfactorily resolved.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe it is appropriate for those matters to be contained in regulations, and that this system provides an independent review. We are reversing the previous government's stance when the staff were absorbed into the Public Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Paragraph 50(c), omit "the Public Service Minister" (wherever occurring), substitute "any relevant Minister".

The amendment omits `the Public Service Minister' in the opposition's amendment and substitutes `any relevant Minister'. This opposition amendment relates back to clause 33, which is the `review of actions' clause. I have introduced this amendment because I am concerned once again with accountability matters. I am concerned that in the review of actions employees should not be constrained to any particular and individual minister in a formal sense. Employees should be able to access any relevant minister. That then allows employees to have greater access to the various ministers they might know, who might be in the same building as they are or whom they feel comfortable with.

BREAK.PARA: If they are required to go through the formal access of the Public Service Minister only, who is not precluded by my amendment, our feeling is that that would unnecessarily limit the access and protection which is intended by the opposition's amendment. I therefore commend my amendment to the opposition amendment No. 46 to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that I give a very brief response to Senator Murray, because he has made a considered contribution to the debate. The view of the opposition is that we consider the Public Service Minister to be the appropriate minister to receive these reports. I have not heard a persuasive argument that would allow me to support the amendment. I hear what Senator Murray says, but I really think in this instance that the minister with responsibility for the Public Service or assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service matters is the person who most appropriately should receive these reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Murray's) not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) After paragraph 50(d), insert:

TAB.TAB: (da) to provide advice to APS employees in relation to disclosures under section 16;

(db) to provide support to APS employees in relation to disclosures under section 16 including through the provision of education programs, counselling, protection, re‐employment assistance and safeguarding of documents.

SPEECH.PARA: This is, once again, addressed to you, Senator Faulkner. If you accept it, then we can have an opportunity or a prospect of promoting it. Amendment No. 3 on page 769 relates back to section 16 which was the whistleblower's protection. The whistleblower's protection clause says:

A person performing functions in or for an Agency must not victimise, or discriminate against, an APS employee because the APS employee has reported breaches (or alleged breaches) of the Code of Conduct to:
(a) the Commissioner . . .

The commissioner is defined on page five of part 2, `Interpretation', as the `Public Service Commissioner appointed under this act'. You would be aware that your amendment refers to the Merit Protection Commissioner. It is our view that the Public Service Commissioner might well receive the report but it is not his or her function to act as the prop or the support for the APS employee who has made the report. The Public Service Commissioner's job is simply to receive the report and to make an investigation and follow it up.

Our belief, however, is that, in relation to matters of whistleblowing which the government has attended to under clause 16 in a minimalist sense, there may still be a need to provide advice to APS employees in relation to those disclosures and to provide support to APS employees in relation to those disclosures including through the provision of education programs, counselling, protection, re‐employment assistance and safeguarding of documents. Those of you who heard me talk on this matter yesterday would recall that I referred to the August 1994 report of the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, In the public interest. Those matters I have picked up in my amendment under (3)(db) in fact relate to recommendations which came out of that report.

It is our belief that the Merit Protection Commissioner would be the appropriate person to provide the support and prop which may be necessary in a whistleblowing matter, in contrast to the Public Service Commissioner whose job, under clause 16, is to purely receive and then investigate a report and not to provide some kind of support for these matters. We think it is an appropriate addition to the list of matters put under your proposed amendments, Senator Faulkner. I would, therefore, commend it to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I just say for the record that the government opposes the amendment proposed by Senator Murray. We opposed the previous one on grounds similarly expressed by the opposition and by the government on other matters which are related.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have a similar set of circumstances before the committee. Again, Senator Murray may well have a strong case on the merit of what he puts before us. The difficulty is that I have maintained, on behalf of the opposition, a consistent position—I still maintain it, Senator Murray, and I hope you appreciate that that is the case—that these matters are better addressed through whistleblowers legislation. I rather expect that you would predict that I would be consistent on these matters. My approach to a number of subsequent amendments that you are going to move will, again, be consistent. We strongly believe that this is a matter which the parliament ought to address in separate legislation. We believe that is the most effective way of dealing with the whistleblowing issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, you would appreciate that your consistency is not convincing but it is overwhelming.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Murray's) not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now need to put the question on opposition amendment No. 46.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —What is being proposed is to place in the legislation the duties of the Merit Protection Commissioner, and I support that.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Faulkner's) agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we move off this particular issue, I have noticed some press speculation literally within the last 24 hours about proposals the government might have in relation to the Merit Protection Commissioner. I would be interested, given the amendments that have found favour with the committee, whether it is the government's intention and whether an assurance can be given that we will have a full-time Merit Protection Commissioner. That is an assurance I would like to receive from the minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the suggestion in today's Canberra Times suggesting that the government has left open the possibility that the Merit Protection Commissioner will be a part-time position. Can I say that the government accepted the advice of the JCPA in relation to the position of a Merit Protection Commissioner. Clause 53 of the bill does not provide that the position of the Merit Protection Commissioner be part time. I refer to the clause which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The remuneration and other conditions of appointment of the Merit Protection Commissioner are as determined in writing by the Public Service Minister.

I assure the Senate that the person appointed to this important position will be an appropriate person on terms and conditions which will enable the role to be effectively performed to ensure that the administration of the APS continues to be free of any suggestions of favouritism or corruption.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that is an assurance. As far as the opposition is concerned, there is no way that the functions that the Senate has determined are responsibilities for merit protection could be conducted by anyone other than someone who has this as a full‐time level of responsibility. I did not quite hear the satisfactory words pass the minister's lips. Minister, would my interpretation of your words, that you have given the Senate such an assurance, be an accurate one?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —The appointment of the Merit Protection Commissioner will be such that the commissioner concerned will be able to carry out his or her duties fully. At this stage, that is the government's undertaking.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am genuinely very concerned about this issue. I was hoping there would be no need to move a further amendment.
—He said fully.
—Senator Harradine, if you heard that—
—I heard him say fully. What is fully if not full time?
—Is fully full time, Minister? Senator Harradine has interpreted this a little differently from me.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to mislead the Senate in any way. The government intends to appoint a Merit Protection Commissioner who will be able to carry out his or her duties fully and meet the requirements of the legislation and regulations. The government is unable to say or give any undertaking as to the duration of the employment. When I say duration I do not mean from the start to the finish of engagement. I mean the hours for which that person will be required on a weekly basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, Minister, I do not think that really is a satisfactory response to the committee. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 52, page 26 (line 6), after "Governor‐General", insert "on a full‐time basis and".

Clearly, the responsibilities of the Merit Protection Commissioner now are such that it will require someone dedicated to this task on a full‐time basis. I would have preferred a commitment from the minister and to have moved on but, in these circumstances, it is appropriate to move this amendment. There has been press speculation about this and it has certainly raised serious concerns within the Opposition, and right throughout the Australian Public Service. It is for those reasons that the Opposition proposes this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are happy to support this amendment. We are disappointed that the minister has been seen to be equivocal in his response to that question. It seems to me that the answer could be that a part‐time commis sioner would be able to fully satisfy the requirements of the description of the functions. I indicate that the Democrats now strongly support the need for such an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that the functions that should attach to the job of Merit Protection Commissioner have now been decided upon by the committee, I would have thought that that person would be as busy as a one‐armed paper hanger with fleas. Under those circumstances, I would have thought that that person would have to be full time.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened carefully to what the minister said. He used the words `fully engaged'. I do not think that there is much equivocation there. I just confirm the view that is probably generally felt around the chamber that this job ought to be a full‐time job. I am inclined to support the amendment that has been moved by the opposition, as circulated.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (47) Clause 51, page 25 (lines 16 and 17), omit "Public Service Commissioner", substitute "Public Service Minister, for presentation to the Parliament,".
(49) Page 25 (after line 20), after clause 51, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 51A Capacity to report to the Prime Minister and Parliament

TAB.TAB: Where action that is, in the opinion of the Merit Protection Commissioner, adequate and appropriate in the circumstances is not taken with respect to the matters and recommendations included in a report to an Agency or an investigation of a grievance, the Merit Protection Commissioner may in writing inform the Agency Minister, the Prime Minister, the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition argues that the Merit Protection Commissioner should report to parliament through the Public Service minister. In our view, it is vitally important to the independence and authority of the Merit Protection Commissioner that the commissioner has the capacity to report directly to the Prime Minister and the parliament on significant matters, as is currently the situation. We would not expect a commissioner to have to exercise this power often, if at all. But the fact that the power is there constitutes a powerful deterrent to decision makers who might wish to ignore due process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service is, in my view, not just there to serve the government in a narrow sense; it is there to serve the public. Obviously, there must be direction by the government but the capability to direct must be there as well. Essentially, the public servant is a servant of the public, whichever government is in power. The government is charged with the responsibility of carrying out government policy, of course. But the Public Service now is accountable in many respects to the parliament. What have we been doing most of last week? We have been sitting in estimates committees asking the Public Service to give an account of the expenditure of moneys that has been voted by the parliament for particular departments.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to recognise the authority of the parliament and, as Senator Faulkner said, to uphold what is currently the case—the ability of this officer to report to parliament directly. I do not want to go over it because there is another situation in Victoria at the present moment with the Auditor‐General but I believe that, in the interests of democracy and in the interests of the profession of the Public Service, this office of the Merit Protection Commissioner should be able to report in writing information to the agency minister, the Prime Minister and to the parliament through the presiding officers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate that the government records its opposition to this amendment. Clause 51(2) of the bill provides that the Merit Protection Commissioner's report is to be included in the report of the Public Service Commissioner prepared in accordance with clause 44(2). It is the view of the government that it is considered more appropriate that the Merit Protection Commissioner report to the Public Service Commissioner, rather than direct to the parliament or the agency minister. There will be provision in the annual reporting by the Public Service Commissioner which will, in turn, provide the report by the Merit Protection Commissioner. Therefore, the government believes that there is adequate transparency and accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (36) Clause 35, page 17 (lines 8 to 16), omit subclause (2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) The function of the SES is to provide a group of APS employees who collectively provide a mobile leadership resource for the APS as a whole and who, as individuals, within their Agencies:

TAB.TAB: (a) provide one or more of the following at a high level:
(i) professional expertise;
(ii) policy advice;
(iii) management; and
(b) promote co‐operation with other Agencies; and
(c) by personal example and other appropriate means, promote the APS Values and compliance with the Code of Conduct.

SPEECH.PARA: (37) Clause 36, page 17 (line 19), at the end of the clause, add ", including engagement, promotion, redeployment, mobility and termination".
(38) Clause 38, page 18 (lines 3 to 5), omit the clause, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 38 Termination of employment

TAB.TAB: In the case of termination of the employment of an SES employee, the Commissioner must certify that the termination meets the minimum requirements specified in a direction issued under section 36 and that the termination is in the best interests of the APS.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition amendment No. 36 to clause 35 of the bill, which deals with the constitution and role of the SES, is an important amendment. It is again, if you like, an attempt to counter the fragmentation of the APS which the bill in its current form will encourage and to retain the SES as a mobile leadership group, which, of course, is how the SES was origi nally conceived. We believe it is appropriate that this should be reflected in the legislation. The current act provides that the SES may be deployed so as best to promote the efficiency of the APS.

In relation to opposition amendment No. 37, we believe the commissioner should have a role in each of these important areas: engagement, promotion, redeployment, mobility and termination. We think that these are important areas of SES employment. I draw the committee's attention to the fact that the explanatory memorandum already mentions engagement, promotion and separation.

In relation to opposition amendment No. 38 to clause 38, termination subject to the Workplace Relations Act, given the increased powers of agency heads to set salary and conditions, as well as hire and fire, there is a very strong argument that SES officers should have at least some protection from capricious or arbitrary dismissal. Of course, further protection will be afforded by the certification proposed in the new section 38.
