The application of the unfair dismissal provisions of the Workplace Relations Act to SES officers is unclear, so perhaps it might be a useful point on this particular amendment if Minister Ellison could clarify that issue for the benefit of the committee before we move on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is extraordinary that no government minister or parliamentary secretary has deemed these bills significantly important enough to be in the chamber. Despite some 14 months having passed since the government announced the surcharge tax measure designed to apply an additional 15 per cent tax on the superannuation contributions of high income earners, here we are again about to debate a package of six complicated amendment bills which will supposedly fix the many problems associated with the government's ill‐conceived and error ridden 15 per cent superannuation tax measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence given to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation recently confirmed that even with these amendment bills, this measure may still not apply to some defined benefit superannuation funds. In that evidence the committee heard that these bills will not fix what is a fundamentally flawed and disastrous superannuation policy. That evidence also showed that these amendment bills have the potential to make things even more complicated and unfair—for example, the inconsistent superannuation tax treatment of those in defined benefit schemes compared with those in accumulation schemes.

Labor and a whole litany of industry representatives, consumer representatives, superannuation specialists and the superannuation select committee, now in two separate reports, told the government that this legislation would not work. The government was told time and time again that its collection method was too complicated, that it would impact on low and middle income earners, that it would cost more to implement than the revenue it would collect and that it would undermine people's confidence in superannuation as a savings vehicle.

Now we can add to that list of critics, thanks to the recent Senate select committee hearings into these bills, Mr Noel Davis, a superannuation lawyer from the law firm Clayton Utz—I might say that law firm is the law firm which retained the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) as a direct consultant to it for many years, and therefore I guess it is the Prime Minister's law firm—who said:
In my 20‐odd years of practice in this area, this is by far the worst legislation that I have seen.
It is bad legislation and it was enacted purely out of political expediency.
We all know what the political expediency that Mr Davis is referring to is—a broken election promise by the coalition not to increase any existing taxes or introduce any new taxes.

That is the reason the government chose a complex and constitutionally doubtful collection method. To collect the superannuation tax in a way which was administratively simplest and most cost effective would have meant breaking solemn commitments made before the last federal election neither to raise the rate of existing taxes nor to introduce any new taxes, but that is exactly what this is—a new tax.

How did the government deal with the fact that it was breaking its promise not to introduce any new taxes and not to increase existing taxes? It tried to deceive the Australian public by implementing what it called a surcharge, but which everyone in the country knew was really another tax. It tried to slip a new tax on superannuation past the people of Australia by calling it a surcharge and hoping that nobody would notice.

People did notice. They noticed and they did not like being deceived. They are not impressed by governments who try to disguise broken election promises by calling a tax a surcharge. It did not work anyway. The superannuation tax which the government tried to hide by calling it a surcharge is now called a tax because of amendments in the Senate which were designed to inject some honesty into the debate and to give the government the opportunity to go back to the drawing board and design a better collection method for the tax.

Unfortunately, that did not happen. The government has chosen to persist with its flawed collection method for the superannuation tax when it could have saved us and itself a lot of trouble in the first place by calling the surcharge a tax and administering it in the most efficient manner possible.

If this is an example of what we can expect from this government by way of taxation reform, it is no wonder that Australians are quaking in their boots at the thought of a GST. This surcharge tax measure has severely undermined any credibility the coalition government had, if it had any after 1993, on taxation reform.

So despite the advice offered the last time we debated these bills, despite the willingness and encouragement from the opposition for the government to change its method of collection of the superannuation tax, here we are again debating a set of bills designed to fix the government's superannuation tax mess. The opposition believes the government should—indeed, has an obligation to—clean up its own superannuation tax mess.

BREAK.PARA: We are not opposed to the intent of these bills which apply the superannuation tax to high income earners excluded from the flawed original legislation and will not be opposing the second reading of the bills. However, we do have some concerns about these bills and will be moving some appropriate amendments which we believe will go some way towards making this flawed and unfair measure more sensible.

I also understand that the Australian Democrats will be moving a second reading amendment calling for the delay of these bills, requiring the government to consult further with the industry and providing an extension of time for defined benefit funds to report to the Australian Taxation Office. Labor will not be supporting the amendment for several reasons. It is interesting that the Democrats are taking such a principled stand on this issue given that they, along with Green senators, supported the government's surcharge tax legislation last time we debated this measure in this chamber.

Clearly, Democrat senators are now listening to the criticisms about this measure, many of which are the same criticisms that were around last time. We welcome this newfound concern for the superannuation tax collection method but lament the fact that it is a bit late. The measure already applies to many superannuation funds and will be paid by thousands of low and middle income earners regardless of whether these bills are passed or not. That is a reality which cannot be ignored and should not be forgotten by those who previously supported this measure.

Delaying these bills a further two weeks and forcing the government to consult with industry will not result in a better piece of legislation simply because the government is not listening to industry. We have already gone through an extensive consultative process via the Senate select committee hearings. Consider the evidence to the committee from Mr Noel Davis, a partner and superannuation lawyer with Clayton Utz, the Prime Minister's legal firm, when he said:

You, at your end, have not seen this, but the arrogance of the government in its responses or its lack of responses to people who have put a great deal of time and effort into putting forward genuine submissions as to what the problems are, and were, with this act, and the arrogance with which those submissions have been dealt with, had to be seen to be believed.

So delaying these bills another two weeks so that the industry can talk to an arrogant blank wall, or an empty vessel in the case of Senator Kemp, on this issue, or even forcing the government to talk to the industry, is a waste of time when the government has shown that it is unwilling to listen to constructive criticism.

These bills will give the Commissioner of Taxation the discretion to extend the time that a fund has to report to the Australian Taxation Office. There is thus no need to provide an across-the-board extension of time to defined benefit funds, provided the commissioner is fair and reasonable in using his discretion to extend the reporting date. So this stunt by the Democrats has no substance and arises because they understand the gravity of the error they made in making a deal with the government to pass what Mr Davis from Clayton Utz, a renowned industry expert, has referred to as `by far the worst legislation I have seen'. We oppose it not because we disagree with the objectives of the Democrats' second reading amendment but because we know it will not achieve those objectives.

What are some of the errors which these amendment bills are supposed to fix? Before the Senate committee examined these amendment bills, I would have counted at least 10 superannuation tax bungles but, since then, more bungles have been revealed which the government, up till now, has not provided any sensible answers to.

The first is that the superannuation tax did not apply to state politicians, judges and public servants because they are in constitutionally protected schemes. The government was hoping to get the states to pass complementary legislation which would have allowed the tax to be collected from state public servants, judges and politicians but, unfortunately, that has not gone as was hoped. The states, especially so-called conservative states such as South Australia and Western Australia, gave the government a big N‐O no on the super tax.

Because of the failure of the government to get the cooperation of the states, we have here as part of this package two additional bills which will have the superannuation tax apply to these fund members. True to form with this superannuation tax, the way that the government is proposing to do this will create even further complexity, confusion and uncertainty for both superannuation funds and the fund members affected.

For example, the superannuation tax collection method for schemes which are not constitutionally protected is different from the collection method for constitutionally protected schemes. Both superannuation funds will be required to notify the Australian Taxation Office of a member's taxable superannuation contributions, however, for constitutionally protected schemes, it will be the fund member who is liable for the superannuation tax rather than the superannuation fund itself. This, of course, differs from schemes which are not constitutionally protected where the superannuation fund itself is liable for the superannuation tax.

It is important to remember that one of the reasons the government claimed that its superannuation tax was not actually a tax was that it said the superannuation funds will be paying it, not the individual member. But, for constitutionally protected schemes, the opposite will be happening. It is a tax on individual fund members administered by the Australian Taxation Office. So the government's feeble defence that it was not breaking an election promise now stands completely exposed. One has to then ask the question: why is the government persisting with this crazy collection method when it has undermined its own arguments?

The second bungle in the superannuation tax legislation was the government's failure to include federal public servants, judges and politicians. It is amazing to think that the government came up with a policy which did not include its own employees. One would have thought that the government would have been able to at least ensure that its own employees set an example by paying the tax.

The third bungle was the government's admission that it would have to redraft the legislation to correct problems in collection from the defined benefit funds. This problem arose from the government's attempt to make the legislation fit within the constitution after Dennis Rose QC pointed out that the tax was unconstitutional. While that doubt still appears to exist, according to some, these bills appear to include high income earners in defined benefit schemes, albeit in an incredibly complex and expensive way.

The fourth bungle related to evidence suggesting that the tax could be an eligible tax deduction. It is absolutely absurd that a tax which is intended to raise revenue for the government could be considered as a tax deduction, therefore, negating the whole value of the exercise.

The fifth bungle relates to concerns that, in defined benefit funds with benefit cliffs, individuals would be assessed as having a total superannuation tax liability of higher than 15 per cent. The government seems to have understood the unfairness of the impact of this measure and has now apparently moved to ensure that it does not happen. However, as the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation reported, there are problems of consistency surrounding this measure. That makes five bungles which this package of bills is proposing to rectify but which, according to the Senate select committee hearings into these bills, will only add to the complexity of the legislation.

The disappointing aspect of the next set of bungles that I will identify is that they are errors in the government's model which no amount of legislative tinkering will adequately fix. The only way the government could fix the mess it has created would be to change the entire foolish collection method it has adopted.

For example, the government's legislative amendments are, unfortunately, too late to prevent rises in fees and charges as superannuation funds put in place ridiculously complicated schemes to collect and process the information needed to pass on to the Australian Taxation Office. The estimated collection costs could be up to $100 million, with some estimates at more than $200 million. Then there is the huge cost to superannuation funds of having to collect thousands of tax file numbers from members who, for their own reasons of privacy, may have chosen not to give their tax file numbers to their superannuation funds. A perspective on the government's cost bungle is offered again by Noel Davis who, in a recent Superannuation Bulletin article, said:

Because of the deficiencies and complexities of the legislation imposing this tax . . . the cost of implementing the administration systems to collect the tax will probably exceed the amount of the revenue received by the Government from it.

I have to say that is absolutely incredible. The cost of implementing the superannuation tax collection system could exceed the revenue the government receives from it. Why? Because of the deficiencies and complexities of the legislation, according to Mr Davis, who is an expert in superannuation law.

What the government clearly does not care about is that, as superannuation funds pass on these added collection costs to fund members by increasing fees and charges, those increases will disproportionately affect low and middle income earners. In other words, government claims that this is a tax on higher income earners—those earning over $70,000 per annum—are false. Lower and middle income earners will be paying higher fees and charges in order that the government can collect it. So much for the government's claims in its budget boasts last year that it was attacking the top end of town.

Another bungle is the revelation that up to one million lower and middle income earners would have to pay the tax, as supported by evidence to the Senate superannuation committee. Mr Peter Downes, from Jacques Martin, advised the committee of the poor success rate that Jacques Martin‐administered superannuation funds have had in obtaining tax file numbers from members. After some three attempts to collect tax file numbers from fund members, Jacques Martin have had only a 23 per cent success rate. That means that thousands of low and middle income earners will pay this tax measure which is supposed to impact on high income earners. With evidence such as this, perhaps Senator Kemp may like to rethink his constant reassurance to the Senate that low and middle income earners need not pay the surcharge. Clearly, many people are not providing their tax file numbers and will be subject to the surcharge tax.

Then there are the actuarial concerns about the guidelines for assessing the tax liabilities of individuals in the defined benefit funds. Some actuaries have already indicated that they will be unable to prepare some individuals' tax liability assessments in time for superannuation funds to meet the government's 15 December deadline for reporting to the Australian Taxation Office.

This was reconfirmed during the Senate committee hearings and is a matter of considerable concern. The government announced back in August last year that the superannuation tax was coming, yet we still have a situation where people in defined benefit funds are unable to know just what the impact of these changes will be on their superannuation entitlements as the 15 December deadline approaches. As we come towards a year and a half after the government first announced these changes, it is simply not good enough that people in these funds are unable to ascertain what their superannuation situation actually will be.

The last bungle is the inequitable tax treatment of golden handshakes, depending on whether they are taken as cash or rolled over. Labor will be moving an amendment on this issue to make it fairer and more consistent.

So that is it—at least 10 original superannuation tax bungles of which this legislation will fix only five, and even that is doubtful. It would be nice to think it would stop there but, with the complexity of these measures, I am not sure that is so. Unfortunately, no amount of fiddling will fix a bad policy, which regrettably appears to have caused a decline in confidence in the entire superannuation system.

Labor has worked hard since 1983 to build Australia's enviable three pillars retirement income system, of which superannuation is a crucial component. Over the period when Labor was in government, there was an enormous change in focus given to superannuation saving as part of the government's retirement income policy objectives. It was Labor which positioned superannuation to make a major contribution towards achieving our national savings objectives over the medium term. We overwhelmingly succeeded in our objective of extending access to superannuation benefits throughout the work force, especially to women and part‐time employees who previously were largely excluded. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of six superannuation bills we are considering here today seeks to amend the superannuation high income earners tax surcharge ahead of the 15 December deadline for reporting by superannuation funds on liabilities. In particular, the bills seek to impose a new taxation regime on the constitutionally protected state funds which refuse to impose the surcharge by taxing the employees themselves. The bills amend various aspects of the tax surcharge law—making it a mind‐numbingly complex piece of legislation, even more complicated and difficult to administer. I wish to remind the Senate that it need not have been this way.

SPEECH.PARA: If the government had accepted the recommendations of the Senate superannuation committee—which were supported, I might say, by virtually all the superannuation, business and worker representatives before the committee—a far more appropriate collection mechanism would have been in place, with the tax being levied on employees through group certificates. Instead, the tax has been levied on the funds, with the funds facing the massive administrative task of tracking down tax file numbers for 16 million account holders to identify just 350,000 or so people who are liable to pay the surcharge. Along the way, the tax collection mechanism has become more and more complicated.

In May, the Democrats agreed somewhat reluctantly to support the government's collection mechanism when it was clear that the government would not move to close the massive tax concession on superannuation with a fairer tax collection mechanism. But we set two clear conditions on our support. First, we said that we wanted to be assured that low and middle income earners would not end up paying the surcharge in error as a result of not being aware that they must provide a tax file number. Second, we sought an assurance from the Treasurer that the government would keep an open mind to reducing administrative problems with the tax as they arose. This legislation we are told by the government represents the results of months of negotiation with industry aimed at making the tax more workable.

Industry was somewhat surprised at this characterisation. Indeed, evidence to the Senate superannuation committee showed that industry regards these bills as adding to compliance costs, making reporting requirements even more onerous and failing to fix glaring anomalies with the existing legislation. The Democrats want to see a workable tax surcharge on high income earners. We want to see a tax which is easily understood, where complicated costs are minimised but where the revenue is still properly protected. We want to ensure that low and middle income earners are not inadvertently caught up in the net of the tax.

Based on the evidence before the committee, I have come to the view that this legislation fails to meet these objectives. I am not convinced that the government has properly negotiated with industry on minimising compliance costs and that this legislation is as simple as it could be.

Let me cite just some of the current problems with the superannuation surcharge legislation: the difficulty of persuading members to provide tax file numbers, with just 23 per cent of members providing them, despite three requests and the possible need for further education measures to minimise the prospect that low income workers might be caught up in the tax surcharge; the costs of collecting information from the large number of people who have exited the superannuation system since August 1996 and the added difficulty of then collecting the tax from them; new requirements in the amending bills were suddenly made retrospective to August 1996; the near impossibility of the maybe 200 available actuaries in Australia completing the work needed on 15,000 defined benefits funds to report to the tax office before 15 December deadline; continuing confusion about the meaning of the requirements in the act itself; and the inconsistent treatment of different superannuation funds in enforcing the government intent that benefits will not be reduced by more than 15 per cent.

Other problems with the legislation include: the difficulties associated with the application of the surcharge to allocated surplus funds, in particular, in its possibly inadvertent extension to accumulation funds; the inconsistent treatment of eligible termination payments as to whether they are paid out or rolled over in application of the surcharge; complexity of reporting requirements to the tax office on trustees beyond what is necessary for operation of the legislation; clarifying who can make payments to offset surcharge debts; unfair treatment where tax surcharge overpayments are made in terms of characterisation as an ETP and payment of interest; possible over taxation of partly invested benefits; underestimation of the difficulties and time delays in obtaining the actuarial reports necessary to implement the legislation, particularly in the absence of practice guidelines from the Institute of Actuaries; and failure by the drafters of the legislation to minimise compliance costs for funds in the collection of the revenue.

These issues were all placed before the Senate superannuation committee. The industry has raised other issues with me, and no doubt with other members of the committee since that time. I wish to emphasise that the Democrats do support the superannuation tax surcharge. As I understand, the opposition does too. But let us do everything we can to make this tax work effectively. I was prepared to give the government time to properly address these issues but the Democrats cannot support this package of amendments without these very important issues being dealt with.

Industry estimates the costs of complying with this legislation at upwards of $100 million this year. Add on to that the hefty losses many funds incurred in the stock market fall, and we are looking at serious cuts in fund returns this year for all members. I think the Senate would be remiss if it did not do all that it could to improve this legislation.

BREAK.PARA: At the end of the second reading I had intended to move to defer the bill's second reading for two weeks in order to require the government to have another go at amendments to reduce compliance costs. The motion also called on the government to agree to an amendment to extend the deadline for defined benefit funds to 1 March. That, I suggest, would have been a huge relief for the 15,000 defined benefit funds facing the impossibility of reporting by 15 December.

I think we should act to preserve the 15 December reporting date for accumulation funds. But, even there, we should aim to ensure that the reporting requirements are the minimum reasonably necessary to collect the tax, and this review of the more onerous reporting requirements tendered in this legislation will help achieve that.

Both the coalition and the ALP have now indicated that they are opposed to my second reading amendment because of the cut‐in of the native title legislation. So I will not be proceeding with that. However, based on evidence to the Senate committee, I will foreshadow that the Democrats have drawn up a list of 15 areas where we believe that the bills need to be amended. I have given this list to all parties, particularly the government.

I am still awaiting a response from the government to my list, and I would expect to be moving a number of amendments in the committee stage. I will circulate these to senators as soon as they are available and will keep interested senators informed as to the progress of the response from the government. As I said, the Democrats objective is not to obstruct this bill, rather to make it better and more workable. I will return to that topic in some detail during the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my contribution tonight by thanking the superannuation committee secretariat for again preparing a report on very short notice and under such difficult circumstances. I also thank those who took the time to make oral and written submissions to the committee hearings. The committee sought at all times to assist the government with its legislative program, but it really put the committee behind the eight ball. It was so rushed that the majority of the presentations, despite their excellent standard, were purely oral. An attempt was made to get the committee to report even before the Hansard was available so that very complex issues could be read for the first time. It is disappointing to see that the government members on the committee decided to simply go along with the process in what really is a fairly ordinary report on their part.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite some 14 months having passed since the government announced the surcharge tax measure, here we are again debating another piece of legislation on this shambles of a measure before we are able to have any true understanding of the implications. I describe this measure as a shambles because of the way in which the government has chosen to implement it.

When Labor referred these bills to the superannuation committee for public hearings, we were not sure what type of response we would get. There was a concern that people were so fed up with the measure that they could not be bothered going to the trouble and expense of preparing submissions and showing up for the hearings—particularly when it was clear that the government is not listening to what the industry or anybody else is saying. As Noel Davis, a partner and superannuation lawyer with Clayton Utz, said to the committee:

You, at your end, have not seen this, but the arrogance of the government in its responses or its lack of responses to people who have put a great deal of time and effort into putting forward genuine submissions as to what the problems are, and were, with this act, and the arrogance with which those submissions have been dealt with, had to be seen to be believed.

But, on the contrary, with just two days notice, we had some excellent presentations from industry representatives and individuals who showed that the fire is still in the belly on the super tax measure. The government should be on notice. They are a laughing stock over this issue.

The evidence presented to the committee was highly critical of the surcharge tax collection method chosen by the government. Further evidence from Mr Davis was particularly scathing. Senator Cook has already alluded to it, but it is so scathing that it is worth putting it on the record a second time. Mr Davis said:
In my 20-odd years of practice in this area, this is by far the worst legislation that I have seen . . . It is bad legislation and it was enacted purely out of political expediency.

We all know what the political expediency is that Mr Davis is referring to—a broken election promise by the coalition not to increase any existing taxes or introduce any new taxes. But—and this is why this measure is such a shambles—the government tried to sneak this new tax past the people of Australia by calling it a surcharge and using what must be the most complicated collection method in taxation history.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! Rubbish!
—You go out and talk to anybody involved, Senator Heffernan. You are a laughing stock on this issue.
—Not as funny as your bow tie.

—It is funnier than my bow tie. Perhaps the worst aspect of this government's persistence with the complex collection method it has chosen is that it will unfairly affect low and middle income earners, who will pay for the collection of the surcharge tax in higher administration costs and will pay the surcharge tax itself if they do not provide their tax file numbers to their superannuation funds.

BREAK.PARA: The committee heard evidence from Jacques Martin of the poor success rate that Jacques Martin administered superannuation funds have had in obtaining tax file numbers from members. After some three attempts to collect tax file numbers from fund members, Jacques Martin have had only a 23 per cent success rate. That means that thousands of low and middle income earners will pay this tax measure which is supposed to impact only on high income earners.

With evidence such as this, the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) might like to rethink his constant reassurance to the Senate that low and middle income earners need not pay the surcharge if they provide their tax file number. Clearly, many people are not providing their tax file numbers and will be subject to the surcharge tax.

The government clearly expressed an urgency in seeing these amendment bills passed by the parliament. To assist the government, Labor agreed to allow these amendment bills to be introduced and debated in one sitting session and also agreed to a very tight time frame for the committee to conduct hearings and report to the Senate. However, Labor believes that the parliament should have a reasonable opportunity to scrutinise the bills and recommend appropriate amendments, if necessary. The government's objection to allow a reasonable time for the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation to examine these complex bills and report to the Senate undermines the role of the parliament.

Other issues which Labor raises in the report—which have got no answers yet from the government—include the following points. First, the application of the surcharge tax to individuals in constitutionally protected schemes rather than superannuation funds undermines the government's argument for using the complex surcharge tax collection method in the first instance. Why then is the government persisting with this complex method when it has undermined its own argument for having it in the first place?

Second, there was a lack of detailed responses to the questions raised by witnesses from government officials who attended the committee hearings. Unfortunately, I had to leave before we got to that section, but I am told it was a debacle. I am told that the government and the officials were not able to answer simple questions. It was a debacle.

Third, there is evidence that, even with these amendments, the surcharge tax will not apply to defined benefit schemes because of an absence of an actuarial standard for calculating notional surcharge contributions. Fourth, there was evidence presented by ASFA that these amendment bills add to the complexity of the surcharge tax measure and will lead to further confusion within the industry and amongst those who pay the surcharge tax. This was supported by evidence from Mr Peter Downes of Jacques Martin, who said:
It is the most complex and inefficient series of legislation that has been introduced into the parliament in my time of examining Commonwealth legislation since 1969.
That is almost back to when I was born.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on!
—Really. It is that bad, Senator Hogg.

BREAK.PARA: Fifth, there was concern that many funds will not meet the 15 December deadline for reporting to the tax office because there are not enough actuaries in Australia to deal with the complex calculations needed for notional contribution factors. Sixth, several inconsistencies which exist include the application of, and payment of, the surcharge tax liability. Seventh, there was evidence from Mr Davis which was highly critical of the definition of `allocated surplus amount'. On the complex definition, he stated:
It may as well be written in Russian. It is rubbish!

Eighth, there is concern that it could be a double tax on fund members. Ninth—and this is really pernicious—the inconsistent treatment of golden handshakes for surcharge purposes, depending on whether they are taken as cash or rolled over, is inequitable, has the potential to severely damage the superannuation system and is contrary to the government's retirement incomes policy. And they are not all of the problems associated with these bills.

This is a mess that the government has created for itself. It is up to the government to fix it. We have provided ample opportunity to do this and would welcome a further review of this measure if the government is serious about cleaning this shambles up.
Finally, I would like to return to that question of rollovers. I draw senators' attention to Anne Lampe's article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Wednesday, 12 November. She says:

When the Treasurer announced the surcharge in the August Budget last year, he assured everyone that different treatment would be given to eligible termination payments (ETPs) that resulted from lengthy service. He said a five-year phase-in period would apply and the introduction on these payments would be staggered.
However, when the Contributions Tax Act was introduced last June, this principle was adopted in respect of cashed-in ETPs, but not for payments that were rolled over.
There have been no explanations forthcoming from the Government.

This is contrary to the entire thrust of the superannuation policies being pursued, supposedly, by both the government and us. What we have set out to do is encourage people not to take the lump sums but to, in actual fact, take annuities and rollovers. That is the thrust of what we have been trying to do, yet we have set up a piece of legislation here—against the word of the Treasurer (Mr Costello)—that does the exact opposite, and that has affected many people.
Mr Bruce Harris said before the committee:

Had I cashed this same amount of money in, my tax incidence because of the surcharge would have been almost nothing, because I would have had very little service after 20 August and I happened to have quite a lot of service before then, so the proportion would be very small.

He is now going to be hit because the Treasurer has welshed on his word, his press release. That is why this bill is a disgrace and a shambles. I urge senators to congratulate Senator Heffernan on his bow tie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not wearing a bow tie tonight.
—Shame!

—It is a shame. I believe the introduction of this package of superannuation surcharge bills is problematic at this time. While the bills will almost certainly pass in some form before the end of the year, the process of their passage is indicative of several serious problems. We are told these bills are urgent. Perhaps passage of them by the end of the year is essential to maintain a level of equity, but urgency is a result of management by crisis and the whole combination of ad hoc approach and bullying that has characterised this government.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue is compelling. Obviously, having imposed a surcharge on the general public, it would be self-serving and a flagrant disregard for equity to exempt MPs and judges and other members of constitutionally protected state and federal schemes. Unfortunately, most of these schemes are exactly the schemes, the defined benefits schemes, where the legislation fails so dismally to work well or fairly. What is being applied to these people, who certainly should not be exempt from the tax, is the very worst and least workable aspect of a bad scheme. There are other outstanding issues such as the collection mechanism and the situation for those who have not given their tax file number, TFN.

Why have these bills taken so long to draft if the same unworkable aspects which applied to the main package of bills are also used here? The major difficulties with the defined benefits schemes have not been resolved. The difficulties with the collection mechanism have not been resolved. What took so long? Why were these bills not introduced months ago?

BREAK.PARA: These bills were introduced in the House on 2 October—about a month ago. They were introduced here on 22 October and the Senate referred the bills to a committee on 23 October. The committee has had a short hearing and presented its report on the bills prior to the reporting date of 17 November. It is now the 18th and we are debating the bills.

I have nothing against haste, but I believe the situation in which complex legislation is considered with minimal time for consultation and amendment is not conducive to good legislation. I believe this is a complex area and that the time has been minimal and the pressure considerable. Given what I see in the legislation, I cannot understand why it was not introduced in the House during the last session and in the Senate early this session. I have heard this was to allow consultation and changes. Given the limited number of essential changes in these bills, I cannot see why it took so long.
The 27th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation seems to confirm this. On page 4 there is a list of issues still of concern. Paragraph 21 says:
Witnesses who gave evidence on the provisions of the bills concentrated on several key areas. These were as follows:
. the mounting volume of the legislation and difficulties of comprehension;
. industry's ability to meet the December 15 reporting deadline;
. delays in provision of final guidelines, making compliance difficult;
. expanded reporting requirements;
. practicality of applying the surcharge to defined benefits schemes;
. differences in the application of the 15 per cent cap on surcharge liabilities on members of constitutionally protected schemes, commonwealth schemes and private sector schemes;
. application of the surcharge to investment earnings within accumulation schemes through taxation of surplus allocation amounts;
. possible retrospective application of the surcharge to taxation of surplus allocation amounts;
. possible difficulties with the definition of "allocated surplus amounts" in the bills; and
. effect of surcharging "notional contributions" where benefits are not fully vested.
Paragraph 22 indicates:
Private sector witnesses also gave evidence of a more general nature about the operation of the surcharge. Points argued by witnesses included:
. complexity of the legislation—
and, of course, that links in with the first concern of the other witnesses in paragraph 21—
. compliance and administration costs;
. incidental application of surcharge administration costs to moderate income earners;
. low response rates to requests for tax file numbers and consequent application of the surcharge to non‐target groups;
. application of the surcharge to the full amount of rolled over termination payments regardless of service period;
. the different treatment of ETPs taken as cash; and
. application of the surcharge to death and disablement superannuation policies.

I imagine that these might be amongst the 15 items that Senator Allison mentioned she may have included in her list to the government for answers. The government report suggested that these issues were raised and satisfied when the main surcharge tax package went through. Obviously, the government had the numbers then, but the issues were not satisfied. The appearance of virtually the same issues from the public indicates that they were not satisfied and that they are still of concern.

A fundamental concern is that this legislation, which is touted as a mechanism to tax the rich and upper middle class, will affect people not in those classes. There are two sides to this. The first is that it will affect the people who do not have their tax file numbers listed. It is true that the Senate passed an amendment that will exempt those with less than $2,000 in contributions to superannuation. But $2,000 is less than six per cent of the September figure for the average weekly ordinary time earnings, or AWOTE, for full‐time adult workers.

The stated intention of this bill is to catch out those on incomes of over $70,000 per year. Their compulsory employer superannuation contribution is more like $4,200. Basically, anyone from that point down to slightly below the average weekly income will be hit with this tax if the superannuation funds do not have a tax file number. In what sense is this fair or fulfilling the government's intention?

This is of particular concern because the number of members for whom superannuation funds have been able to get tax file numbers, as has been mentioned, is around 25 per cent. Three‐quarters of people have not given them and three‐quarters of members will be subject to potential tax. This highlights a second problem with the legislation.

Part of the problem is that superannuation funds are not set up to pay income based taxes in respect of members' incomes. It is not their normal activity and it requires a fair bit of administration. On the other hand, employers normally do pay such taxes, normally do know employee incomes and normally do have the tax file numbers. They also make the superannuation contributions and know how much they are.

We have created a situation where superannuation funds have to take on the role of employers in terms of tax file numbers and payment of tax to the Australian Taxation Office. They need to take on the role of the members in terms of presenting and paying tax based on all income sources and take on the role of the Australian Taxation Office in terms of tracking down members and ensuring that all relevant information is submitted. That is a lot of work. There is no way the government can deny that there is a substantial compliance burden placed unnecessarily on the superannuation funds.

On the other hand, it would be relatively easy for the employer, who knows the income the employee gets and the superannuation contribution being made on their behalf, to do a deduction and send it to the tax office along the same route as the PAYE payments. As with variables such as dependants, HECS debts and so on, a simple notification by an employee if income is over $70,000 would be enough to allow deductions to be made. It could be relatively automated as part of the pay cheque. The mechanism already substantially exists. I suppose this would be too simple for the government—the kind of government that brings back into the Senate, unnecessarily, three times, the legislation on alcohol tax, just to satisfy Carlton and United Breweries and waste the Senate's time. No, it would be too simple.

This would have three advantages other than administration. The first would be that the money comes out of income rather than out of savings. This increases savings and decreases consumption by those who can best afford to decrease it—those making over $70,000 in income per annum. The second is that it reduces compliance costs for superannuation funds. By reducing administration costs, it reduces costs and increases the benefits to members. This also increases savings. The third factor is that, by making the payment effectively part of PAYE, workers know whether or not they are being taxed and at what rate. There are few people making under $70,000 who would be taxed under punitive tax file number provisions without knowing it and taking action in that case.

If the issue of a second job arises, it is really not different from the issue that currently applies because, under PAYE, employees pay part of their income as tax, on the assumption that the rates applying on that income are the rates they should be paying. I think there are options to vary that rate, if they wish, by declaring extra income to at least one employer. On the other hand, they may wish to pay at a lower rate, knowing that they will be assessed and will have to pay the Australian Taxation Office a lump payment. This would equally apply in relation to the extra superannuation tax.

Everyone making a reasonable income is obliged to fill in an accurate tax form with a tax file number anyway. It could be their responsibility to pay the additional tax if they do not declare an income of over $70,000 to an employer. It could be their responsibility to pay their assessable tax if they do not have an employer. Generally, a person making over $70,000 without an employer has an accountant and a tax agent. We are a country with a very large percentage of tax agents because we are a country with a very complex tax system.

I do not think it would be too huge a compliance cost. In that case, if they are not making PAYE payments, in most cases they are already somehow budgeting for tax. In other words, there are mechanisms already in place to allow the collection of this tax through standard taxation channels without imposing significant compliance costs, and without problems of targeting and taxing people who are not intended to be taxed at a higher rate.

The reason these were not used is simple: the government did not want to use standard tax channels because they wanted to preserve the pretence that it is not a tax. However, now that it is clearly stated as a tax, why can't we use the far simpler tax mechanisms already in place? This would go a long way to resolve the issue of taxing those below the threshold and reducing the burden and cost on superannuation funds.

Remember the burden and cost we put on people by trying to organise the family allowance through the Taxation Office—unnecessarily—because the government wanted it to look like something else? The same thing, in reverse, is happening in this instance. Obviously, this seems to be something of a mess.

It might be worth while getting amendments, but I believe that the government will not be accepting any Senate amendments. It is blind bull‐headedness of the sort we saw on the excise legislation recently that I mentioned in relation to the drinks tax, where the Senate amended a bill in a way consistent with the government's own committee recommendations. The government excuse for not accepting the amendments was not that something was wrong with them but that the government was treating the bill as a trivial, technical amendment, not intended to address the problem, and the whole issue could be addressed when the Treasurer (Mr Costello) comes out with Fightback mark II—I mean a comprehensive review of taxation to discover that we really need a GST and that there is only one solution.

I suppose that the superannuation industry will have to wear this until then, and probably afterwards, because it has nothing whatsoever to do with a GST. It is ironic that this government is causing its own unnecessary complexities and then goes to the public and says, `We have an unduly complex tax system and we have to have a simpler one. Wouldn't that be terrific?'

As has been highlighted by non‐government members of the committee that reviewed this issue, the government's solution to the inability to apply federal revenue measures to state government schemes is to tax the employee. It is obviously not that difficult; in many ways it is far more straightforward than the government's scheme of collection through superannuation funds. The government argument is as weak as dishwater. It is simply that it decided to do it the way it is doing it—messily and badly—and will continue to it that way—so there!

The other major issue here is the ongoing saga of the defined benefit schemes. On the basis of concerns presented to the committee, there seems to be no real effective measure to incorporate them into the overall superannuation treatment. These schemes are not marginal schemes, but cover very large numbers of workers in the federal and state public sectors.

The major issue is that there are up to three interacting variables in calculating what a person owes. First there is the calculation of what a person is getting as superannuation contribution. This affects their calculation of total income, which then affects the rate at which they should be taxed under the superannuation surcharge regime. This then affects the estimation of tax liability.

If the calculation of notional employee contribution is off, it throws off not only the income that has been taxed but also the rate of taxation if the person is making between $70,000 and $85,000 per annum. The combination of these two rates act together to throw off the estimate of tax liability further than a change of either variable independently. So any error in calculation will be magnified, either up or down. Perhaps we will just sit and wait to see what happens to the first person who gets prosecuted for one of these errors.

One issue is how it is treated. What happens when someone pays too much? What happens when someone pays too little? Who pays whom interest, and at what rate? It is a very complicated thing and, after all, the taxpayers may not be at fault if they underpay. Perhaps we will get the equivalent of Senator Newman talking about taxpayer fraud or superannuation surcharge fraud—how many people have been thrown off their superannuation for frauding the system. I can just see it now.

The problem is that the answer may not be forthcoming for several years. In defined benefit schemes, the benefits are unknown until retirement. The resulting inaccuracies may have happened and accumulated over 15 years or more, so the issue of interest becomes important. To some extent, this is less important where it is the Commonwealth paying the Commonwealth but, outside of that scheme, other schemes are the parties liable to pay the tax. Those schemes are the ones who will either fight out the interest issue with the Australian Taxation Office, or perhaps simply dock the employee by whatever the Australian Taxation Office says, and maybe it will be the employee who ends up being diddled over time. On the other hand, in this bill we are creating a situation where members of state defined benefit schemes will pay directly. They are, therefore, the liable party.

I do not think this is so simple. I do not believe that it is easy to envisage how it will work and who will be ahead or behind. It is like the situation with workers in defined benefit schemes in relation to when they pay. Would they be better off leaving their money in superannuation and having the tax, with interest, removed at the end? Would they be better off paying as they go, not owing interest and not getting the benefits of leaving the money in superannuation? I do not know. I do not know if anyone has a real handle on it at the moment.

This is a package of bills which will go through in some form soon. It must go through if the government persists with the rest of the scheme. Personally, I think the whole thing is a monumental mistake—and that is a polite word. When we get down to it, this mess is a way to raise taxes. It is a way that was made acceptable by taxing the wealthier part of the community. It was then turned into a monumental mess through trying to create the impression that it was not a tax. No‐one believed that, but the damage was done.

Rather than putting this through as an amendment to the Income Tax Assessment Act and Income Tax (Rates) Act, it was put through as a special tax which was applied and collected through superannuation. As I mentioned before, it is the same attempt at hocus‐pocus used with the family tax initiative, and with the same sort of legislative, messy outcome. I guess we will be dealing with departments which have been stripped of more and more staff but which will have to deal with it and administer it.
We will support these bills because on the issue of whether the richer part of society ought to be paying a contribution we have already put our views on record. But we think the scheme stinks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be confined to the Superannuation Contribution Tax (Members of Constitutionally Protected Superannuation Funds) Assessment and Collection Bill 1997. I will direct my remarks to the definition of a constitutionally protected superannuation fund, set out in clause 37. The bill defines `constitutionally protected superannuation fund' as having:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the same meaning as constitutionally protected fund has in part IX of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

When I read that, I wondered why a constitutionally protected superannuation fund, having the word `superannuation' in it, should be defined as meaning `constitutionally protected fund', and why different expressions are used in this particular bill from those in the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is defined in the Income Tax Assessment Act as follows:
. . . "constitutionally protected fund" means a fund that is declared by the regulations to be a constitutionally protected fund . . .
In the regulations, there is a series of funds nominated. They relate to people such as judges. In the Income Tax Assessment Act itself, as a matter of interest, section 271A says:

BREAK.PARA: Despite any other provision of this Part, income derived by a constitutionally protected fund is exempt from tax.

To follow that through, there is a shift in the words used to describe what in effect is a pension rather than a superannuation fund. For example, judges in the Victorian jurisdiction get a pension, not a superannuation allowance.

In my view, everybody should have superannuation. Some good schemes have been developed to see that that is done, because people should be given security as they get older. As far as judges go, they do not get superannuation; they get a pension. It is a concept that goes back centuries.

A pension for judges is based on the same reasoning that tenure is given to judges. Judges are given tenure and security of income. You do not necessarily have to make them wealthy, but they should have security of tenure and income both during their working life and when they retire, to ensure that they are able to act independently and to make decisions for the community without fear or favour—the same sort of thing we want from the Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives.

It is interesting that this legislation attacks that concept of security of tenure for the sort of people that we want to help us govern the community in a way that is fair, just and according to law. I ask the minister, when he is replying at the end of this debate, to tell us why the government has taken that fairly radical position of attacking a long‐held tradition in the common law field and a strong constitutional principle that has also had a long history.

The idea of tenure was established by the Act of Settlement at the beginning of the 17th century. It has been repeated in the constitution of the United States of America, our own constitution and the Code Napoleon in France. There is a tradition of giving security to the decision makers who are going to decide the way the law is to be applied in the community.

I find it very interesting that that principle should, perhaps inadvertently, be attacked. Of course, judges and others should make their contribution to the income that government needs to run the country, but I am pointing out that an interesting concept is being expressed by this legislation.

The concept being expressed is that they do not get this pension—it is not part of the mechanism of the need to have independence and fairness established—but they are paid as everybody else within the Public Service is paid. So they are looked upon as another arm of the executive government, not an independent arm of government as they ought to be. That concept coming through in this legislation ought to cause some concern for us all. The judiciary is a third arm of government, not a department of the executive arm of government. This definition in this particular bill changes that concept around and does so, I believe, with some danger to the constitutional proprieties by which we live.

It was very interesting to see the insertion of the word `superannuation' in the definition of the concept of the pension that people have been talking about. That word was injected into that concept. The word `superannuation' was inserted in the phrase `a constitutionally protected fund', which is clearly understood—a fund is constitutionally protected because of the need to have independence in the judiciary to ensure that they judge as they ought to judge—and that is a phrase which appears in the tax act. Why that should be done would be an interesting question for the minister to answer in his reply.

I want to add no more at this stage—I know Senator Quirke is about to deliver forth a very penetrating address. I do think that we ought to look with some care at this issue of the encroachment of the executive upon another arm of government by treating it as a department within its survey and taxing, in the way that it does, a pension which is part of that mechanism which is used by the community to ensure that we have fair decisions made for the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I get to the main focus of my address tonight, I want to make a couple of preliminary remarks about what this package of superannuation bills, in effect, is seeking to do. Firstly, it is rather interesting that the government took the view that it did in the 1996 budget that there are a number of superannuation schemes out there that are worthy of being looked at, and a number that really ought to be taxed. In fact, that is what this is—it is taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no great problem with taxation because taxation is the means by which we can deliver a number of outcomes in Australia that we need to. But one point that needs to be made about this is that the populist view that you are taxing the rich is actually not correct in this particular instance. You may well be taxing the rich at the other end of the equation, but you may not be as well. Let me explain that.

What triggers this legislation now is an income of over $70,000 a year. I do not want to get into a great dissertation tonight about how good an income of $70,000 a year is. Obviously it is a fairly reasonable income. But, at the end of the day, it is not the person who is earning $70,000 that is going to be paying the tax today; it is his or her widow or widower at the other end who is going to be paying this tax, because the effect of this is going to be a reduction in the benefit further downstream. Once that pension is crystallised in five, 10, 15 or 20 years time, whatever the terms of that benefit are, that is when it is going to bite in the pocket of the individual.

What that means is this: of the people who are in one of those schemes—and members of parliament are, as are a number of civil servants around the country and a number of state parliamentarians—there are a number who will go on to achieve very large incomes indeed. A number of these people will, through the pension system, achieve a pension as great as the income they are currently getting. There are a number that will not quite get that far for all sorts of reasons—they do not have government service, they do not have extra service or they have minimum parliamentary or judicial service, which means that at the end of the day the pension that will be paid to those persons, or paid to their partner through death or disability, will be considerably less than that.

I want to put on the record that there are a large number of backbenchers, even in this place, on both sides, whose widows or widowers—if those backbenchers are forced into involuntary retirement of one kind or another within the parameters of the superannuation scheme that is in effect in this place—who might have to look after children, will get, as a pension, the average male weekly wage which will now be slugged. Previously, they would have received a higher income.

In my view, this is against all the ways in which taxation principles ought to apply. If it is necessary, it ought to apply at the point where the income is on or well over the $70,000. That is the equitable way in which it should apply. I would also venture the opinion that it might be an easier way to address this problem, because these bills are enormously complicated. The one thing I have found when I have gone into them is just how complicated they are. My address tonight is not to propose justice for backbenchers and all the rest of it, because I am one. At the end of the day, it is to concentrate on one particular aspect of the first bill here tonight.

What was put to me about a week ago, when this proposal first surfaced around Australia for the Senate to look at, was that there was going to be specialist treatment for federal public servants, federal politicians and federal judges. I will explain how it was suggested it might work. I was told that there was a serious deficiency in section 15(6) of the first bill before our consideration tonight. I was told that the aforementioned persons—namely, those protected by various other sections of these acts, such as the Commonwealth participants—would only bear the impact of this surcharge from 20 August 1996, which I understand was budget night when the Treasurer (Mr Costello) made this pronouncement.

I have no argument with that; it is fine. The government was elected to govern, and the government got up and made those statements. I suggest that a few people opposite really ought to be looking at some of these things in more detail, but it is up to them how they want to deal with them. However, I was also told that people who are caught by this legislation in some of the other states—namely, state politicians and state public servants in defined benefit schemes as well as accumulation schemes—will pay before 20 August 1996.

I am told by very good authorities that section 15 is so deficient that it will be retrospective not back to budget night in 1996 but to the first day that these people started work. This may sound bizarre, but I have not yet found anyone who has refuted this, and I have taken it around to a number of people. I understand that there were a few committee hearings on this before I came into this place. There were a number of individuals who said that that would be one of the outcomes of this piece of legislation.

I want to make this crystal clear: when it comes to the consideration in detail stage, I am going to be seeking some assurances that this is not so. This bill should be correctly drafted so that everybody in this country, at least on this level, will be treated fairly. In fact, the surcharge should start on 20 August 1996 if you are a federal politician, a state politician, a federal judge, a state judge or if you are in one of those state schemes. Certainly I know that they are in place in South Australia. I am talking about the defined benefits scheme for public servants as it was until 1985 in South Australia. At least when I was the shadow Treasurer three years ago and we had to deal with it, there were still 10,500 persons in that scheme in South Australia.

It also has an impact on the accumulation schemes. I understand that the actuaries do not mind the accumulation schemes because you can work them out much more easily than you can a defined pension at the other end. I want to be assured—if I do not get this assurance from the minister at the end of the second reading stage, I am going to be seeking it during the consideration in detail stage—that state politicians, state judges and state public servants who have gone into a defined benefits scheme will not be liable for this surcharge before 20 August 1996. If they were liable, I have been assured that the South Australian government would proceed to constitutionally challenge this act.

I have been told that during this debate tonight I can make that crystal clear. State treasury officials there have assured me that in no way are they going to see people under their jurisdiction treated much more adversely than here at the Commonwealth level. They have assured me that if this bill goes through as it is, with proposed section 15(6) not having the necessary protections for every person in a constitutionally protected scheme so that they will not be treated any differently from people who may sit around in here, there will be a challenge to that act to ensure that that is the outcome at the other end.

I do not know what the government intends to do about this. I have had a close look at proposed section 15(6). It is my view as well that those protections are not there for all persons in constitutionally protected schemes. I have no doubt, looking at the rest of the legislation, that the protections are there for us. I have no doubt that the protections are there for Commonwealth public servants. I have no doubt that the protections are there for all the people in the act who need those protections and were guaranteed them as a result of budget night 1996. But I cannot see the same mention anywhere else in the act that will protect the interests of those persons who are in constitutionally protected schemes in the states, be they in state legislatures or the state Public Service or be they members of the various police force schemes around the place. There are a number of police officers whose income triggers at $70,000 as well. There are a lot at the commissioned officer level who will be impacted by these changes.

I do not want to take too much of the Senate's time tonight. I know that a couple of my other colleagues—at least one—want to join in this debate. I just want to get on the record now that I am going to be looking very closely at what the minister says when he sums all this up. If the case, as it has been put to me, is that provided you are around here you are looked after and if you are not then you are not looked after, then that is a matter we will take into the committee stage.

I certainly have been talking to some of my colleagues on this side about this and some of them will testify, too. I have talked to some of the government senators about this as well. I have indicated that in my view section 15, and in particular 15(6), needs to have explicit protections put in so that least everybody can see that the government is serious; and so that it will not in many instances retrospectively bring in these measures well before 20 August 1996. It is possible that some persons, in fact, could be taxed for the 20 or 27 years. When we get to the committee stage I will go into detail of how this affects certain people that I know who are in these schemes and what impact it will have on them when they crystallise those schemes and go onto the pension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree fully with the sentiments put forward by my colleague, Senator Quirke. I rise in this debate this evening for a number reasons. I am primarily concerned with the effect that this legislation is going to have on a number of low income and middle income earners. I refer to an unintended consequence, obviously, of the legislation, but one which seems to be gathering momentum and getting quite away from the government. Of course, the government does not seem to be prepared to take any counsel on this issue whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me, from the evidence that we heard at the hearing of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on 28 October, that there are substantial numbers of people who are yet to supply their tax file number. Jacques Martin—and I am not going to say they are necessarily the benchmark—gave evidence that after three attempts they had secured something like only a 23 per cent response on tax file numbers. I am aware of other industry funds which have a higher return rate but, nonetheless, there is still a substantially large number of people who have not complied, either out of ignorance or because they just do not understand the consequence of not supplying their tax file number. Of course, at some stage down the track, they will face the consequences of this legislation, which is a tax bill.

Who will be predominantly affected? It will not be those people who have been able to rearrange their incomes or those who have been able to repackage their packages. It will be those who are invariably low and middle income earners, who are PAYE taxpayers. Many of them will be ascribed as the battlers. They will be the people who cop the tax bill at the end of the day.

In particular I want to refer to the issue of workability, which is covered in the report of the Labor senators in the 27th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. This really sums up the mess that the government is in. In the report we deal with an issue which specifically relates to defined benefit funds—that is, the taxing of the notional surchargeable contributions. This is the real problem with the defined benefits scheme. I thought the evidence of Mr Davis, in particular, before the Senate select committee was very telling of the government. A number of quotes from the evidence given by Mr Davis at that hearing really sum up the mess. He said:
. . . the government asked the Institute of Actuaries to adopt an actuarial practice that would apply in Australia in calculating the notional surchargeable contribution . . .
He goes on to say:
The Institute of Actuaries, after looking at the issue, resolved that it could not adopt an actuarial practice to apply to this, because it was too difficult to try to do so.
This is in spite of some discussion that we had with officers at the end of the hearing. It is not resolved in my view. He goes on to say:
The government actuary—
and he referred specifically to the government actuary—
undeterred by that, prepared a document which gives his view of how a notional surchargeable contribution factor can be calculated.

One can only assume that as a partner in Clayton Utz and a legal person, as I understand it, Mr Davis has a fair degree of expertise in this area. Whilst there may be another expert view, the point that he has put forward is that the government actuary, undeterred by the view of the Institute of Actuaries, has put forward a view which he clearly disagrees with and, as I understand, other elements of the superannuation community also disagree with. He goes on in his evidence to say, and I am not going to read it all:

BREAK.PARA: . . . an act of parliament that will apply to funds that make up half of the assets in superannuation, and which is unworkable because there will be no actuarial practice.

So his view of the legislation is that there cannot be and will not be an actuarial practice, in spite of the government actuary having taken their own view of how to levy the notional surchargeable contribution factor. He goes on to say:

The government actuary's view of how the notional contributions factor should be calculated is one actuary's view. It does not constitute actuarial practice, and no other actuary will be required to take any note of it in attempting to calculate it. An actuary, therefore, who seeks my advice on this will be told, `You can't calculate that. The act requires you to calculate it in accordance with actuarial practice. You cannot do it. If you were to attempt to do so and caused trustees to pay tax that they wouldn't otherwise have to pay, that would be negligence.
And he goes on to say at the end that it is putting in place a regime that will be unworkable in relation to defined benefit funds.

That is most damning and it is something that the government have seriously got to address. They just cannot come in and impose the government actuary's view. There must be something of greater substance than that; otherwise I believe that this matter will go on completely unresolved and will end up the subject of major litigation. I think that that will be very much to the detriment of the superannuation industry. It will eat into the funds that should otherwise go towards people's retirement benefits.

Having briefly had a look at that issue, I want to take a look at another issue that came up in the hearing. Whilst one might say that it is not the subject of this piece of legislation, I believe that the government should reasonably make it part of this legislation. That is the issue of timing as addressed in the Labor senators' report.

The evidence to the committee on 28 October was that the reporting of member contributions should be put out to a date beyond 15 December. Whilst the response of the government was that the funds could seek an extension from the Australian Taxation Office, which of itself seems quite reasonable, what I cannot understand is that this will lead to a multiplicity of such extensions being sought.

If we are going to have duplication, surely one of the things that would be sensible and logical to do would be for the government to amend its existing legislation and put that date out beyond 15 December. The evidence to the committee clearly indicated that that was necessary. I cannot recall which group it was that gave evidence that two‐thirds of their corporate schemes use a package called Superb 2000. Apparently, the Superb 2000 software will not be modified in time to meet the 15 December deadline.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jacques Martin.

—That is right. It was Jacques Martin. So, whilst it may be nice for some of the government departments to be in a preferred position whereby they will meet the 15 December deadline, the clear impression that was created at the hearing was that there would be at least a substantial number of extensions being sought to that 15 December reporting deadline. It just makes good ordinary commonsense for the government—not to eat humble pie, not to backtrack, but purely and simply—to extend the date of reporting. I do not think that is in any way going to disadvantage the government and its expected tax collections as a result of the surcharge measure that is in place.

BREAK.PARA: The other issue has been addressed by my colleague who spoke before me, and that is the issue of the government needing to be consistent—consistent in the way the tax is applied. My colleague referred to some people being disadvantaged by the date of 20 August last year. It seems to me that the government must make it beyond doubt that no‐one is going to be disadvantaged or taxed differently as a result of this legislation.

We heard evidence that the 15 per cent cap on the surcharge tax for the members of Commonwealth schemes and constitutionally protected schemes should apply to all, and that seems reasonable. We heard that there was a definition of the 15 per cent cap applying to Commonwealth members after 20 August. If that applies to those people then I am saying that it should apply to those consti tutionally protected and other defined benefit schemes as well.

Another recommendation in the Labor senators' report related to the question of the options for payment for defined benefit schemes—that is, the rules about letting it accrue yearly or paying it as it falls due need to be applied consistently. As I understand the legislation, that will not necessarily be the case at all.

Last but not least, I want to briefly address the issue of the allocated surplus amounts. Again, I turn to the evidence of Mr Davis. He seemed very convincing in the evidence that he put before the committee. Where there are surplus amounts in superannuation funds which are to be allocated then those will be the subject of the tax. That appears, as I understand it, to be quite unfair. As is said in our report, it will end up being a double tax. This will of course apply to accumulation funds. At page 25 of Hansard of the hearing on 28 October, Mr Davis states:

. . . accumulation funds that have never needed the services of an actuary are going to have to incur the expense of obtaining an actuarial report on what is the taxable allocated surplus amount for members of the accumulation fund.

Many of those surpluses are there for the bad times and it seems to me that the double taxation of those funds is quite improper indeed. I will go on to what I believe to be the government's position in a few moments. Mr Davis in his evidence then goes on to say that there is a:
. . . requirement that the actuary `determine the taxable amount having regard to actuarial practice'. Of course, there is no actuarial practice.
This seems to be the common fault that we are finding—that there is no actuarial practice. He goes on to say:

It imposes a new requirement for an expense for an actuary that has never been a requirement before. It requires a calculation to be done in accordance with actuarial practice that doesn't exist, and which there is no intention of bringing into existence.

Having said that, the issue was raised not only by Mr Davis from Clayton Utz but also by Coopers and Lybrand. As I understand it, the government did answer the issues raised by Coopers and Lybrand at the back of the report. In respect of the issue of the definition of an allocated surplus amount in the act and the taxing of that, at page 3 of appendix F at the back of the 27th Report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation , the response from the government is:
The Commissioner of Taxation, in conjunction with the Australian Government Actuary, proposes to issue a ruling outlining the circumstances in which an allocated surplus amount will arise.
