There is no such ruling at this stage. It is an unknown quantity for the superannuation industry and that is putting people on a promise. The response continues:
A fund will only have to seek an opinion from an eligible actuary if they come within those circumstances.
Whilst this is a response, it is a very nebulous response. It does not in any way define the circumstances. It goes on to say:
The Ruling will also provide details about the calculation of the allocated surplus amounts.

So, when one takes that response and the evidence of Mr Davis, there is a wide gap indeed—a gap, unfortunately, which the government cannot bridge at this stage. Just on those scores alone, the government legislation is failing very much.

So I would put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson, that the government has a lot of work to do if it is going to have a piece of legislation that is understandable and workable in the first instance, let alone having any regard to how well it is either received or, most likely, not received out there in the broader world.

I will finish on a note which I think sums up the mess that the government is in with this piece of legislation. It comes again from Mr Peter Downes, Manager Government Business, Jacques Martin, when he was before the Senate select committee on 28 October. He said:

At the moment we have some 20 centimetres of 12 acts and regulations, explanatory material, second reading speeches. It is an incredible body of legislation and it is extremely complex. It is the most complex and inefficient series of legislation that has been introduced into the parliament in my time of examining Commonwealth legislation since 1969.

I think that really sums it up, really gets to the heart of the problem. The fact is the government started down the road of a surcharge. It has now come to a screaming halt in terms of the defined benefit schemes. The industry, of course, are asking the government to stop, hold everything, look at it with the industry and come up with a sensible result so that, at the end of the day, even though they might not like it, at least there will be something that is workable, something that is understandable for them. But, left in its current form, it is an absolute mess, and the government needs to take a very close look at this piece of legislation before we get into the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to make a contribution to the debate on this package of superannuation bills which seek to complement and extend the existing legislation that provides for a contribution tax on high income earners. I do not wish to traverse all the ground that my colleagues have because senators, like Senator Hogg, have done a good job of reflecting the concern within the industry and within the community at the shambles that has become the superannuation contributions tax for high income earners. It is an issue that the government really must address seriously rather than try to bulldoze its way through, as it is currently trying to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The government continues to repeat the mantra that this is fair legislation, that the opposition is merely from vested interest groups and that it will all be okay. I am sure the officers who have had to live with this for over a year now will testify that there are genuine and serious concerns with the government's approach on this issue.

It is obviously the case that like a good political idea—a 15 per cent surcharge, as the government liked to call it—it is now legislatively called a tax on high income earners in the context of the budget. It was something that they thought that both the community and the opposition parties would have difficulty in opposing because, since the days of Robin Hood, taxing the rich has been a popular sort of cry and it has immediate and on face value appeal.

The reality is that somebody then got the job of trying to implement what was a very simple idea, and it has not proved to be simple to implement and it has not been capable of being implemented in a fair and equitable manner. I do not want to labour the politics of this. We have been uphill and down dale over this for some time now. It is important though that the government try to come to terms with fixing the problem.

The opposition parties are in an unenviable position. Our problem with these bills is that we are confronted with a situation where these bills seek to extend the contributions tax for high income earners to those funds that were not covered by the first set of bills. So, in equity terms, one is inclined to say that one ought to support the extension of the contributions tax to those funds so that all high income earners with superannuation are taxed at the same rate and are caught by this legislation.

The difficulty with that is that we are also being asked to extend what is clearly bad, inappropriate, imprecise, complex and expensive legislation to a whole new range of people. So you are caught between the desire to treat everyone equitably and the prospect of extending, even further, legislation that is clearly bad legislation. I guess that is something we in the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens will have to grapple with. I know the Democrats in the Senate select committee report recommended that the government look to go back to industry and consult again. The Labor Party has also advised that we really take a serious look at alternative mechanisms to make sure we can do it better. I do not think it is beyond the wit of the superannuation industry and the government to do it better. Certainly, a range of submissions to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation suggested alternative approaches which meet the government's policy and revenue goals but which provide a much more efficient, fair and less complex collection mechanism.

As I said, I do not want to labour the politics but it does seem to me that the government should seriously reconsider its position in relation to this matter. They will have to reconsider it down the track in any event when the difficulties with the legislation continue to emerge.

Despite the earlier bills having been passed some time ago now, the industry continued to express serious concerns and disquiet about the legislation. During the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation inquiry into this package of bills, the government expressed the view that it was the same old critics continuing to harp on. What that reflects is that the industry's view was not merely a political one—as the minister tries to paint it—but that there are serious and deep-seated concerns and criticisms and those concerns and criticisms continue. Nothing in the experience since the passage of the first set of bills has allayed those concerns.

A range of those matters were raised with the committee again in this inquiry into this package of bills and they go to questions, including as my colleagues have said, the difficulty of tax file number collection. A witness from Jacques Martin indicated that, despite two or three attempts to collect tax file numbers, they still had only a 23 per cent success rate. Even if theirs is a peculiar experience and not reflective of the general industry and other schemes do better—whatever caveats you want to put on it—the reality is that that means, on anyone's assessment, a significant number of low and middle income earners will not provide their tax file numbers to their superannuation fund. That means this will not be a tax on the rich; it will be a tax on those persons who fail to provide their tax file number. It is not, as the government says, a tax on the rich. It will be a tax on ordinary wage and salary earners on a low or middle income within Australia. So one of the principal arguments for this set of bills is defeated by the fact it is not confined to the target group as the government claims.

The Labor senators and the Democrats senator, Senator Allison, dealt with a lot of these concerns in the committee's report. I do not wish to canvass them all tonight but I do have particular concerns about the treatment of allocated surplus amounts. It appears to me from the evidence we heard that the impact of the government's current legislation is to double tax those allocated surplus amounts. Those funds play an important part in evening out the returns paid to superannuation fund members. They are an important mechanism for ensuring that superannuation fund members about to retire are protected from the vagaries of sharp movements in the market from time to time. Anything that seeks to penalise those funds that operate allocated surplus amounts should be of concern to this parliament and the government. I think the government ought to have another look at the proposed tax treatment of those surplus amounts. I am not assured by the government's evidence and I certainly will be pursuing the minister in the committee stages on that issue.

The other issue I wanted to raise briefly was the impact of this legislation on golden handshakes. It seems to provide a taxation advantage to those people who take a superannuation payment in cash rather than roll it over. Given the history of the development of superannuation in this country, any measure which effectively favours in the tax treatment cashing out superannuation rather than rolling it over is a retrograde step and is not consistent even with the government's own stated objectives and principles in relation to superannuation.

So there are a range of issues like that which are covered in the report but which I do not want to labour now. A lot of the issues stem from the basic internal inconsistencies in the government's approach. We now have some funds being taxed whereas in other funds we are seeking to tax the member. The whole thing has become such a shemozzle that very few people in this country understand it. Certainly, the average member of a superannuation fund will have no chance of understanding the principles at stake, how things operate or whether they are being treated fairly.

As a senator who has served on this committee for a number of years now, I find each time I come to the issue I have to go over the reading to try to re‐acquaint myself with the issue to get a grip on some of the complex issues that are involved. Some would say that I do not do that very well, and I am prepared to accept that criticism because you would have to be a practitioner dealing with it daily to get your head around some of the issues. I think that is a problem in terms of this legislation.

The fact that the industry is so disquieted by this taxation measure really ought to be taken much more seriously than it seems to have been taken by the minister, Senator Kemp. It is not acceptable to denigrate those who criticise. One has to answer and counter their criticisms. To be brutally frank, I do not think that has been done. We will be insisting that it is done in the committee stage because I think people deserve answers to the very serious criticisms that have been raised.

To highlight those, as you probably would have expected, I want to raise the issue of the letter received by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation from the Institute of Actuaries of Australia on 14 November. That letter seeks to provide the committee with information regarding its report and the taxation on contributions. They claim that the committee `has not been provided with the correct facts regarding several very important issues'. They go on to say:
Our concerns are addressed below and we urge you to bring them to the attention of the other senators prior to debating these bills in the Senate.

One of their central concerns is the evidence given by the Australian tax office to the effect that an `instruction has been given to the Institute of Actuaries to ensure that there would be a 15 per cent cap on the surcharge liability; in particular, that the Actuary's calculation of the notional surcharge contribution factor would ensure that nobody pays more than 15 per cent'. The Institute of Actuaries absolutely deny this. They say:

There is no provision for a 15% cap in the calculation methodology set out in this ruling and in fact, it is inevitable that the application of this Ruling to defined benefit schemes will result in individual cases occurring from time to time where a member's surcharge liability will exceed the 15% limit.

The Institute of Actuaries are saying that the evidence given to the committee by the tax office is bunkum. We have not been convinced by the tax office's evidence to us and are inclined to support the view confirmed in the Institute of Actuaries letter.

BREAK.PARA: In response to Senator Kemp confirming that the government's policy was that the 15 per cent cap was an absolutely clear and unequivocal intention of the government, the Institute of Actuaries said:

This may be the intent of the government, but it can not be achieved with the current legislation as it applies to defined benefit funds as well as certain accumulation funds, particularly where there is a vesting scale. We can clearly demonstrate this problem to you, should you require more information.

The concerns not only of the industry but also of the Institute of Actuaries continue. They do not believe the government. They do not accept the evidence of the government that members will be protected from having any more than 15 per cent tax paid on their contributions. So the government's policy is in tatters because the 15 per cent tax will be applied not only on lower and middle income earners who fail to provide their tax file numbers but higher income earners. Indeed, anybody who fails to provide their tax file number is liable to pay more than 15 per cent tax on their contributions in certain circumstances.

So none of the guarantees the government continues to offer are achievable. None of them, according to industry or the Institute of Actuaries, are correct. We are asked to take the government on trust and accept that everybody else is wrong. As I say, the evidence given to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation convinced me and convinced the other Labor and Democrat senators that there are still very serious problems with this tax on contributions, that the government's case had not been made out, that the government are only providing rhetoric in answer to serious concerns raised by industry groups and by the Institute of Actuaries, and that they really have an obligation to provide a much more compelling case if they expect this legislation to be carried by the Senate.

On the evidence that has been presented so far, no reasonable person, no uninterested third party, could accept the government's view. They have not produced the goods. As I say, I do not know that the Institute of Actuaries are known as a particularly left‐wing group or as a radical group or as a group that is prone to exaggeration. I think they have taken a very considered and sober look at the legislation, and in their view the government do not meet the claims that they make for the legislation.

I think the government really have to have a serious look at this and accept that what looked like a politically smart move at the time has turned out to be a very poor move in terms of good policy and good legislation. They ought to reconsider their whole approach to the tax on high income earners' contributions to superannuation.
Debate (on motion by Senator Minchin) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 .

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 10.00 p.m. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to celebrate the achievements of the Forest Protection Society. This Friday, this dynamic community organisation will celebrate its 10th anniversary. From humble beginnings born out of frustration at government policies that were destroying small timber communities and their families, an organisation that now boasts 12,000 members and 55 branches across our country was launched.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I acknowledge the current leaders and coordinators of the Forest Protection Society who, I note, are present in the gallery. In particular, I acknowledge: Chris Althaus, the National Director; Heike Phillips, the National Coordinator; and a number of the state coordinators from right around Australia. Let me also place on record my proud membership of the Forest Protection Society.

BREAK.PARA: The aim of the Forest Protection Society has been to gain secure long‐term access to natural resources to generate employment and a future for regional communities and to ensure that our unique Australian forests are scientifically evaluated and sustainably managed for the benefit of future generations and genetic diversity.It seeks to encourage the sensible, balanced multiple use of our forests for the benefit of all Australians. In short, it supports productive conservation.

The Forest Protection Society is a truly community based organisation and has pursued the interests of its members and communities with great vigour and success. For too long, the hardworking regional communities were sidelined and ignored by the powers that be—namely, the federal and state governments. The armchair conservationists, blissfully ignorant of the real issues, ran campaigns which misled the well‐meaning and prejudiced the future of our fellow Australians in regional areas.

Using chemically treated glossy paper, the extreme Greens peddled their propaganda with its emotive language, whilst those who lived in harmony with the forests producing jobs, infrastructure and a truly renewable resource were ignored by virtue of a lack of an organised voice.Well, the righteous indignation of one logger's wife got too much for her, and the Forest Protection Society came into being. I pay tribute to Robyn Bain's pioneering role in its formation.

Since then, the Forest Protection Society has been at the cutting edge of the environment debate throughout Australia. They provide information booths at agricultural shows, educational kits, inspection tours and also an active, sincere voice in what was previously an uncoordinated and marginalised yet very important valuable and productive group within our community.

The educational value of the Forest Protection Society has seen the public become more educated about the facts, and it has seen the extreme Greens lose considerable ground. Indeed, in my own home state of Tasmania the results are obvious. In the late 1980s the Greens gained their zenith of 17.13 per cent of the popular vote. Now, as we get towards the end of the 1990s, they have plummeted to 11 per cent. In the 1980s they had hundreds to their rallies, sometimes thousands. Now they are lucky if they can round up 100 for the signing of the regional forest agreement in Tasmania. This decline can be attributed to the general society being better educated about forestry. Dissemination of facts has been vital and very successful, and I pay tribute to the role of the Forest Protection Society in achieving those results.

What the Forest Protection Society has done is to place on the record and in the public arena the true facts about our forest industry. Timber is from a natural and renewable resource, competing—might I add—with non‐renewable commodities like steel, aluminium and plastics.

Native forests are logged for the purpose of providing sawn timber for housing, furniture and for use in the construction industry. The waste from sawmilling is then either converted into woodchips or burnt and wasted at sawmills. Similarly, in the forests, trees from the harvest area unsuitable for sawmilling are either chipped or left to burn or rot. If woodchipping were to stop, sawmills would still need the same number of trees to be logged. The only difference is that the by‐product would be wasted rather than turned into books and paper.

Let me also say for the chuckling Democrats that the federal government's Resource Assessment Commission determined with its exhaustive study into Australia's forests—1989 to 1992—that there is no evidence that any plant or animal species has been threatened with extinction because of forestry activities. Given that state forests have been logged for more than 100 years, this is sound evidence of the resilience of our forests.

There are a lot of other facts, but the time is running short. The new woodchip regulations which allow for the productive use of our forest waste and the regional forest agreements already signed in the Gippsland area and in my home state of Tasmania are important achievements which have provided jobs and export earnings in an environmentally friendly way. These have been achieved with overwhelming community support, and we are seeing the pendulum swing back to sensible, scientifically based sustainable harvesting of our resources.

The Forest Protection Society has been at the forefront of achieving this balance and putting commonsense back into the debate about our timber industry. And balance and commonsense were desperately needed. At last count it appeared that there were some 400 experts working on the policy on behalf of the trees and just two assigned to cover the impact of industry closures on people and communities.

As Robyn Bain would say, `I don't think it too outrageous to ask that people be given the same consideration as trees.' That such a statement was made—and, indeed, had to be made—is a very sad indictment of the state of the debate concerning the harvesting of our renewable timber resources. It is particularly regrettable when considered in the light of our $2 billion per annum trade deficit in wood products, which sees the importation of wood products from areas around the world which do not have such vigorous forestry guidelines as exist in Australia.

The Forest Protection Society network across this country also provides a great degree of civic‐minded and motivated activity in supporting each other and developing community facilities and making representations for, and on behalf of, their communities in a whole range of areas. In short, the Forest Protection Society has been a welcome addition to Australia's patchwork quilt of community organisations. Its contributions through its members and sizeable network of branches to the forestry conservation debate in this country have been refreshing. Its genuine grassroots and spontaneous growth have really stamped the Forest Protection Society as the organisation of the decade of its life.

I wish the Forest Protection Society well and wish it many happy returns and ongoing success in its vital campaign in informing our fellow Australians about the facts of our vibrant and environmentally friendly forest industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to report on my visit on Sunday to Breamlea, which is a coastal township 20 minutes from Geelong. I was invited to Breamlea to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Breamlea wind generator and to press a switch to restart that generator. The community group which now owns and operates this generator is the Alternative Technology Association. This is a group which has been actively promoting sustainable technologies for more than 20 years.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1994, with funds donated by its members, it saved the wind generator at Breamlea from being dismantled and removed at the time the Victorian state government sold the State Electricity Commission. Like the Howard government, the Kennett government does not regard greenhouse emissions and global warming as issues which warrant action. The Victorian coalition government inherited 10 experimental wind generators from the previous Labor government. When the coalition government privatised electricity in Victoria, it decided to scrap the lot, in spite of the fact that eight out of the 10 proved to be sited where wind conditions would have made them viable.

Three years ago this remarkable and committed community group put in a successful bid for the generator. They repaired the damaged components and got the wind generator restarted. It began feeding power back into the power grid in January 1995. They continue to provide monthly maintenance work on this generator.

This Westwind generator was built in Australia, and it is similar to those used in Europe and the United States. When wind speeds exceed four metres per second, the microprocessor‐based control system connects the machine to the local power grid. The average wind speed at Breamlea is 6.3 metres per second. This single 60‐kilowatt wind generator works day and night to generate non-polluting greenhouse gas free electricity for Melbourne consumers. So far it has produced 680 megawatt hours of electrical energy, which goes straight into the Victorian grid. This generator alone has already saved the emission of 1,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide, which would otherwise have been produced in the Latrobe Valley. Over two million kilograms of CO2 emissions will be saved over the 15 remaining years of the life of this generator.

CityPower, the new owners of Melbourne's electricity supply business, has had a very important role in supporting this wind generator at Breamlea, and for that I congratulate them. The problem that many producers of clean energy face is in finding a buyer. Once again, it is fortunate for Victorians that CityPower has had the foresight to do just that. They have done it even though Breamlea is, in fact, outside the distribution region.

Arrangements like this are supposed to be very straightforward through the national electricity market. This new model of an electricity industry broken up into producers, numerous distributors and systems, which now cross state borders, was hailed as a breakthrough in competition which would drive the cost of electricity down and open the way for alternative energy generators to feed into the grid. In fact, it has been very difficult for small producers like Breamlea to sell power to anyone other than their local power distribution company. Surprise, surprise!

This small volunteer group took an enormous gamble. At the time they considered making the bid, there was no guarantee that they would be able to sell their power. In the event of a blade failure, they might be up for $30,000 for a replacement set. They did not even know whether they would be able to continue to lease the land on which the generator was sited. Eventually, a small group of investors got together and put up the funds and, with the commitment and the support of the members of the Alternative Technology Association, the Breamlea wind generator was restarted.

Small producers like the Breamlea Operations Group are effectively excluded from the open market in which large producers and distributors buy and sell their power, and they are generally stuck with whatever price the local distributor chooses to pay; that is, of course, if they choose to purchase at all.

Australia is way behind other countries in its commitment to wind power, particularly North America and Europe. Quite recently, President Clinton guaranteed that one million homes in the States will be powered by alternative energy over the next few years. Australia, on the other hand, has only one significant wind farm, and that is in Esperance in Western Australia. This farm has two megawatts of Vesta machines connected to a 14‐megawatt diesel power station. In 1993, a 10‐megawatt wind farm proposed by a private consortium on the Victorian coastline was shelved when negotiations on purchasing arrangements broke down with the Victorian government.

The Tasmanian Hydro Electric Commission is well advanced in its plans for a 700‐kilowatt wind farm on King Island in Bass Strait. Pacific Power in Sydney owns and operates a 150‐kilowatt wind turbine. There are plans afoot for a 66‐turbine wind farm near Mount Gambier in South Australia, which is due to commence operations in December next year. But that is about it. In spite of the fact that polls have shown that, given the choice, people would even be prepared to pay a little more for clean, renewable energy, conservative governments in this country in particular have shown enormous reluctance to take the lead.

The Australian Consumers Association recently released the results of a survey it did in July this year on greenhouse. The association found that, whilst only 67 per cent of 1,500 respondents actually understood what the greenhouse effect is, 70 per cent felt that it is extremely important and must be dealt with immediately. Seventy‐nine per cent felt that they were able to personally make some difference in reducing Australia's greenhouse gases. Over 75 per cent said that they were interested in getting solar energy in their homes. More than half of those surveyed said that they were willing to pay a tax on their petrol to help find ways of reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

In fact, less than 10 per cent of Australian households have solar powered hot water systems. This suggests that it is just too difficult or too expensive for people to take that initial step. That is why governments need to take a leading and visionary role in alternative energy.

The Democrats' greenhouse package released this month has some very simple, practical and realistic ways of achieving real commitments to greenhouse gas reductions. For instance, we say that there should be a condition on electricity utilities licences and access to the national grid to see that they work towards improved performance standards. Low interest loans should be offered to help utilities phase out older, heavy polluting power stations and replace them with natural gas in the short term, and renewable technologies in the medium to long term.

Natural gas should be seen as a bridging fuel. Movements to researching, improving and utilising renewable energies must be a top priority. Consumers should be given the option of sourcing their energy supply from renewable sources. Funding of commercial development of renewable energies such as solar, wind, ethanol and other biomass should not only be restored to its pre‐1996 levels but be expanded significantly.

We would like to see a household energy efficiency trust set up to offer interest free loans to encourage households to switch to solar heating and improve insulation. This could be funded by a grant of $200 million a year by drawing on the diesel fuel subsidy for the mining industry. The loans could be repaid over six to eight years, making the trust self‐funding.

These are just a couple of the suggestions from our package. I urge the government to take a closer look at this paper and at the excellent work being done out in the community to help turn around our appalling record on greenhouse gas emissions. It can be done. It does not cost jobs. All it needs is some leadership and commitment by a government to get it right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on another matter that is of great concern to the Demo crats, an issue that has environmental implications as well as economic implications in my own state of Queensland and an issue that was reported on to some extent today in the Sydney Morning Herald —that is, what is labelled as a catastrophe in the Daintree area in Far North Queensland. That catastrophe relates to the clear-felling of rainforests, the draining of wetlands and the destruction of the tourist values that have made that region famous. A collective of Daintree tourist operators is so concerned about land clearing that it has published advertisements in local newspapers to express its outrage at this destruction.

SPEECH.PARA: This lowland rainforest is critical habitat for cassowaries and tree kangaroos. It is being cleared basically just to make way for further grazing. The Daintree area is pretty well known to a lot of people by name at least. It was listed as part of the northern section of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area in 1988. It was listed primarily for its superlative natural values. The rainforest there is incredibly old and represents some major stages in our evolutionary and biological history.

I could reel off a number of percentages of plants, bird species, reptiles, et cetera that are found in that area and in that area only. Rather than do that, it is probably easier to just say that it is a spectacular area. I would very much recommend to anyone who has not been up there that they do go up there because it is just a magnificent piece of this planet. It is a magnificent experience for anybody who does have the privilege to go to that area. Given the threat that is being posed to that area at the moment, it is even more important than ever that people get up there before it disappears forever. That certainly seems to be a danger that is being presented.

The Cairns and Far North Environment Centre, which has done so much in the far north of Queensland to bring attention to the threats to the environment in that part of the world, has been desperately trying to make clear to people how much threat is being posed by the current level of clearing that is occurring in the Daintree region. Lots of people, including me up until a few years ago, assume that, given how wonderful this area is and the fact that it has got world heritage status, it would be protected—`How could anybody think that that sort of area could be at risk of being clear‐felled by people just wanting to basically run a few cattle across the place?' But, unfortunately, that is the case.

As the coordinator of the Cairns and Far North Environment Centre said recently, there is a widespread misconception among Australians that the rainforests of the Daintree are protected from land clearing and inappropriate development. In fact, almost all of the lowland coastal rainforest habitat in the Daintree is neither national park nor world heritage areas. The current protected area is hopelessly inadequate in terms of being able to protect the Daintree's world famous natural values. I think it is absolutely crucial that we do all we can to make sure that those values are protected before it is too late.

Part of the attempts to protect that area occurred through the Daintree rescue package—something that the Democrats advocated very strongly for back in the earlier part of this decade. We were very glad to see some money provided by the Commonwealth and state governments back in 1994 to buy back some freehold blocks of land to prevent some large-scale residential and tourist development and the land clearing that occurs as part of that.

That money is almost all used up now, unfortunately, but the vision to buy back the Daintree area for the people of Queensland, the people of Australia as a whole and, indeed, for the people of the planet and for future generations, is yet to be fulfilled. Throughout the far north of the state, people are strongly advocating that that vision be completed and extra funds be provided to finish the job.

Basically, the funds that have been provided to date risk being wasted if areas are bought back, but in insufficient amounts to enable the ecological values of that area to be preserved. If wide scale clearing and development occurs around it, then the environmental and economic values of that area will be at risk. Certainly, the tourism potential of that area is clear for anybody to see who wishes to look.

BREAK.PARA: It is crucial that we protect this land from land clearing by ensuring that adequate land clearing laws exist which are enforced, as well as by buying the land in that area to protect it from the things that can happen when it is freehold title. It is that issue of ensuring that land clearing laws are enforced that is crucial to this problem.

After a fair bit of pain and agony, the local Douglas Shire Council has finally introduced some land clearing laws for that area but, unfortunately, the council does not appear to have the will to enforce those laws. The Mayor of Douglas Shire Council, Mike Berwick, who has been a great defender and supporter of preserving what makes that part of the world so special, has been having a lot of trouble convincing his own council to enforce those laws. That is a great tragedy, not just for the people of that area but for the people of Queensland and the rest of Australia.

The area is under threat not just from land clearing, but also from the Queensland government's plan to connect the electricity grid to properties north of the Daintree River. The Democrats have spoken on that many times in the past in this chamber, and more than a year ago my colleague Senator Woodley from Queensland brought to the Senate's attention the threat that is posed there. Unfortunately, the threat from the Queensland government is still there and is stronger than ever. It appears that the federal government is willing to let that happen.

Some 500 freehold landowners in the area have offered their properties for sale to the government as part of trying to encourage buying back in that area for future generations, but only 80 have been purchased, according to a spokesperson from the Daintree Rainforest Task Force. Of the $14 million allocated to buy back private land in that area, only a very small amount is left, as I said earlier. We have well over 400 property owners willing to sell their properties, but at the moment the money simply is not there for the Daintree Planning Coordination Group or the Wet Tropics Management Authority to spend.

The Democrats wish to point out to the federal government, as well as to the Queensland government, that this is a crucial issue, and it is at flashpoint at this very moment. If nothing is done in the near future to address this problem—both in terms of the ongoing land clearing that is being done in contravention of the land clearing laws that have been introduced by the local government, and in terms of the Queensland government's plan to introduce the connection of the mains electricity grid to the area north of the Daintree, with the likely impacts of massive population increases, infrastructure development and the probability of resort developments occurring in that area—then the values that make the Daintree so special and enable it to be listed as a world heritage area will be lost to the people of Queensland. That is a matter of grave concern to me and to the Australian Democrats.

It is time for action on this issue and it needs to happen very quickly. Rather than see the magnificent Daintree area suffer death by a thousand cuts, the Democrats call on the federal and Queensland governments to act now before it is too late. It certainly will hang over the heads of the coalition governments at both federal and state level if they do not act now while the chance is there to preserve this marvellous area for future generations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What programs and/or grants administered by the portfolio provide assistance to people living in the following federal electorates: (a) Bass, Denison, Franklin, Lyons and Braddon; and (b) what was the level of funding provided through the programs or grants to each electorate for each of the 1994‐95, 1995‐96, 1996‐97 financial years; and (c) what level of funding was budgeted for in each program or grant to each electorate for the 1997‐98 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Compensation Program provides for pensions and associated allowances to be paid to entitled veterans and dependants, including those living in the specified electorates.
The Health Care and Services Program provides for health care and treatment for entitled veterans and dependants, including those living in the specified electorates.

The Training and Information Program (TIP) provides training and information about Veterans' Affairs benefits and services, legislation and procedures to members of ex‐service organisations who assist veterans and their dependants.

The Claims Assistance Grants Scheme (CAGS) provides assistance to ex‐service organisations throughout Australia to obtain resources such as computer equipment, accommodation and trained officers which they need to assist veterans and their dependants in accessing Veterans' Affairs benefits and services. The Scheme was an initiative announced in the 1996‐97 Budget.

The Their Service—Our Heritage commemorative program provides funding for purposes such as commemorative events, public awareness, education and memorial projects. The aim of the program is to involve as many Australians as possible in commemorative activities and projects. The commemorative program was an initiative announced in the 1996‐97 Budget. Grants made under this program have replaced those made through the Minister's Discretionary Fund and the Australia Remembers 1945‐1995 program.

The Residential Care Development Scheme improves the access of entitled veterans and their widow(er)s to high quality residential aged care services and community aged care packages and helps the ex‐service organisations to continue their role in providing residential and innovative aged care services.

The Joint Venture Scheme maintains and improves the independence and quality of life of the veteran community by assisting ex‐service organisations to provide social and personal support services, in particular to those organisations which do not have the capacity to fund projects themselves.

The Community Care Seeding Grants Program maintains and improves the independence and quality of life of veterans and their widow(er)s living in the community by increasing access to community care services and residential and community‐based respite care. The Program was introduced in 1995‐96.
The Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service (VVCS) provides counselling and support for veterans and their families residing in metropolitan, rural and remote areas across Australia.

Services are provided for veterans and their families in rural and remote areas under the Country Outreach Program which allows access to contracted professional counselling services in their locations, administratively supported by VVCS staff from designated VVCS centres.

A number of programs have also been developed under the Younger Veterans Program including residential lifestyle courses, specialised group courses and involvement in the treatment and ongoing management of veterans with chronic conditions such as post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), with strong links to intensive hospital-based treatment programs.

In Tasmania, services in the southern electorates of Denison and Franklin are based in Hobart; services in the northern electorates of Braddon and Bass are based in Launceston; and services in the central electorate of Lyons are shared between Hobart and Launceston.

Dementia Care Training for Carers provides training and materials on the common problems associated with dementia, to assist carers with their day to day management. It also provides skills to keep carers well, and able to cope with the stresses involved in caring for someone with dementia at home.

The Health Promotion Grants Program and Never Too Late joint funding initiative with The Australian Sports Commission aim to assist veterans towards a greater awareness of relevant health issues and to help change the behaviour of veterans toward healthier lifestyles to prevent illness and improve health and quality of life.

(b) Estimates of expenditure within the specified electorates on pensions and allowances and treatment have been made by pro‐rating the numbers of veterans and/or dependants in each electorate and applying this to the actual Australia‐wide expenditure in 1994‐95, 1995‐96 and 1996‐97.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) (a) Did the Coalition parties promise at the 1996 federal election that the Defence Housing Authority (DHA) would give special attention to housing in isolated areas and the standard of accommodation for on-base single personnel; and (b) is that still the Government's intention.
(2) What forms of special attention to housing in isolated areas has the DHA been asked by the Government to give.
(3) How much accommodation for on-base single personnel has the DHA been asked to provide to date.
(4) Is the DHA to be subject to the full range of competitive neutrality measures such as taxes and providing a business rate of return on its assets.
(5) Is a study proceeding into the option of disposing of Government ownership of the DHA.
(6) Is there to be a study into the legislation governing the DHA; if so, for what purpose has the study been ordered.
(7) Does the Government have any policies on how Defence families are to be assisted with housing if the DHA is dismantled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with advice to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel the following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (l) (a) Yes. The Coalition policy on Defence stated "The Defence Housing Authority will give special attention to housing in isolated areas and the standard of accommodation for on-base single personnel." The standard of accommodation for on-base personnel has been rigorously reviewed and in 1996 a comprehensive survey of living in accommodation was undertaken across Australia. Recent development proposals for Townsville and Darwin have been based on the outcomes of these reviews and include providing soldier accommodation of a single room with individual ensuite.
(b) Yes.

(2) The function of DHA is to provide housing to meet the operational needs of the Australian Defence Force and the requirements of the Department of Defence. To cater for fluctuations in the number of houses required, DHA provides around 85% of the total requirement with the remaining houses being rented by individuals on the private market. In isolated areas where there is little or no private market. DHA provides 100% of the housing requirement.
(3) None. DHA do not provide accommodation for on-base single personnel.

(4) DHA will need to comply with the Commonwealth's Competitive Neutrality Policy Statement. The degree to which DHA will comply with, and the timing for application of, these principles is presently a matter for discussion between the relevant shareholder Ministers.

(5) Reviews are being undertaken of the need for continued Commonwealth ownership of Commonwealth GBEs. The previous government categorised the Defence Housing Authority as a GBE and the review process thus includes the Authority.
(6) A review of the Defence Housing Authority Act 1987 is required under the Commonwealth's Legislation Review Schedule for 1997-98.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 16 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What qualitative and quantitative research has been undertaken by the Department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(2) What was the nature of the research undertaken (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation) and to whom were the results of the research available.
(3) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(4) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: Details of qualitative and quantitative research commissioned by the Department and the portfolio agencies since 3 March 1996 appear below. The details encompass polling and marketing research conducted by external parties and do not include other research or research performed in house.
ENVIRONMENT PRIORITIES AND CO-ORDINATION

(1) Research to evaluate the impact of the first independent national report on the state of Australia's environment entitled Australia: State of the Environment 1996 and of the executive summary to that report.

(2) The evaluation research had three components. First, there was an analysis of self-completion surveys which were distributed with the main report and the executive summary. The questionnaires were five and four pages long respectively. A total of 325 completed questionnaires were received. Second, there was a telephone survey of 500 people in the general community. Third, there were two group discussions with 8-9 persons in Sydney and Canberra as well as 15 personal interviews spread across Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne The evaluation report was provided to the Department, the Minister, the State of the Environment Advisory Council and the Commonwealth/State Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council State of the Environment Reporting Task Force.
(3) Bell Dignam and Associates Pty Ltd.
ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION
A.
(1) Cleaner Production Demonstration Project—Communications Component
(2) Research to determine the level of community/industry awareness of cleaner production and its benefits following the completion of the Cleaner Production Demonstration Project.

Nature of research: survey (approx 25 questions over the phone) of 220 organisations, including small to medium enterprises, government departments, regulators, media organisations, and environmental organisations. The Project is not yet finished.
(3) AMR: Quantum Harris, subcontracted by Edelman Public Relations World Wide Pty Ltd.
B.
(1) Barriers and Motivators to the Uptake of Cleaner Production

(2) Research consultancy for the National Strategy for Cleaner Production to determine barriers to, and motivators for, the uptake of cleaner production in Australia, including financial, regulatory, information, and business accounting mechanisms.

Nature of research: Collation, review and critical analysis of relevant domestic and international literature, including database searches and electronic information networks. Consultation with industry representatives, key government departments and relevant regulatory agencies, other interest groups and expert individuals including academia.
Evaluation included in final report. Report used for the National Strategy for Cleaner Production (under development), available to interested parties upon request.
(3) Australian Centre for Environmental Law (ACEL).
C.
(1) Education and Training in Cleaner Production.

(2) Research consultancy for the National Strategy for Cleaner Production to review the availability of cleaner production courses in Australia, assess the needs of industry and business for cleaner production training and the existing capacity to meet that need, and develop proposals for improving the co-ordination, efficiency and delivery of such training.

Nature of research: Identify and assess existing provision of training through consultation with academic, vocational and industry based training providers and review of education databases; determine industry needs for training through telephone survey of 60 large (approx. 5 questions), medium and small enterprises.
Evaluation included in final report. Report used for the National Strategy for Cleaner Production (under development), available to interested parties upon request.
(3) Infotech Research Pty Ltd.
AUSTRALIAN AND WORLD HERITAGE
(1) Research into community understanding of the terms `wilderness' and `wild rivers' and community attitudes about wilderness and wild rivers.
(2) The research comprised two methodologies:
. four focus groups held in metropolitan and rural areas; and
. a Computer-assisted Telephone Interviewing (CATI) survey of a national random sample of 1059 adults. There were 22 questions in the survey.

The results form two volumes, some of which is mainly of interest to the Australian Heritage Commission. The Minister for the Environment, Senator Robert Hill, released the main results of the survey at a press conference on 4 September 1996. A media release with highlights of the results was issued Australia-wide on that date. An explanation of the methodology and a summary of the results was also widely distributed to interested people including media. A limited number of the two-volume report of results of public interest was made available to people interested in the details of the research. The media release, highlights, research summary and explanation of methodology are also made available on request and the two-volume research details are available from the Commission's library.
(3) Roy Morgan Research Centre, Pty Ltd. 21 Torrens Street, Braddon ACT 2612.
CORPORATE SERVICES
A.
(1) Global Warming. Market research consultancy—information and education objectives for the revised National Greenhouse Strategy (NGS) March 1997.

(2) Community attitudes and knowledge on greenhouse issues related to the information requirements for communications strategy in the NGS. There were ten focus groups with sample sizes ranging from 8 to 10 people. There were 13 questions running to 3 pages covered both by written answer and direct questions by facilitator. Evaluation was completed by the consultant and the results have not been released but are publicly available. They will be used to prepare the NGS in late 1997.
(3) Keys Young, Sydney.
B.
(1) Woodsmoke. Market research and campaign effectiveness consultancy—Breathe the Benefits campaign in Tasmania and Western Australia on restricting smoke from woodheaters—September 1997.

(2) 452 people were sampled in both the pre- and post-evaluation in Tasmania. In Western Australia 321 people were questioned before the campaign and 642 after. The evaluation was conducted by telephone interview. There were 31 questions to voluntary respondents. Evaluation was completed by the consultant. Results have not been released but are available publicly. They will be used to plan a national campaign in 1998.
(3) CR Attwater and VJ Thorpe, Bellerive, Tasmania.
(4) $30,000 overall for market research. $8,000 allocated specifically campaign study only. Other funding was allocated to technical background study on attitudes to woodheaters.
BUREAU OF METEOROLOGY

(1) The Bureau of Meteorology has conducted two surveys into use of and attitudes to Bureau weather information. The first, in 1996, was a pilot study. The second, more major survey began in May 1997 and will continue for 12 months.

(2) The 1996 pilot study into usage of and attitudes to Bureau weather information consisted of 220 telephone interviews in Victoria and NSW, entailing 23 questions. The major survey is progressive, with 108 telephone interviews per State per three months (total $3,024 per annum) consisting of 31 questions with an average interview time of 11 minutes. Details of the survey are available from the Bureau of Meteorology.
(3) The pilot study was undertaken by Frank Small and Associates and the major survey by Reark Research.
(4) The cost of the pilot study was $15,000 and of the major survey $57,600.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 22 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) When was the Hobart office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman established; (b) what was its annual budget; and (c) when was it closed.
(2) What services were provided through that office.
(3) What was the nature of the complaints made to that office and how many complaints were received.
(4) How do residents of Tasmania now gain access to services provided by the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman given the closure of the Hobart office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Ombudsman has never had an office in Hobart. Until 31 May 1996 it had an agency arrangement with the Tasmanian Ombudsman. This arrangement commenced on 21 February 1980 and cost $101,000 in 1994‐95 and just under $106,000 in 1995‐96.

(2) The Tasmanian Ombudsman acted as delegate for the Commonwealth Ombudsman and received and investigated complaints within the Commonwealth Ombudsman's jurisdiction. Other services included the provision of advice, referral to other bodies or agencies, and outreach activities.

(3) Complaints were received on a range of matters within the Commonwealth Ombudsman's purview. 428 complaints were received in 1994‐95 and 380 from 1995 to the termination of the arrangement in 1996.

(4) Residents of Tasmania can gain access to the Commonwealth Ombudsman's services through a toll‐free telephone service or in writing, by fax or by E‐Mail. Nationally, over 95% of complainants access the Commonwealth Ombudsman's services using one of these methods.
